headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's c
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead,

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Ashley, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the fourth quarter of 2015 and the full year 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer; and with me today are Scott
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Ashley, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the fourth quarter of 2015 and the full year 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer; and with me today are Scott Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney and Becky Barkley, our primary Investor Relations contact. I will begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the fourth quarter and the full year results for 2015. This will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items. 
After I finish my remarks, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating, provide his perspective on our operating results and give some thoughts on the outlook. As we have done in the past, we have opened up this call to the public and are doing a webcast. And that webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. Additionally, to help with the discussions, we are provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be refreshing the slides this morning in my comments. We filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information and we plan to file our 10-K in the next few weeks. 
I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. And please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation has some of the necessary reconciliations, which have been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements I corporate them with this reference. A 16% improvement in OSB price in the fourth quarter as compared to the third quarter 2015 and positive adjusted EBITDA for all 4 segments contributed to strong earnings for the fourth quarter of 2015. On a non-GAAP annual basis, LP recorded 2% lower sales, for a 52% higher adjusted EBITDA. We exited 2015 with lean OSB finished goods inventory, low raw material cost and a favorable U.S. dollar versus Canadian dollar exchange rate. We are well-positioned in 2016 to take advantage of the ongoing U.S. housing -- the ongoing recovery in U.S. housing. Here are some details behind our earnings reports. 
Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the fourth quarter and full year 2015 consolidated results. We are reporting net sales of $463 million for the fourth quarter of 2015, a 2% increase from the net sales of $454 million reported in the fourth quarter of 2014. In the fourth quarter, we recorded a net loss of $8 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.05 compared to a net loss of $43 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.30 in the fourth quarter of 2014. The adjusted income from continuing operations for the quarter was $1 million or $0.01 per diluted share, based upon a normalized tax rate of 35% as compared to a loss of $32 million or loss per diluted share of $0.23 recorded in the fourth quarter of 2014. 
Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations were $34 million in the quarter compared to negative adjusted EBITDA of $17 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. For the year ended December 31, 2015, we recorded a net loss of $88 million or loss per diluted share of $0.62 compared to a loss of $75 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.53 for 2014. The adjusted loss for the year was $46 million or a loss of $0.32 per diluted share based upon the normalized tax rate of 35% compared to a loss of $60 million or $0.42 loss per diluted share in 2014. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $67 million for 2015 compared to $44 million in 2014. 
Now moving on to Slide 5 and a review of our segment results, starting with OSB. OSB recorded net sales for the fourth quarter of 2015 of $206 million, slightly higher than the $203 million in net sales recorded in the fourth quarter of 2014. OSB reported operating income of $11 million compared to a loss of $29 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. This is the first quarter of operating income in our OSB segment's since the fourth quarter of 2013. And adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations for the quarter was a positive $25 million compared to negative $15 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. Pricing from OSB was higher by 10%, which resulted in an improved operating result by $18 million. In an addition to the improved OSB price, results benefited from reductions in raw material costs as well as the positive impact of the Canadian currency incurred by Canadian operation as compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. 
For the fourth quarter of 2015, the average of the U.S. Canadian exchange rate was $0.75 as compared to $0.88 in the fourth quarter of 2014. For the full year, OSB recorded operating sales of $808 million compared to $855 million, down 6% from the prior year. And we recorded an operating loss of $46 million compared to $53 million in 2014. Adjusted EBITDA for 2015 was $12 million compared to $4 million in 2014. Sales volumes increased 2% and prices decreased 7%. The decrease in selling price unfavorably impacted operating results by $61 million. Offsetting the reduction in sales price for the year was a reduction of raw material cost relates petroleum based of raw materials and a positive impact of Canadian currency exchange rates on the cost incurred by Canadian operation as compared to the prior year. For the full year of 2015, the average U.S. dollar Canadian exchange rate was $0.78 as compared to $0.91 in 2014. 
On Slide 6, we reported the results of the siding business. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel signing products as well as a minor amount of OSB. Our Siding segment had a record sales and a record year for sale, operating income and adjusted EBITDA. For the fourth quarter of 2015, the Siding segment reported sales of $141 million, operating income of $14 million and adjusted EBITDA of $19 million, all comparable to the fourth quarter of 2014. For the quarter, SmartSide average sales were up 2% and volumes decreased 5%. Volumes increased in of our SmartSide siding line due to customers continue to rebalance our inventory based upon expected housing starts and labor availability, which has slowed in housing completion. 
During the third quarter of 2015, we began the conversion of our smart value OSB mill to a SmartSide mill. During the majority of the fourth quarter, this mill was not operational. It is estimated that the additional cost incurred at the Swan Valley facility during the fourth quarter related to that conversion as well as market related downtime was approximately $6 million. For the year, the Siding segment reported sales of $636 million, an increase of 3% from $617 million reported in 2014. Siding segment reported operating income of $93 million compared to $80 million and adjusted EBITDA of $114 million as compared to $98 million in 2014. The estimated impact of the additional cost incurred at the Swan Valley facility for the full year is approximately $11 million. 
Now please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results of our Engineered Wood Products. This segments includes I-Joist laminates/lumbar laminates, near lumber OSB produced at our main facility plus other related products. This segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the joint venture are under sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. The Engineered Wood Products segment reported sales of $75 million in the fourth quarter 2015, up from $66 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. Segments results were breakeven in the fourth quarter of '15 as compared to a loss of $6 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. For the fourth quarter of 2015, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was positive $3 million as compared to negative $4 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. The best quarter in EWP versus since the third quarter of 2014. Volumes of I-Joist were up 21%, while volumes of LVL and were up 29% compared to the same quarter last year. Pricing was lower by 1% in LVL and LSL and higher by 5% -- I'm sorry, higher by 4% in I-Joist. During the quarter and the full year of 2015, which in the mix of OSB products at a halt in operations, Manufacturing more value-added OSB and less commodity products. The impact of this change resulted in improving operating result of $800,000 in the quarter and $3.5 million for the full year. 
For the year, sales were $286 million, up from $281 million in 2014. The segment's operating loss in 2015 was $7 million as compared to $14 million in the same period of 2014. Adjusted EBITDA improved to $6 million for 2015 from breakeven in 2014. 
Moving on to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded sales of $34 million as compared to $36 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. Operating income is $3 million and adjusted EBITDA was $5 million for the fourth quarter of 2015, essentially flat with the fourth quarter of 2014. Volumes in Chile were up 9% and up 15% in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. The sales volume increase in Chile was due to improved housing demand and the increase in Brazil was due to increased exports. Brazil continues to be in an economic recession with continued political appeal Pricing was down 12% in Chile and down 23% in Brazil. In local currency, Chile's pricing was up 3% with the same quarter in 2014 and Brazil's pricing was up 13%, primarily due to the impact of higher exports. For the year, our South American segment recorded sales of $135 million as compared to $150 million in 2014. Operating income was $10 million for 2015 compared to $11 million in 2014. And adjusted EBITDA declined to $18 million from $20 million in the same period of 2014. 
Total selling, general and administrative expenses were $38 million in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to $41 million in the same quarter of 2014. For the quarter, as the decrease in selling, general and administrative expenses is primarily due to lower compensation expense. For the year, our selling, general and administrative expenses are higher at $153 million as compared to $150 million for 2014, primarily due to higher sales and marketing expenses. 
Please refer to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of December 31, 2015, we had cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $455 million; working capital of $626 million; net cash of $88 million. And in addition to the $455 million of cash on our balance sheet, we had $200 million of availability on our credit facility. Capital expenditures for 2015 were $114 million. We are planning on spending between $120 million and $135 million in capital expenditures for 2016. Approximately $100 million has been allocated that North American project; 50% for growth and the remaining for capital maintenance and cost reduction project. The remaining $35 million has been allocated to our South American segment, primarily for the building of the third mill in Chile. And we anticipate that the South American capital expenditures will be funded by cash on hand in Chile as well as the local bank financing. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Curt for his comments

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for that review, Sally. Good morning to all of you and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP safety performance. For the full year, our total incident rate for recordable injuries or TIR was 0.47, which is the 10th-year in the rol
componenttext:
Thanks for that review, Sally. Good morning to all of you and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP safety performance. For the full year, our total incident rate for recordable injuries or TIR was 0.47, which is the 10th-year in the role, which LP was 1.0. Now that impressive statistics that demonstrates LP's commitment to safety is there for the second year in a row that contractors that we use in our capital projects were injury free, a remarkable accomplishment. As I typically do on this call, we provide a few comments on our results and accomplishments in the fourth quarter and the year, discuss the housing market and give you my views for 2016. After that, I will turn it back over to Sally to take your questions. As Sally just reported, all of our segments recorded positive EBITDA in the fourth quarter. For the full year, our EBITDA improved by over 50%, despite a $62 million negative impact in both sales and EBITDA due to lower OSB prices than the prior year. 
As Sally also mentioned, we did benefit from lower raw materials cost in the favorable Canadian exchange rate. In our OSB business, we reacted to lower sales prices by holding our sales volumes relatively flat with lower production due to the conversion of Swan Valley siding in the second half of the year. We were able to shift the same amount by bringing down the inventory of finished goods across the system. This means that we entered the first quarter with very lean inventories, which should be beneficial as the building season resumes in a month or so. We had the most profitable year ever in our siding business with a 16% increase in EBITDA despite absorbing about $10 million cost in the second half of the year associated with the Swan Valley conversion. With Swan operating, we have unleashed our salesforce to return us to the growth way rate that we have demonstrated in the past. 
Engineer Wood with over $3 billion in EBITDA recorded the best quarterly results in many years. For the year, EWP adjusted EBITDA was almost $6 million compared to breakeven last year. In South America, we had another strong year, although reported results reflected a significant weakening of the Chilean peso of about 15% and the Brazilian real over 15% against U.S. dollar. Following approval by the various governmental agencies for environmental permit for the third mill in Chile last October, we did get through the mandatory waiting period. This is good news as we are in a sold-out position in Chile and we are seeing improving economies in Argentina and Colombia. I am anticipating that our board will approve this project next summer and the construction will begin shortly thereafter. 
The news about the housing market continues to be good. However, it is not been strong as forecasted. U.S. Census released their data on housing on January 20. For December, housing starts came in at $1.149 million, while our permits were higher $1.232 million. Other positive housing related news includes, while the rate of the household formation fell a bit in the fourth quarter, we did in last year with an average of 1.7 million household formations, which is significantly higher, more than double than the last few years. This could mean that the millennial are finally on the move. 
Medium home prices for the year were up 7.6% and December marked the 46th consecutive month of the year-over-year gains. First time homebuyers purchased about 30% of the existing homes in 2015 and this was up slightly from last year. The total inventory of housing for sale is 3% lower than a year ago, which is creating some shortages. On the financing side, average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rates were at 3.92 and this is for the week ending January 15. As we look at the consensus forecast for this year, currently stands at $1.263 million is about 14% increase over last year. The consensus for 2017 is $1.385 million, which is the further 10% increase. 
For LP, we are using a budget assumption of $1.2 million to $1.25 million for 2016. Nonresidential construction in area that we do participate in was up 9.3% through the end of November. The 5 most important subsectors for structural panel demand are commercial, offices, religious, healthcare and schools, registered an increase of 22% for office buildings and 5% for healthcare and religious buildings. 
Finally, sales of building materials and supply dealers were up about 4% in 2015 compared to the prior year. So our view for 2016, I just returned from the policy advisory board meeting of the Hardware Joint Center Housing Studies held in Washington D.C. earlier this week. While almost all the participants shared their view of the 2016 will continue to show that 10% to 12% growth in new housing and a continuation of demand in repair and modeling. To a person, the CEOs expressed this may surrounding the current political situation, frustration with financial markets and increasing concern about the more restrictive regulatory environment. 
So with that being said, I do share that as we look back at 2016 post election, I do believe that housing will be one of the few bright spots in the economy. For LP, January order rates were strong presiding in EWP and a bit muted for OSB as reflected by slightly declined price during the month. In the first part of January, we did have our annual sales meeting and also attended the international builders show in Las Vegas. At these 2 events, we had a chance to talk our field sales folks, builders and channel partners. I would summarize that the overwhelming settlement was cautious and optimized. Almost there was a feeling housing and repair model markets in 2016 will be stronger than 2015, but there are some headwinds. Based on the forecast, it does appear that multifamily housing will be a little over 35% of the mix in the U.S. for the next few years. Additionally, with the aging baby boomers and the explosion of the sharing economy like we are increasingly seeing builders single-family units as square footage to accommodate an elderly relative or short-term renter in a separate space. This probably showed up and that the average size of single-family new construction 2015 was the highest ever. 
In Canada, we did see decline in housing starts in the fourth quarter, primarily focused at lower multifamily starts in Ontario and a cut back in the provinces associated with Oil Sands. In 2015 starts were almost 200,000 units and we forecast this to be lower by about 5%. South America, the outlook continues to be mixed, brazil is clearly struggling, while the political situation and continued economic downturn. The bright spot for LP's operation in Brazil is that the dramatically lower Brazilian real has created some export opportunities for us. In Chile, lower copper prices heard the economy, but the government continues to take an active role in funding replacement housing that was destroyed by natural disasters, which benefits LP. Changing government in Argentina and the immediate relaxing of import, export controls, should lead to higher volumes into this country and the continued emergence of the Colombian economy also creates export demand for our products in South America. The retail demand both on Home Depot and Lowe's forecast the same store sales being in that 4% to 5% range for 2016. 
On the longer-term, there has been nothing and that has happened recently that has changed my outlook as I continue to believe that we have several more years of housing growth in front of us based on the under building during the last decade, population demographics in the slow rate of recovery so far. As I said in the past, the constraining factors to more immediate robust housing, labor at all levels, available lots and access to credit for the first time homebuyer. Again, as I said before, I believe the labor issue is based where the builders will ease either through increased employment or changing construction practices that will reduce the need for labor. The shortage continues to result in a multiple factors including the regulation, shortage demand employments and funding for infrastructure. 
On the financing side, we know there will be no significant changes after the 2016 elections. The Fed interest-rate hike in December had very little impact on mortgage rates and based on Fed Chairman's results or comments, yesterday, it looks like they will be very cautious and the custard additional rate hikes. The other interesting trend that is happening is the traditional depository banks with the exception of Wells Fargo have essentially withdrawn from the FHA mortgage market due to increased reserves, documentation requirements and continued litigation from federal and state regulators. The good news is new entrants like quicken loans with their Super Bowl commercials are taking up the slack. 
As we look at the forecast demand for our products, the challenges faced by builders in the emerging trends, there is much than LP can and is doing to take advantage of these opportunities. Let me give you some concrete examples. In single-family new construction, we had very good success in growing the barrier achieving brand to address energy requirements in a number of jurisdictions. We expect to continue this push. In the Urban interface zones in places like California and Colorado, the requirement for fire has given lift to our plane lock product. This is also true in Pennsylvania and Ohio where codes have changed related to fire burned through in the floors above unfinished basements. Our newly released flame back I-Joist addresses this need. In multifamily, these projects also require increased fire redundancy, acoustical performance and low maintenance durable siding. In January, I was joined by sessions of Alabama and other dignitaries at the groundbreaking of $15 million project to add flame block capability to our existing Heart County Alabama mill. This post processing facility will augment the capacity that we have available through our relationship with international bearer technologies. Not only does this meet the technical needs defined by the various billing codes, it also lowers the labor content as structural integrity and gives the architect more design flexibility. 
With our smart siding products include lap and builder multifamily projects are both best looking product available, but also the durability to survive harsh treatment for renters. In like commercial, our EWP products have long player role in this segment as the ease of use and design flexibility are critical to the architect and builder. At the recent international builder show, we introduced a sub street panel that can be used to replicate a stack of look with less cost and less labor. This is important both like commercial as well as like other areas like the Southwest where was a preferred finish. South America, we see very good opportunities to expand and grow our business there. 
As mentioned earlier, we have cleared all the necessary hurdles and our environmental permitting for a third mill in Chile. That will serve the domestic market as well as other countries on the continent. Our plan is to redeploy existing equipment as we  have done in the past to limit the capital investment to $55 million and $60 million. The timing of this construction is likely to be later this year. 
On the industrial side, we continue to develop products for markets beyond residential construction. In this category, we will include panels used in furniture manufacturing, various transportation applications and substrates used for decorative panels, cabinetry and then interior panels. So in conclusion, we continue to rise in housing activity, more normalized repair and modeling activity and new uses for our current products is good for our stakeholders as LP is well-positioned to capitalize on this growth. Further, we are committed to innovation to meet our customer needs and products, efficiencies and affordable costs. 
With that, let me turn it over to Sallie for Q&A.

componenttextpreview: As we said in the earlier quarters, we were in a sold out position we are on allocation. So we really didn't have any more product to sell until the Swan Valley facility came online in the October, late October, early November timeframe, and we have been
componenttext: As we said in the earlier quarters, we were in a sold out position we are on allocation. So we really didn't have any more product to sell until the Swan Valley facility came online in the October, late October, early November timeframe, and we have been ramping up that production. So what we have been doing and comment I made is unleashing the salesforce that is back exactly what we did at the international or at the international sales meeting in early January. We have armed our salesforce with the tools necessary to get us back on the growth rate from the volume standpoint. I would hate to add though if you look at our record results from an EBITDA standpoint. I mean, on allocation, you do have the opportunity to high grade your customer mix, if you will, and that's exactly what our salesforce did. As you were able to take the product that we had available and get a higher price for that, that's why you saw the record EBITDA. So on 2016, the challenges to go back to probably some of those customers who we hydrated out of it, offer them the opportunity to participate in buying these products going forward and manage the gross margin along with the growth rates.

componenttext: We are not going to provide any direct guidance on that, but what I will say is when we put Swan Valley in place, there were some siding projects to maximize our system. And we are doing some of those this year and that will continue into next year. The other thing and as you look a longer-term, this was as mentioned, we didn't have much growth in siding this year because we missed time when the new capacity came online. So we have to be cognizant of that and make sure that we have siding capacity in front of the demand. So you will see in the next probably 2 to 3 years that we will have to do something to add additional siding capacity. As we believe Swan will only give us about 2.5 years of headroom.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curt, when you think about housing recovery in longer-term in the that you mentioned, we clearly seem to be seeing more of strength in multifamily, are you thinking about the long-term rate of demand differently than you were, maybe 3 or 4 years ago?
componenttext: Curt, when you think about housing recovery in longer-term in the that you mentioned, we clearly seem to be seeing more of strength in multifamily, are you thinking about the long-term rate of demand differently than you were, maybe 3 or 4 years ago?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I have just said at the Hardward meeting, you can prove Mark Zandi talked in his comment is demographics is destiny. And he just said with the number of millennials coming forward and the need for housing, whether it's single-family or multifamily,
componenttext: Again, I have just said at the Hardward meeting, you can prove Mark Zandi talked in his comment is demographics is destiny. And he just said with the number of millennials coming forward and the need for housing, whether it's single-family or multifamily, we are going to have to pick up the pace. And I think that was a common theme among the participants. What I believe is that, we are probably fully recovered in the multifamily and you should see about that same level construction going forward. But I think single family is going to see more growth. Interesting statistic that they present at the meeting that the percentage of millennials they want to own a home hasn't changed, it's 92%. 8% of that are happy renting for the rest of their lives, 92% of that want to own a home. That's pretty compelling and that's very consistent with other surveys that have been done. What's stopping them today is the job -- who have had the job growth, but we haven't had the wage growth and then the financing for first-time homebuyers would become much more difficult.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. That's helpful. One more question. We're used to seeing more of a lag in OSB prices as they move up than as they move down. So how much of the improvement that you saw in realizations, would you say was coming from the Q3 pick up versus the Q4.
componenttext: All right. That's helpful. One more question. We're used to seeing more of a lag in OSB prices as they move up than as they move down. So how much of the improvement that you saw in realizations, would you say was coming from the Q3 pick up versus the Q4. And if we saw it would be more or less hang out, would you expect to see a meaningful increase from here in Q1?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: The way I would answer that is that, FEA Economic Advisors who we use to look at pricing, they have 2016 pricing about 16% higher than 2015. And what we saw in January is we saw a slight pricing downturn in OSB, a kind of continued in the first 2 weeks of
componenttext: The way I would answer that is that, FEA Economic Advisors who we use to look at pricing, they have 2016 pricing about 16% higher than 2015. And what we saw in January is we saw a slight pricing downturn in OSB, a kind of continued in the first 2 weeks of February and it's stabilized last week or so. So I mean, I can't really give you much more forecast than that because I had missed the OSB forecast 9 or last 10 years so

componenttext:
Well, I don't know aware of any plastic siding, obviously, there is vinyl siding, which has benefited from lower resin costs with oil-based materials coming down. I am not aware of any new competitors from plastic. I mean Louisiana product, many years ago, that they try to bring to the market, but I am not aware of any so. Maybe you could send some information on, I will follow up. 
All right That sounds like the impact at this point been And then the last thing I was just wondering if you could discuss this review inventories on any sort of week quantifier validate in your comments on inventory has been low would be helpful.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, again, we had our sales being the first week of January and really conversations with our field salesforce and the guys that are the team that manages the big builder and the big distributor. They all had comments that inventories were bein
componenttext: Well, I think, again, we had our sales being the first week of January and really conversations with our field salesforce and the guys that are the team that manages the big builder and the big distributor. They all had comments that inventories were being held relatively lean. And I think that probably it was a reaction to last year. So if you remember, last year, people build up their inventories. We shifted a lot of product in the first quarter and then we had the terrible weather and it didn't flush through the system until May or June. I think you are relatively cautious as a result of that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

componenttext: Before we go on to the next question, I do want to mention back on the OSB that we are seeing improved performance from our Sally and Park County and that did drive along with the improvement in the raw materials in the Canadian relationship, that did also drive the improved performance in the OSB segment.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curt, can you talk a little bit about how Swan is running right now kind of operating rate to the sort of start up problems or anything like that?
componenttext: Curt, can you talk a little bit about how Swan is running right now kind of operating rate to the sort of start up problems or anything like that?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we assume is that we would -- in November, December that we would basically be working out the and rolling out really A grade probably in the 20% range, but then downgrade we would sell a lot of down in the fourth quarter. That's pretty much the way
componenttext: What we assume is that we would -- in November, December that we would basically be working out the and rolling out really A grade probably in the 20% range, but then downgrade we would sell a lot of down in the fourth quarter. That's pretty much the way it played out. In the first quarter, we had planned for 50% capacity. And I think we ran a little over 60% in January. In the second quarter, we assume 75% of capacity and then by summer we would be running that at capacity.

componenttext: Well, overall, capacity as we have the downgrade from OSB because we can't run as fast as 350 million square foot mill. So I would say you are run in full, but the second half that would be 175 and then so you probably much in a quarter than the numbers.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: CanExel it's a single plant and it's a finished product. So we say it's already painted. The declining CanExel really we had an issue in Europe with 2 of our colors that we had -- we actually have a legal dispute with the paint vendor on that, but that as
componenttext: CanExel it's a single plant and it's a finished product. So we say it's already painted. The declining CanExel really we had an issue in Europe with 2 of our colors that we had -- we actually have a legal dispute with the paint vendor on that, but that aside we stopped selling those products in Europe about a year ago. And we have introduced new colors into Europe, but it has taken a while for those to take hold. So the primary reduction has it been in Canada. It's been in the European business that we were satisfying on that facility.

componenttext: Right, I don't have the industrial numbers in front of me, but what we did -- what we do track is how much of our OSB is value-added. In the last year, in 2014, that was about 40% and we increase that by about 4%, 44% in 2015. So we did that there. That was largely it was flame lock. It was radian barrier or flooring products.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the FlameBlock, it is not tied to random links. We do a quarterly pricing. So obviously I would take random links into consideration, but it's a quarterly pricing not subject to weekly adjustments. On text yield in our flooring products, those are larg
componenttext: On the FlameBlock, it is not tied to random links. We do a quarterly pricing. So obviously I would take random links into consideration, but it's a quarterly pricing not subject to weekly adjustments. On text yield in our flooring products, those are largely so they still tied a to random links and what we try to do is move some of the higher end foreign products away from them but we haven't done that yet. On the industrial products, they are priced generally on a quarterly basis.

componenttext: Well, FlameBlock is just in its now we probably had a 40% increase last year, but on a very small base. We expect with the new plant we are putting in place, we are adding about 30 million square feet of capacity and about 20 million at our partners right now. So when that's fully running, that will be about 50 million square feet.

componenttext: Okay, great. And on the siding business, obviously, we are going to benefits have of not having Swan Valley. So that's kind of $11 million positive kicker. Presumably, we are going to have better volume. And it sounded like though that on the pricing side, you could see that third quarter to fourth quarter first of all is down a little bit. And for that January comment, you said about things being strong, can you give us sense to what was happening on pricing in January and some realistic expectations may be for 2016?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: In 2015, we put a price increase in place it took effect in January 1. We have not put a price increase in place for this year yet. And I am not sure we will as we are trying to recover that. I will get back to the growth rates that we have enjoyed in the
componenttext: In 2015, we put a price increase in place it took effect in January 1. We have not put a price increase in place for this year yet. And I am not sure we will as we are trying to recover that. I will get back to the growth rates that we have enjoyed in the past. So I think that you probably wont see any major changes in the price because the mix will get better, but I don't think we are putting price increases in. What you will see is that we will probably go back to some of the customers as I mentioned that were hydrated out and get back into their good graces that starts off. One of the reasons we can do that is Swan Valley will be the lowest cost plant in our system. So we does give us a little bit of flexibility to maintain margins, while giving a little on the price.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Presumably, you are going to certainly want to -- are you generating incremental profit on that volume, so is it fair to say that you would be disappointed as you don't see at least $10 million of improvement in siding 2016 versus 2015 just on Swan
componenttext: Right. Presumably, you are going to certainly want to -- are you generating incremental profit on that volume, so is it fair to say that you would be disappointed as you don't see at least $10 million of improvement in siding 2016 versus 2015 just on Swan Valley reversal?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, lastly, so with exchange rates where they are, there's a lot of talk out there that the Canadian mills are very, very profitable, much more so than the U.S. mills. When you look in your system, how are things shaking out kind of versus the U.S.
componenttext: And then, lastly, so with exchange rates where they are, there's a lot of talk out there that the Canadian mills are very, very profitable, much more so than the U.S. mills. When you look in your system, how are things shaking out kind of versus the U.S. right now in OSB?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in OSB, the problem is that all of our customers know that the Canadian exchange rate is down. And so if you look at the primary benchmarks for product from Canada coming in the U.S., which will be the Western Canadian print and the Eastern Canadian
componenttext: Yes, in OSB, the problem is that all of our customers know that the Canadian exchange rate is down. And so if you look at the primary benchmarks for product from Canada coming in the U.S., which will be the Western Canadian print and the Eastern Canadian print, they are by far in a way the lowest performers across the region. So unfortunately, we have been able to capture all of that because we have given some of that pricing or giving it back in pricing in the Random Lengths reported numbers. I think currently between North Central and Western Canada, we have a $40 differential. We have more than that. So that's the problem.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So actually the Canadian mills are not more profitable per say than the U.S. Mills at this point given those price differences, is that fair?
componenttext: Got it. So actually the Canadian mills are not more profitable per say than the U.S. Mills at this point given those price differences, is that fair?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they are selling into those regional pricing environments, they would not be more profitable how big. And if they are closer to like the North Central market, then they could be.
componenttext: Well, they are selling into those regional pricing environments, they would not be more profitable how big. And if they are closer to like the North Central market, then they could be.

componenttext: Well, I can only talk about LP, Steve. You saw the amount of downtime that we took. We did pull inventories down throughout the year. componenttext: No. That's not the dynamic. The dynamic is that we want to run Swan full on siding, but we don't have demand yet it for 100% of the siding capacity we have. So we will use that swing capability Haywood to run OSB in the North Central region.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. And welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for tod
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. And welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead,

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Ashley, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the fourth quarter of 2015 and the full year 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer; and with me today are Curt
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Ashley, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the fourth quarter of 2015 and the full year 2015. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer; and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact. 
I will begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the fourth quarter and the full year results for 2015. This will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items. After I finish my remarks, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating, provide his perspective on our operating results and give some thoughts on the outlook. 
As we have done in the past, we have opened up this call to the public and are doing a webcast. And that webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. 
Additionally, to help with the discussion, we have provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides this morning in my comments. 
We filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information, and we plan to file our 10-K in the next few weeks. 
I want to remind all of the participants about the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. And please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation has some of the necessary reconciliations, which have been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporate them with this reference. 
A 16% improvement in OSB pricing for the fourth quarter as compared to the third quarter 2015 and positive adjusted EBITDA for all 4 segments contributed to stronger earnings for the fourth quarter of 2015. On a non-GAAP annual basis, LP recorded 2% lower sales but 52% higher adjusted EBITDA. We exited 2015 with lean OSB finished goods inventory, low raw material costs and a favorable U.S. dollar versus Canadian dollar exchange rate. We are well positioned in 2016 to take advantage of the ongoing U.S. housing -- the ongoing recovery in U.S. housing. 
Here are some details behind our earnings reports. Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the fourth quarter and full year 2015 consolidated results. We are reporting net sales of $463 million for the fourth quarter of 2015, a 2% increase from the net sales of $454 million reported in the fourth quarter of 2014. 
In the fourth quarter, we recorded a net loss of $8 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.05 compared to a net loss of $43 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.30 in the fourth quarter of 2014. The adjusted income from continuing operations for the quarter was $1 million or $0.01 per diluted share based upon a normalized tax rate of 35% as compared to a loss of $32 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.23 recorded in the fourth quarter of 2014. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $34 million in the quarter compared to negative adjusted EBITDA of $17 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. 
For the year ended December 31, 2015, we recorded a net loss of $88 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.62 compared to a loss of $75 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.53 for 2014. The adjusted loss for the year was $46 million or a loss of $0.32 per diluted share based upon the normalized tax rate of 35% compared to a loss of $60 million or $0.42 loss per diluted share in 2014. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $67 million for 2015 compared to $44 million in 2014. 
Now moving on to Slide 5 and the review of our segment results, starting with OSB. OSB recorded net sales for the fourth quarter of 2015 of $206 million, slightly higher than the $203 million of net sales recorded in the fourth quarter of 2014. OSB reported operating income of $11 million compared to a loss of $29 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. This is the first quarter of operating income in our OSB segment since the fourth quarter of 2013. And adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations for the quarter was a positive $25 million compared to negative $15 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. 
Pricing at OSB was higher by 10%, which resulted in improved operating results by $18 million. And in addition to the improved OSB price, results benefited from reductions in raw material costs as well as the positive impact of the Canadian currency incurred by our Canadian operation as compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. For the fourth quarter of 2015, the average of the U.S.-Canadian exchange rate was $0.75 as compared to $0.88 in the fourth quarter of 2014. 
For the full year, OSB reported operating sales of $808 million compared to $855 million, down 6% from the prior year. And we recorded an operating loss of $46 million compared to $53 million in 2014. Adjusted EBITDA for 2015 was $12 million compared to $4 million in 2014. Sales volumes increased 2%, and prices decreased 7%. The decrease in selling price unfavorably impacted operating results by $61 million. Offsetting the reduction in sales price for the year was a reduction of raw material costs related to petroleum-based raw materials as well as the positive impact of the Canadian currency exchange rate on the costs incurred by our Canadian operation as compared to the prior year. For the full year of 2015, the average U.S. dollar-Canadian exchange rate was $0.78 as compared to $0.91 in 2014. 
On Slide 6, we reported the results of the Siding business. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel siding product as well as a minor amount of OSB. Our Siding segment had record sales -- had a record year for sales, operating income and adjusted EBITDA. 
For the fourth quarter of 2015, the Siding segment recorded sales of $141 million, operating income of $14 million and adjusted EBITDA of $19 million, all comparable to the fourth quarter of 2014. 
For the quarter, SmartSide average sales were up 2%, and volumes decreased 5%. Volumes decreased in our SmartSide siding line due to customers continuing to rebalance their inventories based upon expected housing starts and labor availability, which has slowed housing completion. 
During the third quarter of 2015, we began the conversion of our Swan Valley OSB mill to a SmartSide mill, and during the majority of the fourth quarter, this mill was not operational. It is estimated that the additional costs incurred at the Swan Valley facility during the fourth quarter related to that conversion as well as market-related downtime was approximately $6 million. 
For the year, the Siding segment reported sales of $636 million, an increase of 3% from $617 million reported in 2014. Siding segment reported operating income of $93 million compared to $80 million and adjusted EBITDA of $114 million as compared to $98 million in 2014. The estimated impact of the additional costs incurred at the Swan Valley facility for the full year is approximately $11 million. 
Now please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results of our Engineered Wood Products segment. This segment includes I-Joist laminates; Strand Lumber laminates; veneer lumber; OSB produced at our Houlton, Maine facility; plus other related products. This segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. 
The Engineered Wood Products segment reported sales of $75 million in the fourth quarter of 2015, up from $66 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. Segment's results were break-even in the fourth quarter of '15 as compared to a loss of $6 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. For the fourth quarter of 2015, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations improved to $3 million as compared to negative $4 million in the fourth quarter of 2014, the best quarter in EWP since the third quarter of 2014. 
Volumes of I-Joist were up 21% while volumes of LVL and LSL were up 29% compared to the same quarter last year. Pricing was lower by 1% in LVL and LSL and higher by 5% -- I'm sorry, higher by 4% in I-Joist. 
During the quarter and the full year of 2015, we changed the mix of OSB products at our Houlton operations, manufacturing more value-added OSB and less commodity products. The impact of this change resulted in improving operating results of $800,000 in the quarter and $3.5 million for the full year. 
For the year, sales were $286 million, up from $281 million in 2014. The segment's operating loss in 2015 was $7 million as compared to $14 million in the same period of 2014. Adjusted EBITDA improved to $6 million for 2015 from breakeven in 2014. 
Moving on to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded sales of $34 million as compared to $36 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. Operating income is $3 million, and adjusted EBITDA was $5 million for the fourth quarter of 2015, essentially flat with the fourth quarter of 2014. 
Volumes in Chile were up 9% and up 15% in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. The sales volume increase in Chile was due to improved housing demand, and the increase in Brazil was due to increased exports. Brazil continues to be in an economic recession with continued political upheaval. 
Pricing was down 12% in Chile and down 23% in Brazil. In local currency, Chile's pricing was up 3% with the same quarter in 2014, and Brazil's pricing was up 13% primarily due to the impact of higher exports. 
For the year, our South American segment recorded sales of $135 million as compared to $150 million in 2014. Operating income was $10 million for 2015 compared to $11 million in 2014, and adjusted EBITDA declined to $18 million from $20 million in the same period of 2014. 
Total selling, general and administrative expenses were $38 million in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to $41 million in the same quarter of 2014. For the quarter, the decrease in selling, general and administrative expenses is primarily due to the lower compensation expense. For the year, our selling, general and administrative expenses are higher at $153 million as compared to $150 million for 2014 primarily due to higher sales and marketing expenses. 
Please refer to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of December 31, 2015, we had cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $455 million; working capital of $626 million; net cash of $88 million. And in addition to the $455 million of cash on our balance sheet, we had $200 million of availability on our credit facility. 
Capital expenditures for 2015 were $114 million. We are planning on spending between $120 million and $135 million in capital expenditures for 2016. Approximately $100 million has been allocated to North American projects, 50% for growth and the remaining for capital maintenance and cost reduction projects. The remaining $35 million has been allocated to our South American segment, primarily for the building of the third mill in Chile. And we anticipate that the South American capital expenditures will be funded by cash on hand in Chile as well as the local bank financing. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Curt for his comments.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for that review, Sallie. Good morning to all of you, and thanks for joining us on the call. Let me start with LP's safety performance. For the full year, our total incident rate for recordable injuries or TIR was 0.47, which is the 10th year in a
componenttext:
Thanks for that review, Sallie. Good morning to all of you, and thanks for joining us on the call. 
Let me start with LP's safety performance. For the full year, our total incident rate for recordable injuries or TIR was 0.47, which is the 10th year in a row that LP was below 1.0. Now that impressive statistic that demonstrates LP's commitment to safety is therefore the second year in a row that contractors that we use on our capital projects went injury-free, a remarkable accomplishment. 
As I typically do on these calls, I'll provide a few comments on our results and accomplishments in the fourth quarter and the year, discuss the housing market and give you my views for 2016. After that, I will turn it back over to Sallie to take your questions. 
As Sallie just reported, all of our segments recorded positive EBITDA in the fourth quarter. For the full year, our EBITDA improved by over 50% despite a $62 million negative impact to both sales and EBITDA due to lower OSB prices than the prior year. As Sallie also mentioned, we did benefit from lower raw materials costs and the favorable Canadian exchange rate. 
In our OSB business, we reacted to lower sales prices by holding our sales volumes relatively flat, with lower production due to the conversion of Swan Valley siding in the second half of the year. We were able to ship the same amount by bringing down the inventory of finished goods across the system. This means that we entered the first quarter with very lean inventories, which should be beneficial as the building season resumes in a month or so. 
We had the most profitable year ever in our Siding business with a 16% increase in EBITDA despite absorbing about a $10 million cost in the second half of the year associated with the Swan Valley conversion. With Swan operating, we have unleashed our sales force to return us to the growth rates that we've demonstrated in the past. 
Engineered Wood, with over $3 million in EBITDA recorded the best quarterly results in many years. For the year, EWP had adjusted EBITDA of almost $6 million compared to breakeven last year. In South America, we had another strong year although reported results reflected significant weakening of the Chilean peso about 15% and the Brazilian real over 15% against the U.S. dollar. 
Following approval by the various governmental agencies of our environmental permit for a third mill in Chile last October, we did get through the mandatory waiting period. This is good news as we're in a sold-out position in Chile, and we are seeing improving economies in Argentina and Colombia. I am anticipating that our board will approve this project next summer and that construction will begin shortly thereafter. 
The news about the housing market continues to be good. However, it has not been as strong as forecasted. U.S. Census Bureau released their data on housing on January 20. For December, housing starts came in at 1.149 million while permits were higher 1.232 million. Other positive housing-related news includes, while the rate of the household formations fell a bit in the fourth quarter, we did end last year with an average of 1.7 million household formations, which is significantly higher, more than double than the last few years. This could mean that the millennials are finally on the move. 
Medium home prices for the year were up 7.6%, and December marked the 46th consecutive month of year-over-year gains. First-time homebuyers purchased about 30% of the existing homes in 2015, and this was up slightly from last year. The total inventory of housing for sale is 3% lower than a year ago, which is creating some shortages. 
On the financing side, average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rates were at 3.92%, and this is for the week ending January 15. As we look at the consensus forecast for this year, it currently stands at 1.263 million, which is about a 14% increase over last year. The consensus for 2017 is 1.385 million, which is a further 10% increase. For LP, we are using a budget assumption of 1.2 million to 1.25 million for 2016. 
Nonresidential construction, an area that we do participate in, was up 9.3% through the end of November. The 5 most important subsectors for structural panel demand are commercial, offices, religious, health care and schools. We registered an increase of 22% for office buildings and 5% for health care and religious buildings. 
Finally, sales of building materials and supply dealers were up about 4% in 2015 compared to the prior year. 
So our view for 2016 -- I just returned from the Policy Advisory Board meeting of the Harvard Joint Center for Housing Studies held in Washington, D.C. earlier this week. While almost all of the participants shared their view that 2016 will continue to show the 10% to 12% growth in new housing and a continuation of demand in repair and remodeling, to a person, these CEOs expressed dismay surrounding the current political situation, frustration with financial markets and increasing concern about the more restrictive regulatory environment. So with that being said, I do share that as we look back at 2016 post-election, I do believe that housing will be one of the few bright spots in the economy. 
For LP, January order rates were strong, presiding in EWP and a bit muted for OSB, as reflected by a slightly declining price during the month. In the first part of January, we did have our annual sales meeting and also attended the International Builders' Show in Las Vegas. At these 2 events, we had a chance to talk to our field sales folks, builders and channel partners. I'd summarize that the overwhelming sentiment was cautious optimism. Almost universally, there was a feeling that housing and repair-and-remodel markets in 2016 will be stronger than 2015, but there are some headwinds. 
Based on the forecast, it does appear that multifamily housing will be a little over 35% of the mix in the U.S. for the next few years. Additionally, with the aging baby boomers and the explosion of the sharing economy like Airbnb, we are increasingly seeing builders of single-family units add square footage to accommodate an elderly relative or short-term renter in a separate space. This probably showed up in that the average size of single-family new construction in 2015 was the highest ever. 
In Canada, we did see a decline in housing starts in the fourth quarter, primarily focused at lower multifamily starts in Ontario and a cutback in the Prairie provinces associated with oil sands. In 2015, starts were almost 200,000 units, and we forecast this to be lower by about 5%. 
In South America, the outlook continues to be mixed. Brazil is clearly struggling with an untenable political situation and continued economic downturn. The bright spot for LP's operation in Brazil is that the dramatically lower Brazilian real has created some export opportunities for us. 
In Chile, lower copper prices have hurt the economy, but the government continues to take an active role in funding replacement housing that was destroyed by natural disasters, which benefits LP. 
Changing government in Argentina and the immediate relaxing of import/export controls should lead to higher volumes into this country. And the continued emergence of the Colombian economy also creates export demand for our products in South America. 
For retail demand, both Home Depot and Lowe's have given forecast of same-store sales being in that 4% to 5% range for 2016. 
On the longer term, there has been nothing that has happened recently to change my outlook as I continue to believe that we have several more years of housing growth in front of us based on the underbuilding during the last decade, population demographics and the slow rate of recovery so far. As I said in the past, the constraining factors to more immediate robust housing: labor at all levels, available lots and access to credit for the first-time homebuyer. 
Again, as I said before, I believe the labor issues faced by the builders will ease either through increased employment or changing construction practices that will reduce the need for labor. The lack or shortage continues to be a result of multiple factors, including regulation, shortage of manpower and planning requirements and funding for infrastructure. 
On the financing side, we know there will be no significant changes to Fannie and Freddie until after the 2016 elections. The Fed interest rate hike in December had very little impact on mortgage rates. And based on Fed chairman's results -- or comments yesterday, it looks like they will be very cautious as they consider additional rate hikes. 
The other interesting trend that is happening is the traditional depository banks, with the exception of Wells Fargo, have essentially withdrawn from the FHA mortgage market due to increased reserves, documentation requirements and continued litigation risk from federal and state regulators. The good news is new entrants like Quicken Loans with their Super Bowl commercial are taking up the slack. 
As we look at the forecast demand for our products, the challenges faced by builders and the emerging trends, there is much that LP can and is doing to take advantage of these opportunities. Let me give you some concrete examples. 
In single-family new construction, we have had very good success in growing the TechShield Radiant Barrier Sheathing brand to address energy requirements in a number of jurisdictions. We expect to continue this push. 
In the Urban Interface zones in places like California and Colorado, the requirement for fire retardancy has given lift to our FlameBlock product. This is also true in Pennsylvania and Ohio where codes have changed related to fire burn-through on the floors above unfinished basements. Our newly released FlameBlock I-Joist addresses this need. 
In multifamily, these projects also require increased fire retardancy, acoustical performance and low-maintenance durable siding. In January, I was joined by Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama and other dignitaries at the groundbreaking of a $15 million project to add FlameBlock capability to our existing Clarke County, Alabama mill. This post-processing facility will augment the capacity that we have available through our relationship with International Barrier Technologies. Not only does this meet the technical needs defined by the various billing codes, it also lowers the labor content, adds structural integrity and gives the architect more design flexibility. 
With our SmartSide siding products that include lap, panel, trim, soffit and fascia, a builder of multifamily projects will have both the best-looking product available but also the durability to survive harsh treatment for renters. 
In light commercial, our EWP products have long played a role in this segment as the ease of use and design flexibility are critical to the architect and builder. At the recent International Builders' Show, we introduced a substrate panel that can be used to replicate a stucco look with less cost and less labor. This is important in both light commercial as well as other areas like the Southwest where stucco was a preferred finish. 
South America, we see very good opportunities to expand and grow our business there. As we've mentioned earlier, we have cleared all the necessary hurdles for our environmental permitting for a third mill in Chile. That will serve the domestic market as well as other countries on the continent. Our plan is to redeploy existing equipment as we have done in the past to limit the capital investment to $55 million to $60 million. The timing of this construction is likely to be later this year. 
On the industrial side, we continue to develop products for markets beyond residential construction. In this category, we include panels used in furniture manufacturing, various transportation applications and substrates used for decorative panels, cabinetry and interior panels. 
So in conclusion, the continued rise in housing activity, more normalized repair and remodeling activity and new uses for our current products is good for our stakeholders as LP is well positioned to capitalize on this growth. Further, we are committed to innovation to meet our customers' needs for products, efficiencies and affordable costs. 
With that, let me turn it over to Sallie for the Q&A.

componenttext: Sallie, Curt, first question on siding. Can you provide additional color on the big drop in volumes both in production and sales?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said in the earlier quarters, we were in a sold-out position on allocation. So we really didn't have any more product to sell until the Swan Valley facility came online in the October -- late October, early November time frame, and we've been
componenttext: Well, as we said in the earlier quarters, we were in a sold-out position on allocation. So we really didn't have any more product to sell until the Swan Valley facility came online in the October -- late October, early November time frame, and we've been ramping up that production. So what we have been doing -- and comment I made is unleashing the sales force, that is, in fact, exactly what we did at the international -- or at our international sales meeting in early January. We have armed our sales force with the tools necessary to get us back on the growth rate from a volume standpoint. I would hasten to add, though, if you look at our record results from an EBITDA standpoint, looking on allocation, you do have the opportunity to high-grade your customer mix, if you will. And that's exactly what our sales force did as they were able to take the product that we had available and get a higher price for that. That's why you saw the record EBITDA. So on 2016, the challenge is to go back to probably some of those customers who we high-graded out of it, offer them the opportunity to participate in buying these products going forward and manage the gross margin along with the growth rates.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd add a couple more comments on that to what Curt said. If you look at the year-over-year results, the volume is down about 2%, which is pretty much what we had said, that we thought the volumes would be pretty much the same. And so I think it's coming
componenttext: I'd add a couple more comments on that to what Curt said. If you look at the year-over-year results, the volume is down about 2%, which is pretty much what we had said, that we thought the volumes would be pretty much the same. And so I think it's coming as anticipated or as we've anticipated for the past 6 or 7 months. And then things are looking so far pretty good for the first quarter.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then still sticking with siding, are you seeing any increased competitive behavior, especially as your mill ramps up, in siding?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

componenttext: Well, we have a competitor that has been very aggressive. They don't like the fact that we're more durable than they are, so they're competing against -- with us on price. And that's principally close to where they have their facilities. The Texas market has been a market they have been very aggressive in, and some of the central part of the country, they have been pretty aggressive.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And then third question. Just on share repurchases, how are you thinking about it right now given where the share prices and you have your -- the OSB market over the next 12 to 18 months?

componenttext: Well, I think the best way to answer that is with the statement we made about the $120 million, $135 million that we have in capital that's being reinvested in growth primarily in our Siding business as well as capital maintenance and cost reduction. So that's really where the focus is right now in terms of capital allocation.

componenttext: Between $120 million and $135 million. And Chip, sorry, if I could just give a little more color because I think it's important. And we would expect the Chilean capital expenditures to be funded within Chile through cash on hand or local bank financing.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And there seemed to be some -- like there is still a chance you might push that out, just some of the commentary, if I heard that right? And sort of when is the go/no-go decision point for that project?
componenttext: Got you. And there seemed to be some -- like there is still a chance you might push that out, just some of the commentary, if I heard that right? And sort of when is the go/no-go decision point for that project?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Where we are now, now that we've gone through the environmental permitting, getting the approvals and the -- and necessary waiting period and, frankly, some legal issues that we had to go through, we're in a position now to complete the engineering o
componenttext: Yes. Where we are now, now that we've gone through the environmental permitting, getting the approvals and the -- and necessary waiting period and, frankly, some legal issues that we had to go through, we're in a position now to complete the engineering on that term and the equipment that we take down there. And as I said in my comments, I anticipate taking that to the -- we'll do some preliminary work prior to the summer board meeting, but I anticipate that -- taking that to our board in the summer. And that's why, Sallie, walked among the $20 million to $35 million because it depends on the timing on when we start that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then let's say you do get the -- you do the maximum this year, what would next year's pipeline look like at this point, knowing that it's early in '16? But I mean, would that number likely come down? Or are there other projects that you're think
componenttext: Okay. And then let's say you do get the -- you do the maximum this year, what would next year's pipeline look like at this point, knowing that it's early in '16? But I mean, would that number likely come down? Or are there other projects that you're thinking about, maybe you don't want to tell us, that would keep the CapEx at that level?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not going to provide any direct guidance on that, but what I will say is when we put Swan Valley in place, there were some siding projects to maximize our system. And we're doing some of those this year, and that will continue into next year. The ot
componenttext: We're not going to provide any direct guidance on that, but what I will say is when we put Swan Valley in place, there were some siding projects to maximize our system. And we're doing some of those this year, and that will continue into next year. The other thing, and as you look longer term, this was -- as Ketan mentioned, we didn't have much growth in siding this year because we mistimed when the new capacity came online. So we have to be cognizant of that and make sure that we have siding capacity in front of the demand. So you will see in the next probably 2 to 3 years that we will have to do something to add additional siding capacity as we believe Swan will only give us about 2.5 years headroom.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see, I see. And then when you look at the Siding segment, I want to make sure I heard this right, you're saying that within the kind of operating EBIT and EBITDA numbers were $6 million of costs for the quarter and $11 million for the year that shouldn'
componenttext: I see, I see. And then when you look at the Siding segment, I want to make sure I heard this right, you're saying that within the kind of operating EBIT and EBITDA numbers were $6 million of costs for the quarter and $11 million for the year that shouldn't repeat in 2016. Did I hear that right?

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Connelly of CLSA.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curt, when you think about housing recovery longer term in the millennials that you mentioned, we clearly seem to be seeing more of strength in multifamily. Are you thinking about the long-term rate of demand differently than you were maybe 3 or 4 years a
componenttext: Curt, when you think about housing recovery longer term in the millennials that you mentioned, we clearly seem to be seeing more of strength in multifamily. Are you thinking about the long-term rate of demand differently than you were maybe 3 or 4 years ago?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I was just at the Harvard meeting, and you can [indiscernible] but Mark Zandi talked through this. And his comment is demographics is destiny. And he just said with the number of millennials coming forward and the need for housing, whether it's sin
componenttext: Again, I was just at the Harvard meeting, and you can [indiscernible] but Mark Zandi talked through this. And his comment is demographics is destiny. And he just said with the number of millennials coming forward and the need for housing, whether it's single-family or multifamily, we're going to have to pick up the pace. And I think that was the common theme among the participants. What I believe is that we are probably fully recovered in the multifamily, and you should see about that same level of construction going forward. But I think single-family is going to see more growth. Interesting statistic that they presented at the meeting is that the percentage of millennials that want to own a home hasn't changed. It's 92%. 8% said they're happy renting for the rest of their lives. 92% said they want to own a home. That's pretty compelling, and that's very consistent with other surveys that have been done. What's stopping them today is the job -- we've had the job growth, but we haven't had the wage growth, and then the financing for first-time homebuyers has become much more difficult.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Okay, that's helpful. One more question. We're used to seeing more of a lag in OSB prices as they move up than as they move down. So how much of the improvement that you saw in realizations would you say was coming from the Q3 pickup versus the
componenttext: All right. Okay, that's helpful. One more question. We're used to seeing more of a lag in OSB prices as they move up than as they move down. So how much of the improvement that you saw in realizations would you say was coming from the Q3 pickup versus the Q4? And if we saw OSB more or less hung out, would you expect to see a meaningful increase from here in Q1?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: The way I would answer that is that FEA, Forest Economic Advisors, who we use to look at pricing, they have 2016 pricing about 16% higher than 2015. And what we saw in January is we saw a slight pricing downturn in OSB. That kind of continued in the first
componenttext: The way I would answer that is that FEA, Forest Economic Advisors, who we use to look at pricing, they have 2016 pricing about 16% higher than 2015. And what we saw in January is we saw a slight pricing downturn in OSB. That kind of continued in the first 2 weeks of February, and it's stabilized last week or so. So I mean, I can't really give you much more of a forecast than that because I have missed the OSB forecast 9 out of the last 10 years. So...

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from George Staphos of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from George Staphos of Bank of America.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

componenttext: This is actually John Babcock on the line for George. Just a couple of quick questions here. First, on the OSB segment, I was wondering if you could discuss the non-price drivers of EBITDA. And we take it you got about an $80 million contribution from price, but I just want to get a sense for what else might have helped you there.

componenttext: Well, the raw materials -- I mean, the 2 key ones are lower raw material costs year-over-year and the exchange rate, bit of the Canadian-U.S. dollar exchange rate.
