headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to hand the meeting over to Sallie B
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to hand the meeting over to Sallie Bailey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you very much, Karen, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the first quarter of 2016. I'm Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief
componenttext:
Great. Thank you very much, Karen, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the first quarter of 2016. I'm Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney and Becky Barkley, our primary Investor Relations contact. 
I will begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the first quarter of 2016, and these will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items. After I finish my comments, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating and provide his perspective on our operating results and give some thoughts on the outlook. 
As we have done in the past, we've opened up this call to the public and/or doing a webcast. And the webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. Additionally, to help with the discussions, we're provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjuction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We have filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information as well as our Form 10-Q. I want to remind all of the participants about the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. 
The appendix attached to the presentation has some of the necessary reconciliation, which have been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements, incorporate them with this reference. 
The first quarter was a good start at 2016 for LP and for the continued improvement for the remainder of the year. U.S. start does remain choppy, but the market appears to be in a trajectory for 10% to 50% improvement over 2015. Overall, in the past couple of quarters, we have had a number of questions and meetings on this call about the market demand for SmartSide The Siding segment's results this quarter demonstrates that we are back on track given the 22% improvement in SmartSide volume from the fourth quarter of 2015. And with that, let me go into the details. 
Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the first quarter 2016 consolidated results. We are reporting net sales of $505 million for the first quarter of 2016, a 7% increase from the net sales of $472 million reported in the first quarter of 2015. In the first quarter, we recorded net income of $10 million or $0.07 per diluted share compared to a loss of $35 million or a loss of $0.24 per diluted share in the first quarter of 2015. 
The adjusted income from continued operations for the quarter were $10 million or $0.07 per diluted share based upon a normalized tax rate of 35% as compared to a loss of $19 million or a loss per share of $0.13 reported in the first quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $52 million in the quarter compared to $6 million in the first quarter of 2016. 
Moving on to Slide 5 of the presentation and our overview of our segment results. Starting with OSB. OSB reported net sales for the first quarter of 2016 of $217 million, up 14% of $190 million in the first quarter of 2015. OSB reported operating income of $15 million compared to a loss of $29 million in the first quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $30 million [ph] compared to negative adjusted EBITDA of $13 million in the first quarter of 2015.  Sales volumes were flat. Pricing for OSB was higher by 14%, which improved its operating results by $27 million. The first quarter 2016 OSB operating results were positively impacted by reductions in material cost, and utilization rates as well as the positive impact of the Canadian currency. 
Slide 6 reports the results of siding business. This segment includes our SmartSide and our CanExel progress as well as amounts of Siding reported net sales for the first quarter of 2016 of $181 million of [indiscernible] in the first quarter of 2015. Siding reported operating income of $27 million when compared to operating income of $33 million in the first quarter of 2016. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $34 million compared to $38 million in the first quarter of 2015. volume was up 1% from prior year and 22% sequentially. Sales prices on SmartSide were down 2% due to changes in product mix with individual pricing remaining relatively flat. CanExel, sales increased 15% primarily due to increased demand in Europe. Sales prices for CanExel were lower by 1% [ph] U.S. dollars. CanExel Canadian dollar sales prices were up 2%. 
As a reminder, the conversion from an OSB mill -- as a reminder, with the conversion of the OSB mill to Siding segment the Siding segment started producing and OSB again inspite our hayward Wisconsin Mill. In the first quarter of 2016, the Siding segment produced about 53 million square feet of OSB as compared to net OSB production in the first quarter of 2015. The negative impact on swank conversion on the Siding segment's financial results for the quarter were less than $1 million and we are not anticipating any negative impact of the swank conversion in the second quarter on earnings. The reduction operating results for the Siding segment is for the first quarter of 2016 compared to the first quarter of 2015 was primarily due to higher cost of sales related to the fourth quarter higher cost of production due to downturn. Higher cost of production in the fourth quarter was capitalized to the inventory, which was then sold in the first quarter. The cost of production in the first quarter was lower than the cost of reduction in the fourth quarter of 2015. An increase in OSB production and an increased sales and marketing costs to support future growth also contributed to the lower operating results in the quarter. These higher costs were partially offset by lower raw material cost. 
Please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results from our Engineered Wood Products segment. This segment includes I-Joist, Laminated Strand Lumber, Laminated Veneer Lumber; OSB produced at our Houlton, Maine facility plus other related products. This segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by to meet joint venture under our sales agreement with Murphy Plywood. The Engineered Wood Products segment reported sales of $72 million of the first quarter of 2016, up from $65 million in the first quarter of 2015. The segment's results were loss of $2.5 million in the first quarter of 2016 as compared to a loss of $4 million in the first quarter of 2015. In the first quarter of 2016, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations improved by $1 million as compared to the first quarter of 2015. Volumes of I-Joist were up 19%, while volumes of LVL and LSL were up 18% compared to the same quarter last year. Pricing was up 3% in LVL and up 2% in LSL. 
Moving on to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment reported sales of $31 million as compared to $36 million in the first quarter of 2015. Operating income was $5 million as compared $2 million in the first quarter of 2015 and adjusted EBITDA was higher by $2 million for the first quarter of 2016 as compared to the first quarter of 2015. Volumes were down 12% in Chile in 3% in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. The sales volume decreased in Chile was due to increased exports impacting local demand and in Brazil due to decreased local sales as Brazil continues to face an economic recession in their local market. 
On a U.S. dollar basis, pricing was up 1% in Chile and down 11% in Brazil. In local currency, Chile's pricing was up 14% compared to the same quarter in 2015 and Brazil's pricing was 25% higher in local currency. 
Total selling, general and adminstrative expense was $42 million in the first quarter of 2016 compared to $39 million in the same quarter of 2015. For the quarter, the increase in selling, general and demonstrative expense was primarily due to increases in certain management incentives in 2016 and higher costs associated with corporate sales and marketing to support our revenue growth.  Interest expense net was flat between the period. 
Please turn to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of March 31, 2016, we had cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $424 million; working capital of $650 million; net cash of $68 million. And in addition to the $424 million of cash on our balance sheet, we had $2 million of availability on our credit facility. Capital expenditures through March 31, 2016 were $26 million. We're projecting capital expenditures for 2016 at $120 million to $130 million, approximately $100 million has been allocated to North American project, 50% for growth and the remaining for capital maintenance and cost reduction. The remaining $20 million to $30 million has been allocated to our South American segment, primarily for the building of the third mill in Chile. Now with that, I'll turn the call over to Curt for his comments

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sally and good morning and thanks for participating on today's call. As I usually do, I'll start with our safety performance. The American Panel Association just announced the results of their safety and health awards program for 2015 and I'm p
componenttext:
Thank you, Sally and good morning and thanks for participating on today's call. As I usually do, I'll start with our safety performance. The American Panel Association just announced the results of their safety and health awards program for 2015 and I'm pleased that for the second year in a row, LP was recognized the safest large company as a company with more than 4 mills. This is the sixth time that we've been so recognized in the last 8 years. Our I-Joist JV which has 2 mills and Quebec was named the safest small company with fewer mills. 11 facilities included incident-free honor society. The American Force and Paper Association also released their safety data for 2015 for their of companies and LP was identified is having the best total incident rate. I continue to be extremely proud of all of our employees who recognize the value of being safe, committed to it and act accordingly. 
In addition to the obvious savings and workers' compensation cost, LP employees had made their commitments safety to cornerstone of our company's culture, which we believe gives us a competitive edge in the hiring and retention of our people. Finally, the safety culture extends too many contractors that we use in implementing our capital projects. We have gone over 2 years without a single contractor injury associated with these nonroutine tasks. We did have our board meeting and our Annual Meeting of Shareholders last Friday. I'm pleased to report that all the nominees for directors were handily elected. The auditors were ratified and our annual say on pay advisory board passed with over 98% approval rate. 
Also, our board did name a new officer, Greg Harrison, a long-time LP Manager has been named Vice President of Siding Manufacturing as a recognition of his importance for the success of this business. Greg was instrumental in the successful conversion and the start up of Swan Valley mill. 
Today, I'm be providing comments on our results and accomplishments, discuss key demand drivers and give you my views on the outlook for the rest of this year. For the second consecutive quarter, all business segments reported a positive adjusted EBITDA total of $52 million for the company. EBITDA improved by $46 million over Q1 of 2015 and by $18 million compared to last quarter. Steve of reported North Central 716's Q1 pricing down $17 versus the last quarter, but we're actually reporting flat due to an increase in our value-added mix and improved freight utilization. As a result of these significant factors, improved operational opportunity and cost control, our EBITDA improved to $30 million versus $25 million in Q4. 
During the quarter, we also successfully completed the press rebuild of our Hansville, Alabama mill. In Siding, our SmartSide revenue grew 28% versus Q4 driven by a 22% volume increase. The SmartSide volume has the highest volume ever that we've achieved in Q1 of last year. The Swan Valley siding mill conversion is ahead of the pro forma production schedule and we expect this mill to make a positive contribution next quarter. We are very pleased with the rebound on our siding sales as you put a major focus on returning to growth as we put capacity back in front of this business. 
As I said in the last quarter, we have unleashed our sales and marketing team along with our distortion partners and we are seeing the results. LP EBITDA positive for the quarter and performed better than Q1 of last year. However, we did see a drop in EBITDA performance compared to Q4 last year due to an equipment failure in our one of mills that produced quarter-over-quarter sales and the change in the mix. 
Sally said in South America, we had a very good first quarter with adjusted EBITDA at $7 million. Prices improved in Chile and Brazil in local currency versus last quarter. Strong export volumes in China and other South American countries offset weak domestic demand in Brazil. We continue with the engineering design work for our third mill in Chile in anticipation of board approval of this project over the summer. Our housing market, as Sally mentioned the Q1 news was a little bit mixed. Overall, Q1 housing starts ran at an annual rate of $1.13 million, actually flat to Q4 of last year. The consensus for 2016 starts now at 1.23 million, a 10% improvement over 2015, which I believe is possible. Consensus forecast for 2017 is 1.37 million, another 12% increase. The good news for us that in Q1, single-family starts average a seasonally adjusted rate of 792,000. This is the highest quarterly rate since Q4 of 2007, and this represents an increase of 23% over the same quarter last year. We believe the good weather in February, March aided starts. Also notable the improvements in new home demand for entry-level buyers. We estimate that the OSB consumption ratio between single and multi-family is about 3:1. The improvement in single-family starts was offset by a decline in multi-family starts. Compared to Q4 of last year, multi-family starts declined 10% volume from 379,000 to 341,000, which happen to be flat with last year. Household formation growth continues to drive rising rents and low vacancy rates across the country.  Other positive housing data: existing home inventory was down 1.1% year-over-year through January. So home inventory is very tight on a historical basis. 
On the financing side, average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rates were 3.58 for the week ended April 15, which was down for 3.92 3 months earlier. In Canada for the first quarter, starts were at seasonally adjusted rate of $2,000, a growth of 2% from Q4. Almost all of this increase was in single-family detached units, which makes up about 35% of Canadian starts. So while there is forecasted growth in housing for the next several years, it is incumbent on us to focus on continue to increase our growth outside of our traditional market by developing products, product applications and market segments and address needs and industrial repair model where year-over-year growth has exceeded 10% and like commercial activities. The year-over-year non-residential construction was up 11.2% through February. 
So while the consensus for 2016 housing starts has been moved slightly successfully, I am encouraged by the increase in single-family starts and the supporting data for sales of building materials by dealers are up double digits in the first quarter of the year. So I remain optimistic about the rest of 2016. 
As I have said before, I continue to be concerned about labor and land availability for builders uncertainly relative to lending standards for buyers, and the impact for the presidential race on our nation and more specifically potentially consumer confidence. But continued strong employment growth will bolstered household formation. And fundamentally, housing demand should strength throughout this year providing a positive marketing environment for our products. 
In our Siding business, strong order rates continued through April, and OSB random links has reported North Central placing flat or increase in the each week since the end of the quarter. So compared to this time last year, pricing is higher by 37%. Strong single-family starts is driving demand for both of these businesses as well as Engineered Wood. South America expect good OSB and siding demand in Chile throughout the year.
For Brazil, we will continue to focus on export opportunities as these are generally priced in U.S. dollars and we can benefit from the week resilient With that, make sure we're for questions

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: All right. Well, thank you, Curt. Karen, we're ready for questions, if you could go over the queue.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Mark Wilde from Bank of Montréal.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Mark Wilde from Bank of Montréal.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curt, I wondered if you can talk a little bit about your operating rate in OSB in the first quarter. And also if you just talk a little bit about some margins in OSB, because you've had a couple of competitors reported last week, their OSB margins were a
componenttext: Curt, I wondered if you can talk a little bit about your operating rate in OSB in the first quarter. And also if you just talk a little bit about some margins in OSB, because you've had a couple of competitors reported last week, their OSB margins were a bit higher on a reported basis in years. I wondered if you could just talk to that disparity?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our operating rates in the first quarter were 86%, if you don't include the Mill. And as a reminder, what we did have in the quarters, we did take a month of downtime at our Hansville, Alabama Mill to do the press rebuild. As far as the margin, we do
componenttext: Yes. Our operating rates in the first quarter were 86%, if you don't include the Mill. And as a reminder, what we did have in the quarters, we did take a month of downtime at our Hansville, Alabama Mill to do the press rebuild. As far as the margin, we do focus on the margin compared to our public peers and we actually made some progress in the first quarter versus the fourth quarter. Fundamentally in the past, we have taken more of the industry downtimes our operating rates have been a little bit lower. I think our public competitors talk about operating rates about 92%, so we're about 6 points below that. We do believe that if Hansville had to run all quarter in stead of taking the month of downtime, they're probably been another $3 per 1,000 that we would have added to our margin. So we are focused on that. I think that fundamentally it's tied to the operating rates and how much we run these operations. And we are advanced a little bit by our value-added percentage, but our competitors also focus on value-added product.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Will be the operating rate be down in Brazil and Chile, Curt?
componenttext: Will be the operating rate be down in Brazil and Chile, Curt?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chile is running 100% and actually we're adding products from Brazil to Chile as well as North America to satisfied that demand, that's why we're looking at the third mill. In Brazil, we're probably operating at about 60%. We've seen local demand fall by
componenttext: Chile is running 100% and actually we're adding products from Brazil to Chile as well as North America to satisfied that demand, that's why we're looking at the third mill. In Brazil, we're probably operating at about 60%. We've seen local demand fall by about 20% just due to the economy. We haven't been fill that with some of the export business that I talked about earlier.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally, can you just update us on kind of current market conditions. We had quite a in the recent reported prices last week, I think some of that was tied to the story around the board outage?
componenttext: Okay. And then finally, can you just update us on kind of current market conditions. We had quite a in the recent reported prices last week, I think some of that was tied to the story around the board outage?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's exactly right, because when that fire was reported at the end of the day on Wednesday and early Thursday, we did see pricing go up on west side,  principally a little bit on the north-central. And I just think that as we go into the quarter
componenttext: I think that's exactly right, because when that fire was reported at the end of the day on Wednesday and early Thursday, we did see pricing go up on west side,  principally a little bit on the north-central. And I just think that as we go into the quarter, we're closer to -- the demand is closer to the supply and we're seeing it tightening up. I did see that issued a release today that they expect the outage only about 2 weeks.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then last question along those lines. I mean, just with these so early in the season, do you guys have any view on the likelihood of any kind of login restrictions or login difficulties as we kind of move into summer season?
componenttext: Yes. And then last question along those lines. I mean, just with these so early in the season, do you guys have any view on the likelihood of any kind of login restrictions or login difficulties as we kind of move into summer season?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question. And Sally and I talked to our forestry group, and we do have fires in the Peace Valley area, British Columbia. There are 3 fires there that have happened in the last 24 hours. We don't think that's going to affect our operating ar
componenttext: That's a great question. And Sally and I talked to our forestry group, and we do have fires in the Peace Valley area, British Columbia. There are 3 fires there that have happened in the last 24 hours. We don't think that's going to affect our operating areas. Where the fires are important doesn't affect us. It may have some impact on competitors, but it's certainly not a threat to us. The other part that we're worried about is the rain we've had in Texas and Alabama. East  Texas is 20 inches above normal so far this seasonal. Alabama is 15 inches above normal. The good news is we did put in inventory in our log decks in our fourth quarter, take advantage lower pricing and offset maybe some of the risk of this. So we think we're in pretty good shape there. In North Carolina, we've also had heavy rain fall, but we think we're in pretty good shape in North Carolina. But the fire season and the Western Canada is of concern. And so we're going to be very cognizant of that. Fortunately, we'll build a pretty good log deck at Peace Valley in Creek.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually John Babcock in line for George. Just quickly here with regards to EWP, I mean you as well as some of your peers have done pretty well this quarter from a volume perspective there, and I just want to get a sense for ultimately what factors y
componenttext: It's actually John Babcock in line for George. Just quickly here with regards to EWP, I mean you as well as some of your peers have done pretty well this quarter from a volume perspective there, and I just want to get a sense for ultimately what factors you look at when you're trying to engage whether or not the markets tighten enough to have some pricing up there? And then also given where the markets stands right now, if you see that potential for price increases this year?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the thing that we really look at Engineered Wood is single-family. There's little bit of multi-family activity, but this is largely a single-family construction-driven business. And so the housing starts that we had in the first quarter where perm
componenttext: I think the thing that we really look at Engineered Wood is single-family. There's little bit of multi-family activity, but this is largely a single-family construction-driven business. And so the housing starts that we had in the first quarter where permits are, I think bodes well for continued demand. I think the difficulty with the price increase is that we do have a lot of excess capacity in this business and we just have to be cognizant of that. We did have a recent consolidation and that has created some turmoil in the market as producers are pursuing new business or customers are looking for new uses partners. So there is -- I would characterize Q1 is a bit of a turmoil and it's probably going to extended into Q2. That's probably  when you have that kind of turmoil, it's probably not a time for price increase, but I can see the second half of the year at least LP considering price increases, as we will see higher raw materials particularly in the OSB side.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just next on the siding side of things, you talked a little bit about how ultimately you tried to get your sales force out there and other factors to drive volumes there. I was just wondering, where there any market factors that also might
componenttext: Okay. And then just next on the siding side of things, you talked a little bit about how ultimately you tried to get your sales force out there and other factors to drive volumes there. I was just wondering, where there any market factors that also might have helped you? Or was there any sort of volume kind of pull forward that also might have driven things there?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's just the opposite. I think we did have -- because we location last year, I think last year's Q1 was inordinately high. So if you average that with Q2 of last year, that's probably kind of where the blending demand was in 2015. The good ne
componenttext: No. I think it's just the opposite. I think we did have -- because we location last year, I think last year's Q1 was inordinately high. So if you average that with Q2 of last year, that's probably kind of where the blending demand was in 2015. The good news for us is we are seeing order rates that are higher in Q2 than we did in Q1, which means there's not much inventory in the channel. And what we're hearing from our distribution partners is what they're taking is leaving there yards. So I think that's good news for us looking forward.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Bill Hoffmann of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Bill Hoffmann of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curt, can you talk a little bit about your success or how you're doing on some of the growth in the industrial applications et cetera for -- on the OSB side?
componenttext: Curt, can you talk a little bit about your success or how you're doing on some of the growth in the industrial applications et cetera for -- on the OSB side?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very circumspect. I'll talk about that, because I don't public competitors. They know how we're doing in there. We do have -- I think we talked about -- a little bit of growth and innovation in the past. We are spending a lot of resources looking at alter
componenttext: Very circumspect. I'll talk about that, because I don't public competitors. They know how we're doing in there. We do have -- I think we talked about -- a little bit of growth and innovation in the past. We are spending a lot of resources looking at alternative markets to traditional single-family, multi-family housing. And we are having some success. But as I think everybody in the phone realizes, it's hard to get a new product in the market and have a big revenue impact in the first year or 2. But we're certainly setting a foundation for continuing to grow. I'll give you a few examples. We went into the furniture market in 2009, right? We were in the midst of the downturn. It took us a while, but now most of the furniture manufactures that converted to OSB from plywood, that's benefited, not just us, but it's benefited the entire industry. With our fire product, we actually introduced that about 5 years. And now, we are adding a second production facility, so we can satisfy market demand. And hopefully right after that, we'll provide a third manufacturing facility. So we can do that. It's a little slow taking off, but I'm pleased with the progress. If I look at the funnel projects we got, it's very robust. We're limiting where put our resources to those highest priorities, but I feel pretty good about it, and our goal is to have 50% of the overall company at a high value-added margin products in the next couple of years.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, just with regards to South America and Chile, just given some of the issues down there, any thoughts on slowing down your project -- expansion project down there? Or what do you think the market conditions going to look like going forward
componenttext: Great. And then, just with regards to South America and Chile, just given some of the issues down there, any thoughts on slowing down your project -- expansion project down there? Or what do you think the market conditions going to look like going forward here?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that project is going to be somewhere around $60 million, to do another mill down there. Today, the product that we ship from either Brazil or from North America, ends up not providing any margin to the corporation because we give it all to
componenttext: Well, I think that project is going to be somewhere around $60 million, to do another mill down there. Today, the product that we ship from either Brazil or from North America, ends up not providing any margin to the corporation because we give it all to the transportation company. That's about $100  to $110  bill. So if I can put that mill in place and capture that $110 per 1,000, I have a pretty immediate return on that, that's significant. So it's really just having the local production. Plus the other thing is going on is we are seeing Argentina bounce back with the new government. We're seeing Columbia become a stronger economy, and we have -- we've long sales in the Peru. So I think there is great growth opportunities for us both in margin and in product.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Clyde Dillon from Vertical Research.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: Sally, you mentioned that there was probably about $1 million. I think you mentioned in terms of the inventory. I want to make -- maybe I got my terms mixed up, but how much was inventory adjustment in the siding business? You mentioned, you had higher cost capitalized inventories, you went to the first quarter. Did you actually tell us what the impact of that was?

componenttextpreview: No, expect we didn't really quantify it, but it didn't impact -- it was a piece of why we had higher sales and lower EBITDA in the first quarter of '16 relative to the first quarter of 2015.
componenttext: No, expect we didn't really quantify it, but it didn't impact -- it was a piece of why we had higher sales and lower EBITDA in the first quarter of '16 relative to the first quarter of 2015.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess on that, it seems like I remembered from a year ago, you had some very strong shipments in that first quarter of '15 and that you all correctly let us know that maybe some of the -- what normally would have been felt in the second quarter was
componenttext: And I guess on that, it seems like I remembered from a year ago, you had some very strong shipments in that first quarter of '15 and that you all correctly let us know that maybe some of the -- what normally would have been felt in the second quarter was pulled forward. Did you do see that this year? Or should we see a more normal progression from first to second?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We think there should be a much more normal progression from first to second similar to what you would have seen in the years like '13 and '14.
componenttext: Yes. We think there should be a much more normal progression from first to second similar to what you would have seen in the years like '13 and '14.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then, I guess getting back on the OSB situation, it looked like you had a big pop in the benchmark from mid-week to end of the week last week, and not just split here, it's about day-to-day. But it seemed like other regions were only -- th
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then, I guess getting back on the OSB situation, it looked like you had a big pop in the benchmark from mid-week to end of the week last week, and not just split here, it's about day-to-day. But it seemed like other regions were only -- the north-central went up 1,600 or 1,800, but the other regions only went up about 7 or 8. And I guess, in terms of your business, did you really see any change in behavior on the part of your customers in response to the high-level shutdown or not really?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We did see response. I think all of our partners on the West Coast are concerned getting sufficient volumes to satisfy their customer demand in the second quarter going into the third quarter. It's my view Western Canada was a direct reaction to the fire.
componenttext: We did see response. I think all of our partners on the West Coast are concerned getting sufficient volumes to satisfy their customer demand in the second quarter going into the third quarter. It's my view Western Canada was a direct reaction to the fire.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the last question is I would imagine you're selling more of your product down here than you're making here, I would suppose that some of the Canadian production comes down here and that certainly helped your OSB margins, given how weak the
componenttext: Okay. And then the last question is I would imagine you're selling more of your product down here than you're making here, I would suppose that some of the Canadian production comes down here and that certainly helped your OSB margins, given how weak the C dollar had been. But it had strengthened of last and I just didn't know if you could give us some help in terms of how you think your costs going to flow-through in the next couple of quarters in OSB either based on C dollar being stronger or maybe there are other cost issues like that you could help get our arms around?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we said in the past is that penny for Canadian dollars about $2 million annualized, but that still probably a pretty good number. So each penny change would either raise and lower by about $2 million. assumes same amount product come down, so it does
componenttext: What we said in the past is that penny for Canadian dollars about $2 million annualized, but that still probably a pretty good number. So each penny change would either raise and lower by about $2 million. assumes same amount product come down, so it does fluctuate, but that's the good rule of thumb.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we haven't specifically quantified for OSB that improvement in raw material cost, but we have said that we thought this year as you'll recall '15 we thought a lot of improvement due to raw material cost. We thought '16 would look similar to '15 and we
componenttext: And we haven't specifically quantified for OSB that improvement in raw material cost, but we have said that we thought this year as you'll recall '15 we thought a lot of improvement due to raw material cost. We thought '16 would look similar to '15 and we haven't really come off that. For a while, I think we would have thought oil would and resins would help us a little bit that may still be the case. We just have to see what oil -- what happens with oil to go further.

componenttext: One question on pricing for OSB. Obviously, it has continued to move higher. A competitor of your indicated that their average prices in April had been up about $15 versus the first quarter and then they gave some color on where they were now versus April. Could you provide a similar type of framework for us?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's tough. I will do that in July.
componenttext: I think it's tough. I will do that in July.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And obviously, a lot of good news in the quarter, but one area where you do on a relative basis seem to continue to struggle quite a bit is that Engineered Wood business, where some of your competitors are doing a lot better. Any thoughts as to what
componenttext: Okay. And obviously, a lot of good news in the quarter, but one area where you do on a relative basis seem to continue to struggle quite a bit is that Engineered Wood business, where some of your competitors are doing a lot better. Any thoughts as to what the relative issues might be at this point?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we did it -- we do a comparative analysis every quarter of looking at what is publicly available and it's a little tough because some of our competitors include plywood in that and MDF and some include their distribution operation. So you can't real
componenttext: Well, we did it -- we do a comparative analysis every quarter of looking at what is publicly available and it's a little tough because some of our competitors include plywood in that and MDF and some include their distribution operation. So you can't really see what the pricing is. So we look at a relative change between quarters both the last quarter and then the same quarter of the prior year. And from a relative change basis, we were pretty consistent both on a volume standpoint and a pricing standpoint with our competitors and the industry. What hurt us in the first quarter is we did have one of our press lines for LVL did go down on the East Coast and we had about a month outage. And what we did is we replaced that volume to satisfy our customer needs with a production that we get out of Murphy Plywood, where we sell that with basically recovering our sales costs, but not any margin. So our volumes were good, but we had to replace it with manufacturer product outside. The other thing when you look at our margins versus competitor, just to remember is that the or the joint venture in Québec, we only get half of that margin, because we share with our partner. We also only have half of the investment in that. So I believe, our numbers were about $2 million lower than they should have been due to that -- due to the fact of having to satisfy our customers of the Murphy volume.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And lastly, if you could just give us an update on cap spend expectation for this year? And if there are any very very early reads for next year?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And lastly, if you could just give us an update on cap spend expectation for this year? And if there are any very very early reads for next year?

componenttext: Mark, we're continuing to forecast very similar we said in the first quarter, we're now at a $120 million to $130 million, down a little bit fromwhat I said 3 months ago. Still $100 million in the U.S. and $20 million to $30 million is in the Chile, primarily for the -- South America, but primarily for the Chilean mill.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Curt, you said you think you're going to be okay with fiber despite the rains and floods and fires. Are you worried about risk to average prices if you end up with competitors who were scrabbing in those same regions?
componenttext: So Curt, you said you think you're going to be okay with fiber despite the rains and floods and fires. Are you worried about risk to average prices if you end up with competitors who were scrabbing in those same regions?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the risk is that commodity pricing will go up, which is a good risk to have. If you fiber then the end products going to go up. I don't think that we're going to see any, but we could see some short-term pricing. But we have a strategic supp
componenttext: Well, I think the risk is that commodity pricing will go up, which is a good risk to have. If you fiber then the end products going to go up. I don't think that we're going to see any, but we could see some short-term pricing. But we have a strategic supplier program and we got a long term relationships with most of our fiber suppliers, so I don't think that's going to be a significant risk or maybe spot risk, but not significant.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: Well, was a very difficult process. I think if there were a one-off mill, we would consider it. I think anything of scale, I committed to waiting until change in administration or change in view. If you just look at the public comments on the difficulty of GP buy or selling too relatively modest Engineering Wood operation is a tell them I do anything of significant can be a little bit problematic.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sally, can you just walk us through if possible financially how the ramp on the Swan Valley will look as we move through the year? I think you said it was about $1 million drag in the first quarter and it sounded like it was at least breakeven in the seco
componenttext: Sally, can you just walk us through if possible financially how the ramp on the Swan Valley will look as we move through the year? I think you said it was about $1 million drag in the first quarter and it sounded like it was at least breakeven in the second quarter and I'm just curious about how that sequences into 3 and 4?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what you need to do, Mark, is really go back and think about what happened in the third and fourth quarter of 2015. And what we said and I know $10 million for the whole year, I think it was $4 million.  Okay. So Mark, we believe it was $6 m
componenttext: Well, I think what you need to do, Mark, is really go back and think about what happened in the third and fourth quarter of 2015. And what we said and I know $10 million for the whole year, I think it was $4 million.  Okay. So Mark, we believe it was $6 million in the third quarter and $4 million in the fourth quarter -- other way around, $4 in the fourth quarter and $6 million in the -- $4 in the third quarter and $6 million in the fourth quarter quarter, so $10 million for the whole year. And so I think the best way to think about that is we said it was less a $1 million in the first quarter and we don't anticipate any negative drag in the remainder of this year. And so at this point, it just be fully incorporated into our siding business and we don't expect to see any different from any of our other siding mills, albeit the ramp up will be slowly completed by the end of the quarter.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, right. And then Curt, any sense that you can give us of what the underlying growth rate is for your siding business in your view?
componenttext: Okay, right. And then Curt, any sense that you can give us of what the underlying growth rate is for your siding business in your view?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just take the market and look at the mix between repair and model, new home construction, the retail business, the inherent growth rate is 7% to 8%. So penetration, we think the other 5% to 6% on top of that. So I think 13% to 14% overall. And if s
componenttext: Let me just take the market and look at the mix between repair and model, new home construction, the retail business, the inherent growth rate is 7% to 8%. So penetration, we think the other 5% to 6% on top of that. So I think 13% to 14% overall. And if some of these new products really take off in the marketplace, it could be higher than that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And any thoughts on how you think about the potential of having another playing coming to the market?
componenttext: Yes. And any thoughts on how you think about the potential of having another playing coming to the market?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's been rumored for long time. I just think that there would be a big uphill climb. We have a 25-year history of product reliability and warranty information. We've got a sales force in the field. It's now 140 people strong and marketing to s
componenttext: I think there's been rumored for long time. I just think that there would be a big uphill climb. We have a 25-year history of product reliability and warranty information. We've got a sales force in the field. It's now 140 people strong and marketing to support that. It's a different kind of sale commodity OSB. And then, as you know, we spend $85 million from various into a siding mill. So there is a little bit of capital that goes into it. And I think I mentioned on the first quarter call, Swan Valley has one of our most experienced mill teams. It wasn't easy for that. That's even with having that augmented with people from our siding mills to help them with that ramp up. As unlike OSB, if you have a and the face it's downgraded. You can't  So it's a tougher standard. For an external product, it is going to remain to be seen. So it wouldn't surprise me. But we've heard it now for 10 years come in the business.

componenttext: Okay. And the last question I had. So it seems like even away from just fuel prices that conditions in freight markets have eased from where they were a year or 2 ago, are you getting any benefit from what freight cost coming through on the rail or from a trucking standpoint?

componenttext: So Mark, I'll comment on that. We put fuel surcharges in for the rail companies. The trucking companies in the airline industry and not of them have come off. What I will see is probably do more to weather than anything else. We did not have any then rail destructions in the first quarter. And that's -- maybe if you go back to 2013 and '14, it was terrible. So we actually...

componenttext: That's exactly right. As I mentioned, particularly and our OSB business, we were able because of that reliability. We were able to change how we treated reloads and how we treated inventory, is we could rely on that because the product and part of the improvement we had on pricing was better logistics.

componenttextpreview: It's all in the mind of the buyer, John. This is an emotional response. It's a response with incomplete information. As information becomes available then I think buyers will modify their behavior, but this was an emotional response. And we get that -- fo
componenttext: It's all in the mind of the buyer, John. This is an emotional response. It's a response with incomplete information. As information becomes available then I think buyers will modify their behavior, but this was an emotional response. And we get that -- for instance, when Marco announced we're going to build a new mill, pricing when down, but that mill operational for 2.5 years. It really is psychological. And if a buyer can't get the work, they tendency to raise the price.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: For your 2 mills  a Piece River in Creek, do you expect any difficulty getting fiber? Or the forestry is going to put down their logging equipment and go for the somewhere?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Typically, at this time of year, you're not logging. So whatever you're going to run through the mills has to be already sitting in the log yard or a satellite log yard. So with our force it won't be in the woods until the next month at the earliest, is t
componenttext: Typically, at this time of year, you're not logging. So whatever you're going to run through the mills has to be already sitting in the log yard or a satellite log yard. So with our force it won't be in the woods until the next month at the earliest, is that right, Mike? So it won't be in the woods until next month. And then if there is fire -- a fire danger, they may limit what areas they can operate in. But we fundamentally have enough wood in our yards to run through the middle of July in both Creek.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to hand the meeting over to Sallie B
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to hand the meeting over to Sallie Bailey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you very much, Karen, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the first quarter of 2016. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer. And with me today are Curtis Stevens, LP's Ch
componenttext:
Great. Thank you very much, Karen, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LP's financial results for the first quarter of 2016. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer. And with me today are Curtis Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact. 
I will begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the first quarter of 2016, and this will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items. After I finish my comments, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating and provide his perspective on our operating results and give some thoughts on the outlook. 
As we have done in the past, we've opened up this call to the public and are doing a webcast. And the webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. 
Additionally, to help with the discussions, we have provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We have filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information as well as our Form 10-Q. 
I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. 
The appendix attached to the presentation has some of the necessary reconciliations have been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporate them with this reference. 
The first quarter was a good start to 2016 for LP and has set us up for continued improvement for the remainder of the year. U.S. housing start data does remain choppy, but the market appears to be on a trajectory for a 10% to 15% improvement over 2015. Overall, in the past couple of quarters, we have had a number of questions in meetings and on this call about the market demand for our SmartSide siding. The Siding segment's results this quarter demonstrate that we are back on track, given the 22% improvement in SmartSide volume from the fourth quarter of 2015. And with that, let me go into the details. 
Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the first quarter 2016 consolidated results. We are reporting net sales of $505 million for the first quarter of 2016, a 7% increase from the net sales of $472 million reported in the first quarter of 2015. In the first quarter, we recorded net income of $10 million or $0.07 per diluted share compared to a loss of $35 million or a loss of $0.24 per diluted share in the first quarter of 2015. 
The adjusted income from continuing operations for the quarter were $10 million or $0.07 per diluted share based upon a normalized tax rate of 35% as compared to a loss of $19 million or a loss per share of $0.13 reported in the first quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $52 million in the quarter compared to $6 million in the first quarter of 2015. 
Moving on to Slide 5 of the presentation and a review of our segment results. Starting with OSB. OSB reported net sales for the first quarter of 2016 of $217 million, up 14% from $190 million in the first quarter of 2015. OSB reported operating income of $15 million compared to a loss of $29 million in the first quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $30 million compared to negative adjusted EBITDA of $13 million in the first quarter of 2015. Sales volumes were flat. Pricing for OSB was higher by 14%, which improved operating results by $27 million. The first quarter 2016 OSB operating results were positively impacted by reductions in raw material cost, higher utilization rates as well as the positive impact of the Canadian currency. 
Slide 6 reports the results of the Siding business. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel siding products as well as a minor amount of OSB. Siding reported net sales for the first quarter of 2016 of $181 million, up 4% from $174 million in the first quarter of 2015. Siding reported operating income of $27 million compared to operating income of $33 million in the first quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $34 million compared to $38 million in the first quarter of 2015. SmartSide volume was up 1% from the prior year and 22% sequentially. Sales prices on SmartSide were down 2% due to changes in product mix, with individual pricing remaining relatively flat. For CanExel, sales volume increased 15%, primarily due to increased demand in Europe. Sales prices for CanExel were lower by 11% in U.S. dollars. CanExel Canadian dollar sales prices were up 2%. 
As a reminder, the Swan conversion from an OSB mill to the siding -- as a reminder, with the Swan conversion from the OSB mill to a siding mill, the Siding segment started producing and selling OSB again in spite our Hayward, Wisconsin mill. During the first quarter of 2016, the Siding segment produced about 53 million square feet of OSB as compared to net OSB production in the first quarter of 2015. The negative impact of the Swan conversion on the Siding segment's financial results for the quarter was less than $1 million, and we are not anticipating any negative impact of the Swan conversion in the second quarter on earnings. 
The reduction in operating results for the Siding segment is -- for the first quarter of 2016 compared to the first quarter of 2015 was primarily due to higher cost of sales related to the fourth quarter higher cost of production due to downtime. The higher cost of production in the fourth quarter was capitalized into the inventory, which was then sold in the first quarter. The cost of production in the first quarter was lower than the cost of reduction in the fourth quarter of 2015. An increase in OSB production and increased sales in marketing cost to support future growth also contributed to the lower operating results in the quarter. These higher costs were partially offset by lower raw material costs. 
Please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results from our Engineered Wood Products segment. This segment includes I-Joist; Laminated Strand Lumber; Laminated Veneer Lumber; OSB produced at our Houlton, Maine facility; plus other related products. This segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. 
The Engineered Wood Products segment reported sales of $72 million in the first quarter of 2016, up from $65 million in the first quarter of 2015. The segment's results were a loss of $2.5 million in the first quarter of 2016 as compared to a loss of $4 million in the first quarter of 2015. In the first quarter of 2016, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations improved by $1 million as compared to the first quarter of 2015. Volumes of I-Joist were up 19%, while volumes of LVL/LSL were up 18% compared to the same quarter last year. Pricing was up 3% in LVL and up 2% in I-Joist. 
Moving on to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded sales of $31 million as compared to $36 million in the first quarter of 2015. Operating income was $5 million as compared to $2 million in the first quarter of 2015, and adjusted EBITDA was higher by $2 million for the first quarter of 2016 as compared to the first quarter of 2015. Volumes were down 12% in Chile in 3% in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. The sales volume decrease in Chile was due to increased exports impacting local demand and in Brazil due to decreased local sales as Brazil continues to face an economic recession in their local market. 
On a U.S. dollar basis, pricing was up 1% in Chile and down 11% in Brazil. In local currency, Chile's pricing was up 14% compared to the same quarter in 2015, and Brazil's pricing was 25% higher in local currency. 
Total selling, general and administrative expense was $42 million in the first quarter of 2016 compared to $39 million in the same quarter of 2015. For the quarter, the increase in selling, general and administrative expense was primarily due to increases in certain management incentives in 2016 and higher costs associated with corporate sales and marketing to support our revenue growth. Interest expense net was flat between the periods. 
Please turn to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of March 31, 2016, we had cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $424 million; working capital of $650 million; net cash of $58 million. And in addition to the $424 million of cash on our balance sheet, we had $2 million of availability on our credit facility. Capital expenditures through March 31, 2016, were $26 million. We are projecting capital expenditures for 2016 at $120 million to $130 million. Approximately $100 million has been allocated to North American project, 50% for growth and the remaining for capital maintenance and cost reduction. The remaining $20 million to $30 million has been allocated to our South American segment, primarily for the building of a third mill in Chile. 
Now with that, I'll turn the call over to Curt for his comments

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sallie, and good morning and thanks for participating on today's call. As I usually do, I'll start with our safety performance. The American Panel Association just announced the results of their safety and health awards program for 2015, and I'
componenttext:
Thank you, Sallie, and good morning and thanks for participating on today's call. As I usually do, I'll start with our safety performance. The American Panel Association just announced the results of their safety and health awards program for 2015, and I'm pleased that for the second year in a row, LP was recognized the safest large company that's a company with more than 4 mills. This is the sixth time that we have been so recognized in the last 8 years. Our I-Joist JV, which has 2 mills with Resolute in Quebec, was named the safest small company with 3 or fewer mills. There's been 11 facilities included in the Incident Free Honor Society. The American Forest and Paper Association also released their safety data for 2015 [indiscernible] companies, and LP was identified as having the best total incident rate. I continue to be extremely proud of all of our employees who recognize the value of being safe and commit to it and act accordingly. 
In addition to the obvious savings in workers' compensation cost, LP employees have made their commitment to safety the cornerstone of our company's culture, which we believe gives us a competitive edge in the hiring and retention of our people. 
Finally, the safety culture extends to the many contractors that we use in implementing our capital projects. We have gone over 2 years without a single contractor injury associated with these nonroutine tasks. 
We did have our board meeting and our Annual Meeting of Shareholders last Friday. I'm pleased to report that all the nominees for director were handily elected. The auditors were ratified, and our annual say-on-pay advisory vote passed with over a 98% approval rate. 
Also, our board did name a new officer. Greg Harrison, a long-time LP Manager, has been named Vice President Siding Manufacturing as a recognition of his importance to the success of this business. Greg was instrumental in the successful conversion and startup of the Swan Valley mill. 
Today, I'll be providing comments on our results and accomplishments, discuss key demand drivers and give you my views on the outlook for the rest of this year. For the second consecutive quarter, all business segments reported a positive adjusted EBITDA that total $52 million for the company. EBITDA improved by $46 million over Q1 of 2015 and by $18 million compared to last quarter. In OSB, Random Lengths reported North Central 7/16's Q1 pricing down $17 versus the last quarter, but we're actually reporting flat due to an increase in our value-added mix and improved freight utilization. As a result of these significant factors, improved operational productivity and cost control, our EBITDA improved to $30 million versus $25 million in Q4. 
During the quarter, we also successfully completed the press rebuild of our Hanceville, Alabama mill. 
In Siding, our SmartSide revenue grew 28% versus Q4, driven by a 22% volume increase. The SmartSide volume has the highest volume ever that we've achieved in Q1 of last year. The Swan Valley siding mill conversion is ahead of the pro forma production schedule, and we expect this mill to make a positive contribution next quarter. We're very pleased with the rebound on our Siding sales, as we put a major focus on returning to growth as we put capacity back in front of this business. 
As I said last quarter, we have unleashed our sales and marketing team along with our distribution partners, and we are seeing the results. In EWP, we are EBITDA-positive for the quarter and performed better than Q1 of last year. However, we did see a drop in EBITDA performance compared to Q4 last year due to an equipment failure in our one of mills that produced quarter-over-quarter sales and a change in the mix. 
As Sallie said in South America, we had a very good first quarter, with adjusted EBITDA at $7 million. Prices improved in Chile and Brazil in local currency versus last quarter. Strong export volumes in China and other South American countries offset weak domestic demand in Brazil. We continue with the engineering design work for our third mill in Chile in anticipation of board approval of this project over the summer. 
The housing market, as Sallie mentioned, the Q1 news was a little bit mixed. Overall, Q1 housing starts ran at an annual rate of 1.13 million, actually flat to Q4 of last year. The consensus for 2016 starts is now at 1.23 million, a 10% improvement over 2015, which I believe is possible. The consensus forecast for 2017 is 1.37 million, another 12% increase. The good news for us is that in Q1, single-family starts averaged a seasonally adjusted rate of 792,000. This is the highest quarterly rate since Q4 of 2007, and this represents an increase of 23% over the same quarter last year. We believe the good weather in February and March aided starts. 
Also notable are the improvements in new home demand for entry-level buyers. We estimate that the OSB consumption ratio between single and multifamily is about 3:1. The improvement in single-family starts was offset by a decline in multifamily starts. Compared to Q4 of last year, multifamily starts declined 10%, falling from 379,000 to 341,000, which happened to be flat with last year. Household formation growth continues to drive rising rents and low vacancy rates across the country. Other positive housing data: existing home inventory was down 1.1% year-over-year through January, so home inventory is very tight on a historical basis. 
On the financing side, average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rates were 3.58% for the week ended April 15, which was down from 3.92% 3 months earlier. 
In Canada, for the first quarter, starts were at seasonally adjusted rate of 200,000, a growth of 2% from Q4. Almost all of this increase was in single-family detached units, which makes up about 35% of Canadian starts. So while there is forecasted growth in housing for the next several years, it is incumbent on us to focus on continuing to increase our growth outside of our traditional market by developing products, product applications and market segments that can address needs and industrial repair model, where year-over-year growth has exceeded 10% and light commercial activities. The year-over-year nonresidential construction was up 11.2% through February. 
So while the consensus for 2016 housing starts has moved down slightly since January, I am encouraged by the increase in single-family starts and the supporting data for sales of building materials by dealers are up double digits in the first part of the year. So I remain optimistic about the rest of 2016. 
As I've said before, I continue to be concerned about labor and land availability for builders, uncertainly relative to lending standards for buyers and the impact for the presidential race on our nation and more specifically, potentially on consumer confidence; that continued strong employment growth will bolster household, formation; and fundamentally, housing demand should strength throughout this year, providing a positive market environment for our products. 
In our Siding business, strong order rates continued through April, and OSB Random Lengths has reported North Central pricing flat or increasing each week since the end of the quarter. So compared to this time last year, pricing is higher by 37%. Strong single-family starts is driving demand for both these businesses as well as Engineered Wood. 
South America, expect good OSB and siding demand in Chile throughout the year. For Brazil, we will continue to focus on export opportunities as these are generally priced in U.S. dollars, and we can benefit from the week Brazilian real. 
With that, let me turn it over to Sallie for questions

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Well, thank you, Curt. Karen, we're ready for questions. If you could go to the queue.
