headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Mark Wilde from Bank of Montreal.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Mark Wilde from Bank of Montreal.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curt, I wondered if you can talk a little bit about your operating rate in OSB in the first quarter. And also, could you just talk a little bit about your margins in OSB because you've had a couple of competitors report last week, their OSB margins were q
componenttext: Curt, I wondered if you can talk a little bit about your operating rate in OSB in the first quarter. And also, could you just talk a little bit about your margins in OSB because you've had a couple of competitors report last week, their OSB margins were quite a bit higher on a reported basis than yours? And I wondered if you could just talk to that disparity.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our operating rates in the first quarter were 86% if you don't include the Chambord mill. And as a reminder, what we did have in the quarter is we did take a month of downtime at our Hanceville, Alabama mill to do the press rebuild. As far as the mar
componenttext: Yes. Our operating rates in the first quarter were 86% if you don't include the Chambord mill. And as a reminder, what we did have in the quarter is we did take a month of downtime at our Hanceville, Alabama mill to do the press rebuild. As far as the margin, we do focus on the margin compared to our public peers, and we actually made some progress in the first quarter versus the fourth quarter. Fundamentally in the past, we have taken more of the industry downtime, so our operating rates have been a little bit lower. I think our public competitors talk about operating rates in -- about 92%, so we're about 6 points below that. We do believe that if Hanceville had to run all quarter instead of taking a month of downtime, there'd probably been another $3 per 1,000 that we would have added to our margin. So we are focused on that. I think that fundamentally, it's tied to the operating rates and how much we run these operations. And we are advantaged a little bit by our value-added percentage, but our competitor is also focused on value-added product.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Will the operating rate be down in Brazil and Chile, Curt?
componenttext: Will the operating rate be down in Brazil and Chile, Curt?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chile is running 100%. And actually, we're adding products from Brazil to Chile as well as North America to satisfy that demand. That's why we're looking at a third mill. In Brazil, we're probably operating about 60%. We've seen local demand fall by about
componenttext: Chile is running 100%. And actually, we're adding products from Brazil to Chile as well as North America to satisfy that demand. That's why we're looking at a third mill. In Brazil, we're probably operating about 60%. We've seen local demand fall by about 20% just due to the economy. We've been able to fill that with some of the export business that I talked about earlier.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally, can you just kind of update us on kind of current market conditions? We had quite a flurry in the recent reported Random Lengths prices last week. I think some of that was tied to the story around the Norbord outage.
componenttext: Okay. And then finally, can you just kind of update us on kind of current market conditions? We had quite a flurry in the recent reported Random Lengths prices last week. I think some of that was tied to the story around the Norbord outage.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's exactly right. Because when that fire was reported at the end of the day on -- or Wednesday, early Thursday, we did see pricing go up on west side principally a little bit in the North Central. And I just think that as we go into the q
componenttext: Yes, I think that's exactly right. Because when that fire was reported at the end of the day on -- or Wednesday, early Thursday, we did see pricing go up on west side principally a little bit in the North Central. And I just think that as we go into the quarter, we're closer to -- the demand is closer to the supply, and we're seeing it tightening up. I did see that Norbord issued a release today that they expect the outage to only last about 2 weeks.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then last question along those lines. I mean, just with the suppliers so early in the season, do you guys have any view on the likelihood of any kind of logging restrictions or logging difficulties as we kind of move into the summer season?
componenttext: Yes. And then last question along those lines. I mean, just with the suppliers so early in the season, do you guys have any view on the likelihood of any kind of logging restrictions or logging difficulties as we kind of move into the summer season?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question. And Sallie and I talked to our forestry group, and we do have fires in the Peace Valley area, British Columbia. There are 3 fires there that have happened in the last 24 hours. We don't think that's going to affect our operating a
componenttext: That's a great question. And Sallie and I talked to our forestry group, and we do have fires in the Peace Valley area, British Columbia. There are 3 fires there that have happened in the last 24 hours. We don't think that's going to affect our operating areas. Where the fires are in Fort McMurray doesn't affect us. It may have some impact on our competitors, but it's certainly not a threat to us. The other part that we're worried about is the rain we've had in Texas and Alabama. East Texas is 20 inches above normal so far this season. Alabama is 15 inches above normal. The good news is we did put in inventory in our log decks in the fourth quarter to take advantage both of lower pricing and to offset maybe some of the risk of this. So we think we're in pretty good shape there. In North Carolina, we've also had heavy rain fall, but we think we're in pretty good shape in North Carolina. But the fire season in Western Canada is of concern. And so we're going to be very cognizant of that. Fortunately, we've built a pretty good log deck at Peace Valley and Dawson Creek.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually John Babcock on the line for George. Just quickly here with regards to EWP. I mean, you as well as some of your peers have done pretty well this quarter from a volume perspective there, and I just want to get a sense for ultimately what fact
componenttext: It's actually John Babcock on the line for George. Just quickly here with regards to EWP. I mean, you as well as some of your peers have done pretty well this quarter from a volume perspective there, and I just want to get a sense for ultimately what factors you look at when you're trying to gauge whether or not the market is tight enough to have some pricing up there. And then also, given where the market stands right now, if you see that potential for a price increase this year.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the thing that we really look at for Engineered Wood is single-family. There's a little bit of multifamily activity, but this is largely a single-family new construction-driven business. And so the housing starts that we had in the first qua
componenttext: Well, I think the thing that we really look at for Engineered Wood is single-family. There's a little bit of multifamily activity, but this is largely a single-family new construction-driven business. And so the housing starts that we had in the first quarter where permits are, I think, bodes well for continued demand. I think the difficulty with the price increase is that we do have a lot of excess capacity in this business, and we just have to be cognizant of that. We did have a recent consolidation, and that has created some turmoil in the market as producers are pursuing new business or customers are looking for new business partners. And so there's -- I would characterize Q1 as a bit of turmoil, and it's probably going to extend into Q2. That's probably -- when you have that kind of turmoil, it's probably not a time for a price increase, but I can see the second half of the year, at least LP, considering price increases, as we will see higher raw materials, particularly in the OSB side.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just next on the Siding side of things. You talked a little bit about how, ultimately, you tried to get your sales force out there and other factors to drive volumes there. I was just wondering, where there any market factors that also migh
componenttext: Okay. And then just next on the Siding side of things. You talked a little bit about how, ultimately, you tried to get your sales force out there and other factors to drive volumes there. I was just wondering, where there any market factors that also might have helped you? Or was there any sort of volume kind of pull-forward that also might have driven things there?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's just the opposite. I think we did have -- because we're on allocation last year, I think last year's Q1 was inordinately high. So if you average that with Q2 of last year, that's probably kind of where the lending demand was in 2015. The
componenttext: No. I think it's just the opposite. I think we did have -- because we're on allocation last year, I think last year's Q1 was inordinately high. So if you average that with Q2 of last year, that's probably kind of where the lending demand was in 2015. The good news for us is we are seeing order rates that are higher in Q2 than we did in Q1, which means there's not much inventory in the channel. And what we're hearing from our distribution partners is what they're taking is leaving their yards. So I think that's good news for us looking forward.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Bill Hoffmann from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Bill Hoffmann from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curt, can you talk a little bit about your success -- or how you're doing on some of the growth in industrial applications, et cetera, for -- on the OSB side?
componenttext: Curt, can you talk a little bit about your success -- or how you're doing on some of the growth in industrial applications, et cetera, for -- on the OSB side?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very circumspect. I'll talk about that because I don't necessarily want all my public competitors to know how we're doing in there. We do have -- I think we've talked about -- a little bit about growth in innovation in the past. We are spending a lot of r
componenttext: Very circumspect. I'll talk about that because I don't necessarily want all my public competitors to know how we're doing in there. We do have -- I think we've talked about -- a little bit about growth in innovation in the past. We are spending a lot of resources looking at alternative markets to traditional single-family, multifamily housing, and we are having some success. But as I think everybody in the phone realizes, it's hard to get a new product in the market and have a big revenue impact in the first year or 2. But we're certainly setting a foundation for continuing to grow. I'll give you a few examples. We went into the furniture market in 2009, right, when we're in the midst of the downturn. It took us a while, but now most of the furniture manufacturers have converted to OSB from plywood. That's benefited not just us, but it's benefited the entire industry. With our fire retardant product, we actually introduced that about 5 years ago, and now we are adding a second production facility so we can satisfy market demand. Hopefully right after that, we'll provide a third manufacturing facility so we can do that. So it's a little slow taking off, but I'm pleased with the progress. If I look at the funnel projects we've got, it's very robust. We're limiting where put our resources to those highest priorities, but I feel pretty good about it. And our goal is to have 50% of the overall company at a high value-added margin products in the next couple of years.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just with regards to South America and Chile, just given some of the issues down there, any thoughts on slowing down your project -- expansion project down there? Or what do you think the market condition is going to look like going forwar
componenttext: Great. And then just with regards to South America and Chile, just given some of the issues down there, any thoughts on slowing down your project -- expansion project down there? Or what do you think the market condition is going to look like going forward here?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that project is going to be somewhere around $60 million to put another mill down there. Today, the product that we ship from either Brazil or from North America ends up not providing any margin to the corporation because we give it all to t
componenttext: Well, I think that project is going to be somewhere around $60 million to put another mill down there. Today, the product that we ship from either Brazil or from North America ends up not providing any margin to the corporation because we give it all to the transportation company. That's about $100 to $110 bill. So if I can put that mill in place and capture that $110 per 1,000, I have a pretty immediate return on that that's significant. So it's really just having local production. Plus, the other thing that's going on is we are seeing Argentina bounce back with the new government. We're seeing Colombia become a stronger economy, and we have -- we've long had sales into Peru. So I think there's great growth opportunities for us, both in margin and in product.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon from Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon from Vertical Research.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sallie, you mentioned that there was probably about $1 million, I think you mentioned, in terms of the inventory. I want to make -- or maybe I got my terms mixed up. But how much was that inventory adjustment in the Siding business? You mentioned you had
componenttext: Sallie, you mentioned that there was probably about $1 million, I think you mentioned, in terms of the inventory. I want to make -- or maybe I got my terms mixed up. But how much was that inventory adjustment in the Siding business? You mentioned you had higher cost and capitalized inventory as you went through the first quarter. Did you actually tell us what the impact of that was?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Chip. We didn't really quantify it, but it did impact -- it was a piece of why we had higher sales and lower EBITDA in the first quarter of '16 relative to the first quarter of 2015.
componenttext: No, Chip. We didn't really quantify it, but it did impact -- it was a piece of why we had higher sales and lower EBITDA in the first quarter of '16 relative to the first quarter of 2015.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess on that, it seems like I remembered from a year ago you had some very strong shipments in that first quarter of '15 and that you all correctly let us know that maybe some of the -- what normally would have been felt in the second quarter was p
componenttext: And I guess on that, it seems like I remembered from a year ago you had some very strong shipments in that first quarter of '15 and that you all correctly let us know that maybe some of the -- what normally would have been felt in the second quarter was pull-forward. Did you see that this year? Or should we see a more normal progression from first to second?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We think you should -- there should be a much more normal progression from first to second, similar to what you would have seen in the years like '13 and '14.
componenttext: No. We think you should -- there should be a much more normal progression from first to second, similar to what you would have seen in the years like '13 and '14.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then, I guess, getting back on the OSB situation. It looked like you had a big pop in the benchmark from mid-week to the end of the week last week. And not to split hairs about day-to-day. But it seemed like other regions were only -- Nort
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then, I guess, getting back on the OSB situation. It looked like you had a big pop in the benchmark from mid-week to the end of the week last week. And not to split hairs about day-to-day. But it seemed like other regions were only -- North Central went up 1,600 or 1,800, but the other regions only went up about 7 or 8. And I guess, in terms of your business, did you really see any change in behavior on the part of your customers in response to the high-level shutdown or not really?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We did see a response. I think all of our partners on the West Coast are concerned about getting sufficient volumes to satisfy their customer demand in the second quarter going into the third quarter. So it's my view Western Canada was a direct reaction t
componenttext: We did see a response. I think all of our partners on the West Coast are concerned about getting sufficient volumes to satisfy their customer demand in the second quarter going into the third quarter. So it's my view Western Canada was a direct reaction to the fire.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the last question is I would imagine you're selling more of your product down here than you're making here. I would suppose that some of the Canadian production comes down here, and that certainly helped your OSB margins, given how weak the
componenttext: Okay. And then the last question is I would imagine you're selling more of your product down here than you're making here. I would suppose that some of the Canadian production comes down here, and that certainly helped your OSB margins, given how weak the C dollar had been. But it sort -- it has strengthened of late, and I just didn't know if you could give us some help in terms of how you think your costs are going to flow through in the next couple of quarters in OSB either based on the C dollar being stronger or maybe there are other cost issues like resins that you could help us get our arms around.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we said in the past is that $0.01 for the Canadian dollar is about $2 million annualized, but that's still probably a pretty good number. So each $0.01 change would either raise or lower it by about $2 million. Now that assumes the same amount
componenttext: Well, what we said in the past is that $0.01 for the Canadian dollar is about $2 million annualized, but that's still probably a pretty good number. So each $0.01 change would either raise or lower it by about $2 million. Now that assumes the same amount of product comes down. So it does fluctuate, but that's the good rule of thumb.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we haven't specifically quantified for OSB the improvement in raw material costs, but we have said that we thought this year -- as you'll recall, '15 we thought a lot of improvement due to raw material costs. We thought '16 would look similar to '15,
componenttext: And we haven't specifically quantified for OSB the improvement in raw material costs, but we have said that we thought this year -- as you'll recall, '15 we thought a lot of improvement due to raw material costs. We thought '16 would look similar to '15, and we haven't really come off that. For a while, I think we would have thought oil would -- and resins would help us a little bit. That may still be the case. We just have to see where oil -- what happens with oil as we go further.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub from Buckingham Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub from Buckingham Research.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: One question on pricing for OSB. Obviously, it has continued to move higher. A competitor of yours indicated that their average prices in April had been up about $15 versus the first quarter, and then they gave some color on where they were now versus Apr
componenttext: One question on pricing for OSB. Obviously, it has continued to move higher. A competitor of yours indicated that their average prices in April had been up about $15 versus the first quarter, and then they gave some color on where they were now versus April. Could you provide a similar type of framework for us?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's tough. I will do that in July.
componenttext: I think it's tough. I will do that in July.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And obviously, a lot of good news in the quarter. But one area where you do on a relative basis seem to continue to struggle quite a bit is that Engineered Wood business, where some of your competitors are doing a lot better. Any thoughts as to what
componenttext: Okay. And obviously, a lot of good news in the quarter. But one area where you do on a relative basis seem to continue to struggle quite a bit is that Engineered Wood business, where some of your competitors are doing a lot better. Any thoughts as to what the relative issues might be at this point?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we did -- we do a competitive analysis every quarter of looking at what is publicly available. And it's a little tough because some of our competitors include plywood in that and MDF and particleboard. Some include their distribution operation, so y
componenttext: Well, we did -- we do a competitive analysis every quarter of looking at what is publicly available. And it's a little tough because some of our competitors include plywood in that and MDF and particleboard. Some include their distribution operation, so you can't really see what the pricing is. So we look at a relative change between quarters both the last quarter and then the same quarter of the prior year. And from a relative change basis, we were pretty consistent both on a volume standpoint and a pricing standpoint with our competitors and the industry. What hurt us in the first quarter is we did have -- one of our press lines for LVL did go down on the East Coast, and we had about a month of outage. And what we did is we replaced that volume to satisfy our customers' needs with a production that we get out of Murphy Plywood. When we sell that, we're basically recovering our sales costs, but not any manufacturing margin. So our volumes were good, but we had to replace it with manufacturer product outside. The other thing, when you look at our margins versus our competitor, just to remember, is that the Abitibi -- or the Resolute joint venture in Quebec, we only get half of that margin because we share with our partner. We also only have half of the investment in that. So I believe our numbers were about $2 million lower than they should have been due to that -- due to the fact of having to satisfy our customers out of the Murphy volume.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And lastly, if you could just give us an update on cap spend expectation for this year and if there are any very early reads for next year.
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And lastly, if you could just give us an update on cap spend expectation for this year and if there are any very early reads for next year.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, we're continuing to forecast very similar to what we said in the first quarter. We're now at $120 million to $130 million, down a little bit what I -- from what I said 3 months ago. Still $100 million in the U.S. $20 million to $30 million is in Chi
componenttext: Mark, we're continuing to forecast very similar to what we said in the first quarter. We're now at $120 million to $130 million, down a little bit what I -- from what I said 3 months ago. Still $100 million in the U.S. $20 million to $30 million is in Chile, primarily for the -- or South America, but primarily for the third Chilean mill.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Mark Connelly from CLSA.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mark Connelly from CLSA.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Curt, you said that you think you're going to be okay with fiber despite the rains and floods and fires. Are you worried about risk to average prices if you end up with competitors who are scrambling in those same regions?
componenttext: So Curt, you said that you think you're going to be okay with fiber despite the rains and floods and fires. Are you worried about risk to average prices if you end up with competitors who are scrambling in those same regions?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the risk is that commodity pricing will go up, which is a good risk to have. If you looking at fiber, then the end product's going to go up. I don't think that we're going to see any, but we could see some short-term pricing. But we have a s
componenttext: Well, I think the risk is that commodity pricing will go up, which is a good risk to have. If you looking at fiber, then the end product's going to go up. I don't think that we're going to see any, but we could see some short-term pricing. But we have a strategic supplier program, and we've got long term relationships with most of our fiber suppliers. So I don't think that's going to be a significant risk. It may be a spot risk, but not significant.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, okay. And if you -- just changing gears. Can you talk about how you're thinking about OSB acquisitions? If something came up now, how much you might be willing to stretch the balance sheet? And whether you're thinking is any different after Ainswort
componenttext: Sure, okay. And if you -- just changing gears. Can you talk about how you're thinking about OSB acquisitions? If something came up now, how much you might be willing to stretch the balance sheet? And whether you're thinking is any different after Ainsworth about what makes sense.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Ainsworth was a very difficult process. I think if there were a one-off mill, we would consider it. I think anything of scale, I committed to waiting until we have a change in administration or change in view. If you just look at the public comments
componenttext: Well, Ainsworth was a very difficult process. I think if there were a one-off mill, we would consider it. I think anything of scale, I committed to waiting until we have a change in administration or change in view. If you just look at the public comments on the difficulty of GP buying -- or selling 2 relatively modest Engineered Wood operations to Boise tells me if I do anything of significance can be a little bit problematic so...

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, it may be worth noting that in particular, mills that are located in aspen-based regions would be interesting to us because our Siding business primarily -- is aspen-based.
componenttext: Mark, it may be worth noting that in particular, mills that are located in aspen-based regions would be interesting to us because our Siding business primarily -- is aspen-based.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: And our next question is a follow-up from the line of Mark Wilde from Bank of Montreal.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sallie, can you just walk us through if it's possible sort of financially how the ramp on the Swan Valley will look as we move through the year? I think you said it was about a $1 million drag in the first quarter, and it sounded like it was at least brea
componenttext: Sallie, can you just walk us through if it's possible sort of financially how the ramp on the Swan Valley will look as we move through the year? I think you said it was about a $1 million drag in the first quarter, and it sounded like it was at least breakeven in the second quarter. And I'm just curious about how that sequences into 3 and 4.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what you need to do, Mark, is really go back and think about what happened in the third and fourth quarter of 2015. And what we said -- and I know it was 2 -- $10 million for the whole year. I think it was $4 million.
componenttext: Well, I think what you need to do, Mark, is really go back and think about what happened in the third and fourth quarter of 2015. And what we said -- and I know it was 2 -- $10 million for the whole year. I think it was $4 million.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: $10 million in the third.We said $10 million in the third and $5 million in the fourth.
componenttext: $10 million in the third.We said $10 million in the third and $5 million in the fourth.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So Mark, we believe it was $6 million in the third quarter and $4 million in the fourth quarter -- other way around, $4 in the fourth quarter and $6 million in the -- $4 in the third quarter and $6 million in the fourth quarter. So $10 million for t
componenttext: Okay. So Mark, we believe it was $6 million in the third quarter and $4 million in the fourth quarter -- other way around, $4 in the fourth quarter and $6 million in the -- $4 in the third quarter and $6 million in the fourth quarter. So $10 million for the whole year. And so I think the best way to think about that is we said it was less than $1 million in the first quarter, and we don't anticipate any negative drag in the remainder of this year. And so at this point, it just will be fully incorporated into our Siding business, and we would -- don't expect it to be any different from any of our other siding mills, albeit the ramp-up will be fully completed by the end of the quarter.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, right. And then, Curt, any sense that you can give us of what the underlying growth rate is for your Siding business in your view?
componenttext: Okay, right. And then, Curt, any sense that you can give us of what the underlying growth rate is for your Siding business in your view?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we just take the market and look at the mix between repair/remodel, new home construction, retail business, the inherent growth rate is 7% to 8%. So penetration, we think the other 5% to 6% on top of that. So I think you're 13% to 14% overall. And if
componenttext: When we just take the market and look at the mix between repair/remodel, new home construction, retail business, the inherent growth rate is 7% to 8%. So penetration, we think the other 5% to 6% on top of that. So I think you're 13% to 14% overall. And if some of these new products really take off, then the marketplace could be higher than that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And any thoughts on how you think about the potential of having another player coming to the market?
componenttext: Yes. And any thoughts on how you think about the potential of having another player coming to the market?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there -- it's been rumored for a long time. I just think that there would be a big uphill climb. We have a 25-year history of product reliability and warranty information. We've got a sales force in the field. It's now 140 people strong. We have m
componenttext: I think there -- it's been rumored for a long time. I just think that there would be a big uphill climb. We have a 25-year history of product reliability and warranty information. We've got a sales force in the field. It's now 140 people strong. We have marketing to support that. It's a different kind of sale than it is commodity OSB. And then, as you know, we spent $85 million converting Swan into a siding mill, so there is a little bit of capital that goes into it. And I think I mentioned on the first quarter call, Swan Valley has one of our most experienced mill teams. It wasn't easy for them. That's even with having that augmented with people from our siding mills to help them with that ramp-up. Because unlike OSB, if you have a flaw in the face of the panel, it's downgraded. You can't continue to ship it. So it's a tougher standard for an external product. It is going to remain to be seen. So I -- it wouldn't surprise me, but we've heard it now for 10 years, that people are going to come in the business and...

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nobody, okay. And the last question I had. So it seems like even away from just fuel prices that -- conditions in the freight markets have eased from where they were a year or 2 ago. Are you getting any benefit from what were freight costs either coming t
componenttext: Nobody, okay. And the last question I had. So it seems like even away from just fuel prices that -- conditions in the freight markets have eased from where they were a year or 2 ago. Are you getting any benefit from what were freight costs either coming through on the rails or from a trucking standpoint?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Nothing that merits mentioning, Mark. I think we're seeing a pretty similar to rates -- pretty similar to where they were in the last year.
componenttext: Yes. Nothing that merits mentioning, Mark. I think we're seeing a pretty similar to rates -- pretty similar to where they were in the last year.

componenttext: So Mark, I'll comment on that. They put fuel surcharges in for the rail companies, the trucking companies and the airline industry. And none of them have come off. Doesn't make any sense [indiscernible].

componenttext: [indiscernible] what happened to fuel.

componenttext: I know. But look at the airline. You got a fuel surcharge in the airline ticket every time you buy one. And that's -- they don't come off generally. What I will say is probably due more to weather than anything else. We did not have many rail disruptions in the first quarter, and that's -- maybe if you go back to 2013 and '14, it was terrible. So we actually are very [indiscernible] to the railroads.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So costs may not have come down, but kind of the logistics [indiscernible] have been less daunting. Is that correct?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's exactly right. And as I mentioned, particularly in our OSB business, we were able -- because of that reliability, we were able to change how we treated reloads and how we treated inventory because we could rely on them to get the product to the cus
componenttext: That's exactly right. And as I mentioned, particularly in our OSB business, we were able -- because of that reliability, we were able to change how we treated reloads and how we treated inventory because we could rely on them to get the product to the customer, and part of the improvement we had on pricing was better logistics.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I know between raw materials coming in and OSB and siding going out, freight is a really important piece of your cost structure.

componenttext: Yes. They -- we actually ended up from where we were in the fourth quarter, and we are also up from we were on finished goods in the first quarter of 2015. componenttext: I would say that on the fiber side, we saw improvement, primarily in OSB, a little bit in siding. And I don't want to -- we did see some improvements in -- I think I had mentioned this in my comments, in resin pricing [indiscernible] relative to the first quarter of '15.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Norbord 2-week outage, about 35 million square feet, big picture, doesn't seem to be that much, maybe 3% of your quarterly volume, for example. Is the devil in the details or the logistics of getting product to market in the Western region where the d
componenttext: The Norbord 2-week outage, about 35 million square feet, big picture, doesn't seem to be that much, maybe 3% of your quarterly volume, for example. Is the devil in the details or the logistics of getting product to market in the Western region where the distances are large? Is the trucking capacity available to move volumes a few hundred miles out of their normal routes?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's all in the mind of the buyer, John. This is an emotional response. It's a response with incomplete information. As information becomes available, then I think buyers will modify their behavior. But this was an emotional response. And we get that -- f
componenttext: It's all in the mind of the buyer, John. This is an emotional response. It's a response with incomplete information. As information becomes available, then I think buyers will modify their behavior. But this was an emotional response. And we get that -- for instance, when Martco announced they're going to build a new mill, pricing went down, but that mill won't be operational for 2.5 years. Look, it really is psychological. And if a buyer can't get the wood, they have a tendency to raise the price.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: For your 2 mills in B.C., Peace River and Dawson Creek, do you anticipate any difficulty getting fiber? Are the foresters going to put down their logging equipment and go fight a fire somewhere?
componenttext: For your 2 mills in B.C., Peace River and Dawson Creek, do you anticipate any difficulty getting fiber? Are the foresters going to put down their logging equipment and go fight a fire somewhere?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Typically, at this time of year, you're not logging. So whatever you're going to run through the mills has to be already sitting in the log yard or at a satellite log yard. So our foresters won't be in the woods until next month at the earliest. Is that r
componenttext: Typically, at this time of year, you're not logging. So whatever you're going to run through the mills has to be already sitting in the log yard or at a satellite log yard. So our foresters won't be in the woods until next month at the earliest. Is that right, Mike?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's close, yes.
componenttext: It's close, yes.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So they won't be in the woods until next month. And then if there is fire -- a fire danger, they may limit what areas they can operate in. But we fundamentally have enough wood in our yards to run through the middle of July in both Peace Valley and Dawson
componenttext: So they won't be in the woods until next month. And then if there is fire -- a fire danger, they may limit what areas they can operate in. But we fundamentally have enough wood in our yards to run through the middle of July in both Peace Valley and Dawson Creek.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 09, 2016

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference may be recorded.I would like to introduce your host for today's confere
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Louisiana-Pacific Corporation Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference may be recorded.
I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Sallie Bailey, Executive VP and Chief Financial Officer. Maam, please go ahead.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you very much, Michelle, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LPs financial results for the second quarter of 2016. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer. And with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's C
componenttext:
Great. Thank you very much, Michelle, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss LPs financial results for the second quarter of 2016. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer. And with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; as well as Mike Kinney and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact.
I will begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the second quarter of 2016 and the first half of 2016. This will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selective balance sheet items.
After I finsih my comment, Kurt will discuss the general -- provide his perspective on our operating results our capital projects and give some thoughts on our outlook.
As we've done in the past, we've opened up this call to the public and are doing a webcast. The webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. Additionally, to help with the discussion, we've provided a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. 
I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information as well as our Form 10-Q.  I do want to remind all the participants that the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation has some of the necessary reconciliations that's been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. And rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporate them with this reference.
Our second quarter results continued the momentum which started in the first quarter. In addition to the strong results in our OSB segment reporting the $63 million improvement in adjusted EBITDA and just over $40 million of increased sales, the signing business reported record volume and sale, including a 14% increase in volume from the first quarter of 2016 and 22% improved volumes from the same quarter last year.
Now with that, let me go into the detail.
Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for discussion of the second quarter and the for six months of 2016 consolidated result. We are reporting net sales of $582 million for the second quarter of 2016, an increase of -- an 18% increase from net sales of $493 million reported in the second quarter of 2015. The second quarter reported net income of $32 million or $0.22 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $20 million or a $0.14 loss per diluted share in the second quarter of 2015.
The adjusted income from continuing operations for the quarter was $40 million or $0.28 per diluted share based upon a normalized tax rate of 35% as compared to a loss of $12 million or a loss of $0.08 per share reported in the second quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $99 million in the quarter compared to $16 million in the second quarter of 2015. In the first six months of 2016, we recorded net income of $42 million or $0.29 per diluted share compared to a net loss for the first six months of 2015 of $54 million or a loss of $0.38 per diluted share. The adjusted income for the six-month period was $50 million or $0.34 per diluted share based upon a normalized tax rate of 35% compared to loss of $31 million or $0.22 loss per diluted share for the first six months of 2015.
Adjusted EBITDAR for continuing operations was $151 million for the first six months compared to $22 million in the first six months of 2015.
And moving on to Slide 5 and a review of our segment results. with OSB. OSB reported net sales for the second quarter of 2016 of $253 million, up 20% from $211 million in the second quarter of 2015. OSB reported operating income of $44 million compared to a loss of $18 million in the second quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $59 million compared to negative adjusted EBITDA of $4 million in the second quarter of 2015. Sales volumes in OSB were down 7% from the second quarter of 2015, primarily due to the conversion of the Swan mill to a Siding milll, and as such those financial results are not included as part of the Siding segment. Pricing for OSB was higher by 30%, which improved operating results by $59 million. For the first 6 months of 2016, OSB reported an operating profit of $59 million on sales of $470 million compared to loss of $47 million and $401 million of sales in the first 6 months of 2015.  
For six months of 2016, we reported adjusted EBITDA of $89 million compared to negative adjusted EBITDA of $17 million in the first 6 months of 2015. Sales volume are lower by 4% and sales prices were higher by 22%. The impact of higher sales price on OSB operations was $86 million for the first 6 months of 2016 compared to the first six months of 2015.
For the quarter and the 6 months of 2016, reductions in raw material cost, higher utilization rates as well as a positive impact of the Canadian currency on our Canadian operation improved the OSB segment's financial result as compared to similar period in 2015.  
Moving on to Slide 6 for the results of the Siding business. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel products as well as OSB produced on one line of our Harvard facility. Siding reported net sales for the second quarter of 2016 of $207 million, up 26% from $164 million in the second quarter of 2015. Siding reported operating income of $42 million compared to operating income of $29 million in the second quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA in the quarter was $49 million compared to 39 -- $35 million for the same period last year. Sales volumes -- SmartSide volume was up 22% from the prior year and 14% sequentially. Sales prices per SmartSide were down 2% due to changes in product mix with individual prices remaining relatively flat. For CanExel, sales volumes increased 24% due to increased demand, primarily in Europe. Sales prices were lower by 3% due to the impact of the Canadian dollar. Based upon Canadian dollar seeling, prices for CanExel were 2% higher than the same period in 2015.  
We produced approximately 53 million square feet of OSB in the segment during the second quarter of 2016 as compared to no OSB production in the second quarter of 2015.  
The Siding segment reported sales of $389 million for the first 6 months of 2016, an increase of 15% from $337 million recorded in the first six months of 2015. The Siding segment reported operating income of $69 million for the first six months as compared to $62 million in the first six months of 2015 and adjusted EBITDA of $84 million as compared to $73 million of adjusted EBITDA in the same period of 2015.
SmartSide sales volumes were up 11% and sales prices were down 2% for the first six months of 2016 compared to the same period in 2015.  
Please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation which shows the result for our Engineered Wood Products segment. The segment includes I-Joist Laminated Strand Lumber, Laminated Veneer Lumber, OSB produced at our facility and such other related products. This segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture -- or under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood.
The Engineered Wood Products segment recorded sales of $78 million in the second quarter of 2016, up $6 million from the second quarter of 2015. The EWP segment earned operating income of $0.5 million in the second quarter of 2016 compared to a loss of $2 million in the second quarter of 2015. The second quarter 2016 adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations improved to $4 million as compared to $1 million from the second quarter of 2015. Volumes for I-Joist were up 13%, while volumes of LDL and LSL were up 3% compared to the same quarter last year. Pricing was up 6% in LDL and LSL and up 5% in I-Joist.  
For the first six months, sales were $115 million, up from $137 million in the first six months of 2015. The segment's operating loss in the first half of 2016 was $2 million as compared to a loss of $6 million for the first half of 2015. And adjusted EBITDA improved to $5 million from breakeven the first six months of 2015.
Moving on to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded sales of $41 million as compared to $39 million in the second quarter of 2015. Operating income was $7 million as compared to $2 million in the second quarter of 2015 and adjusted EBITDA improved by $5 million from the second quarter of 2015 to $9 million in the second quarter of 2016. Volumes in Chile were up 15% -- volumes in Chile were up 14% and flat in Brazil compared to the same quarter last year. On the USD basis, pricing was flat in Chile and up 4% in Brazil. In local currency, Chile's pricing was up 10% for the same quarter in 2015 and Brazil's pricing increased 20%.
For the first six months our South American segment reported sales of $72 million as compared to $75 million in the first six months of 2015. Operating income was $12 million compared to $4 million in the first six months of 2015 and adjusted EBITDA increased to $16 million from $9 million in the same period of 2015.  
Total selling, general and administrative expenses were $47 million in the second quarter of 2016 compared to $38 million in the same quarter of 2015. For the six months period, our selling general and administrative expenses were $89 million for 2016 compared to $77 million for the first 6 months of 2015. For both the quarter as well as six months period, the increase in selling, general and administrative expenses was primarily due to increases in certain management incentive accruals and higher sales and marketing-related expenses.  
Please refer to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of June 30, 2016, we had cash, cash equivalents, investment and restrictive cash for $495 million. Working capital was $700 million. Net cash of a $135 million. And then in addition to the $495 million of cash on our balance sheet, we had $200 million of availability on our credit facility. Capital expenditures from the first 6 months of 2016 were $51 million. We generated operating cash flow of a $104 million for the first 6 months of 2016 and generated net cash flow of $40 million for the first 6 months of 2016.
We are continuing to project capital expenditures for 2016 of $120 million to $130 million, which approximately is $60 million is for both projects and the other $60 million -- $70 million is associated with maintenance projects. Now I'll turn the call over to Curt for his comments.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sally. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on today's call. As usual, I'll start with our safety performance. Through the first half of the year, our total incident rate or TIR was 0.31 and the rolling 12-month TIR was at 0.36. I continue t
componenttext:
Thank you, Sally. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on today's call. As usual, I'll start with our safety performance. Through the first half of the year, our total incident rate or TIR was 0.31 and the rolling 12-month TIR was at 0.36. I continue to be extremely proud of all of our employees who recognize the value of being safe, have committed to it and act accordingly.
Today, I'll be providing comments on our results and accomplishments during the last quarter and first half of the year, discuss key demand drivers, provide an update on our capital planning including a potential Siding expansion and give you my views on the outlook for the rest of this year and into next year.  
Sales in Q2 is selling, as Sally just reviewed, were 18% better than Q2 of last year and produced net income of $32 million and EPS of $0.22. This was significantly better than Q2 of last year due to greater demand leading to higher OSB prices, better Siding volumes and lower manufacturing cost across all of our businesses.
For the third consecutive quarter, all business segments recorded positive adjusted EBITDA. It totaled nearly a $100 million for the company in Q2. EBITDA improved by $83 million over Q2 of 2015 and by $52 million compared to last quarter.
In OSB, Random Lengths reported North Central Q2 pricing was 17% higher than the first quarter, LP averaged at 10% increase due to regional differences and lower premiums on flooring. However, when coupled with lower costs, our EBIT margin improved from 13.8% last quarter to 17.4% this quarter.
And Siding, our SmartSide revenues grew 26% versus same quarter last year and adjusted EBITDA was just short of $50 million, a 42% improvement. In EWP, we were EBIT positive for the quarter and EBITDA was almost $4 million compared to $600,000 in Q2 of last year. 
South America overall sales were a bit higher but EBITDA more than double. On year-to-date results, our sales were up 13%, net income was $42 million compared to loss of $54 million last year and adjusted EBITDA was $151 million, an improvement of $129 million. In Sally's review, she did discuss the expected capital expenditures for 2016. I want to give you a little bit more color on this.
One of the projects currently underway, will be to more than double the production capacity of our return OSB product FlameBlock. Today, we have used a contract manufacturer for the coding. We have licensed this technology from this very important vendor and are nearing the completion of a $15 million post-processing facility located at Clark County, Alabama site. This should be operational near the end of this quarter and will provide us with lower cost production, improved logistics and greater geographical diversity for this important growth product.  
At our board meeting last week, we did present 3 capital projects to our board which were approved. The first was a maintenance project to rebuild the press at our Texas bill. This $15 million to $17 million project will take place in the first half of next year. We have done similar projects at Roxborough, and we currently have a similar project in one of our lines at that will begin later this quarter.
You have heard me talk about a third mill in Chile for several years. After an arduous and link the environmental permitting process followed by detailed engineering, our board did agree to go ahead with this $60 million to $65 million project, which should come online late next year or early 2018.  
Like our 2 prior mills in Chile, we will be owned equipment from a few of our shuted OSB mills. This expansion will take place on our existing mill site in Southern Chile.  
The third capital discussion was more a work in process as we continue to plan for the next increment of Siding capacity. Based on our current projections, we will need additional capacity around the end of 2018.  
If we are converting an existing mill, we will need about 9  to 12 months for the conversion. If we're building a new mill, this time frame extends to more than 2 years. There are a lot of factors that need to be considered while making this decision.
The expected growth rate and product mix of our Siding business, availability, cost and species of the wood, competitive logistics, a trained and available workforce, available incentives, the overall business climate and forecasted currency rates.
When considering existing mills, the options with LP are limited due to our existing products and customers that we need to satisfy, the locations of those mills, the woods supplied to that mill and the actual mill configuration. Logically, we're also considering OSB mill owned by others in this exploration is ongoing.  
With the new mill option, we have done quite a bit of work on the potential Siding and concluded that the in Northern Minnesota makes the most sense.
We have been working with the State of Minnesota and economic development group for that region, the Iron Range resources and rehabilitation board or IRRRB on possible site selection and incentives. They have been great partners to us in this effort. To date, the legislature and the IRRRB have combined to offer significant incentives that are greatly appreciated and help to make this alternative much more competitive.  
At our board meeting, we discussed the status and requested funds for long lead time items and continuing engineering, While we complete the evaluation of all of our known alternatives. We've got currently have an estimated capital cost as this will be dependent on a number of factors that have not yet been decided. However, it is most likely that little will be spent in 2016 with spending the meeting next year and accelerating as we go into 2018.
With the improvements in our earnings and  a continued positive outlook for housing, we're increasingly getting questions on the balance sheet, liquidity and our plans for the cash. I want to provide you with my thoughts.  
As Sally mentioned in her review of Q2 results, we ended the second quarter with $495 million in cash, cash equivalents, investments and cash. In South America, we did use some of our cash within Chile to prepay about $7 million on existing debt.
Tied in with the third mill in Chile, we have been working with our local banks to put in place financing within Chile to fund the construction. You'll probably see this early next year.
So what are we going to do with the cash? Our first priority is to invest in our current facilities to lower cost, allow for the manufacture value added products and increase our flexibility to ship the product mix to what is being requested by our customers. The examples include the FlameBlock line under construction in Alabama that I just mentioned. We are installing a small I-Joist line in Chile to give us additional flexibility with in South America and we continuing to investments in our Siding mills to increase our flexibility.
The next priority is to invest in new facilities to meet anticipated demand. Earlier I the addition of a third mill in Chile and the exploration of where new Siding capacity will be installed.
These projects all have returns in excess of our 16% hurdle rate. We do continue to explore acquisitions that will add to or complement our existing businesses. Finally, our board continues to discuss returning cash to shareholders by a dividend or share repurchase. As we continue our string of profitable quarters, adding a dividend will certainly be considered. We do have -- while, we have not yet purchased any shares under this authority.
Let me shift to talk about the housing market. The Q2 news in the housing market was good but it did reaffirm there will likely be in the 8% to 10% annual growth rate for starts over the next few years. While not as strong as been forecast, this actually bodes well for both homebuilders and suppliers to the building industry. Housing starts in the first half of this year were up 7% compared to the same period last year. However, the good news for LP is that single-family starts actually increased 13% during this same periods, more of our products are consumed in a single-family start than a multifamily start as mentioned last quarter.
The consensus for 2016 now stands at $1.206 million, 9% higher than last year and 1.34 for 2017 and 11% increase over this year's forecast. In June, I did attend the Policy Advisory Board meeting of the Harvard Joint Center for housing studies, where we previewed the recently released State of the Nation's Housing 2016. While this report looks broadly at housing, homeownership rates, financing, affordability, rental markets and housing challenges, the key underpinning to their forecast is demographics and household formations.
This group believes that demographics alone will drive the addition of more than $13 million households in the next decade.
Their conclusion, I quote, factoring in the need to replace older units and meet demand for vacation homes and other uses, housing construction should average 1.6 million units a year over the next decade. I like the way they are thinking.
Other positive housing-related data home sales rose 3.5% in June, the fastest rate since February of 2008. Sales of existing single family homes rounded to annual rate of $4.5 million in May, up 4.7% compared to May of 2015.
On the financing side, the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was at 3.42 for the week ended July 15. Retail sales for building materials equipment supply dealers was 7.7% higher in the first half of 2016 versus 2015.
In Canada, second quarter housing stars were seasonally adjusted rate of 198,000, unchained from the first quarter, but up about 3% from Q2 of last year. 
So as I look to the rest of the year and into 2017, to achieve the forecasted 9% growth in housing starts with the first half being at 7%, we will need to see an acceleration in activity in the second half of the year. Based on our conversation with builders and the demand we're seeing for our products, I'm optimistic that this will happen.
I believe concerns about labor and land availability for both builders, uncertainly relative lending standards for buyers and the impact of the upcoming election in our nation, and more specifically, on consumer confidence, have been built into this reduced housing forecast.
The news is better on any of these fronts, we could see an upside in activity.
For 2017, I agree that we will a 10-plus growth in housing starts driven by increase household formations and some wage growth. Specific to LP, we have seen further increases in OSB pricing with Random Lengths reporting current levels at 16% higher than the average North Central price in Q2.
On our Siding business, we are on track to achieve volume growth of 12% of 14% on a year-to-year basis with strong activity in all of our market segments.
As I mentioned last quarter, stronger single-family starts is driving about for EWP. Additionally, the trade actions that could occur in October related to the expired lumber agreement could also be beneficial for EWP later this year and the end of 2017.
South America expect good OSB and Siding demand in Chile throughout the year. In Brazil, we will continue to focus an export opportunities as these are generally priced in USD and we can benefit from the weak Brazilian currency.
With that, let me turn over to Sally for question-and-answer.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is, you made good progress on your cost per square foot since 2004, as housing rebounced something more normalized, would you expect cost per unit to continue to come down or would you think that as we go forward, inflation is going to star
componenttext: First question is, you made good progress on your cost per square foot since 2004, as housing rebounced something more normalized, would you expect cost per unit to continue to come down or would you think that as we go forward, inflation is going to start taking hold and we will see the cost start to rise again?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: James, I'll take that. And I think there's two things we benefited from. Obviously, with oil pricing coming down, our material cost have come down, particularly in I don't see that's going any lower. I think you will see some pressure as oil pricing comes
componenttext: James, I'll take that. And I think there's two things we benefited from. Obviously, with oil pricing coming down, our material cost have come down, particularly in I don't see that's going any lower. I think you will see some pressure as oil pricing comes up on that part of our cost curve. On the manufacturer -- the other manufacturing cost, I do think as we increase our utilization of our facilities that we will see cost reductions really across the board. In our OSB business, I think we were capacity.

componenttext: It was 89%.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: 89%. So we have a little bit more to go in OSB. In Siding, we're still filling out the demand from the Swan plant as it's not being fully utilized yet. And then in Engineered Wood, we have been significantly underutilizing our assets there. So I think you
componenttext: 89%. So we have a little bit more to go in OSB. In Siding, we're still filling out the demand from the Swan plant as it's not being fully utilized yet. And then in Engineered Wood, we have been significantly underutilizing our assets there. So I think you will see the manufacturing cost come down but you might see a slight rise in raw material cost. The other part of our cost is wood, and I don't see any significant pressure on the wood side.

In the Québec area, there has been articles that they have plenty of trees but no one's -- they can't harvest the logs because they can't sell the residuals. Would you ever -- are you restarting or and on that, do you have other mills where you can still add chips?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the residual is not an issue for us. How it becomes an issue is these are generally mixed stand. And so when you're logging, if you the mixed stand then you put the log in the right mill. So if Taking nobody's taking the log for lumber, then it makes i
componenttext: So the residual is not an issue for us. How it becomes an issue is these are generally mixed stand. And so when you're logging, if you the mixed stand then you put the log in the right mill. So if Taking nobody's taking the log for lumber, then it makes it most costly to get off the log for OSB. But we don't really have the problem selling residual. Yes, we are underutilized in We are running about 3.5 shifts there, so we can still add some production capacity there. In we have no plans to start that mill this year but we constantly evaluate where we think housing starts are from a demand and what that will lead for an OSB demand.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: I think it's probably, there are some environmental equipment upgrades we need to make. So I'm guessing it's a $6 million to $10 million cost and probably a 9-month period to bring that all up. The other thing I would say is, we don't currently have a wood license from the Québec government. That wood is not been reallocated to anyone else but we would have to procure the wood. There is enough private wood to run that at about 60% but to go beyond that, we would need to reacquire that wood price.

componenttextpreview: Creek, we are used to seeing OSB price declines flow through faster than OSB price hikes, is that what we're seeing this quarter? Should we be expecting more in Q3 the way things have gone? And related to that, for engineered wood, does that mean we shoul
componenttext: Creek, we are used to seeing OSB price declines flow through faster than OSB price hikes, is that what we're seeing this quarter? Should we be expecting more in Q3 the way things have gone? And related to that, for engineered wood, does that mean we should be expecting a fairly significant headwind in Engineered Wood Products in the third quarter?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're right. We see the decline before we see a -- more than we see the increase. I think what hurt us more than that timing of the -- of the increase is actually flooring. Pricing was very low. And we're the largest producer of commodity flooring. Be
componenttext: So you're right. We see the decline before we see a -- more than we see the increase. I think what hurt us more than that timing of the -- of the increase is actually flooring. Pricing was very low. And we're the largest producer of commodity flooring. Before I had more of an impact on the overall pricing but I think that timing in Q2. As far as the cost for engineered wood, I know we went out into the marketplace with an increase in our engineered wood pricing due to raw materials, being lumber and OSB.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And are you confident that the balance in that business is stronger than you was a year ago to try to -- to actually capture some of that?
componenttext: And are you confident that the balance in that business is stronger than you was a year ago to try to -- to actually capture some of that?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. As I said in my comments, engineered wood is heavily dependent on single-family. There is not a lot in the multi-panel So the increase in single-family helps engineered wood. And again, if there is duties put on from the softwood lumber agreem
componenttext: I think so. As I said in my comments, engineered wood is heavily dependent on single-family. There is not a lot in the multi-panel So the increase in single-family helps engineered wood. And again, if there is duties put on from the softwood lumber agreement, it raises the price of Canadian imports, that could have a positive impact on EWP.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Year-over-year, Mark, the utilization increased from 10 percentage points in our LVL capacity that went from say, around 55% or 54%  close to 53%, that's what's causing some of the improvement in the performance.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is on Siding. You did a good job recovering in the business this quarter as you added Swan Valley back into the system. Just wondering where you are from a capacity utilization standpoint with the transition and how much more room do you
componenttext: My first question is on Siding. You did a good job recovering in the business this quarter as you added Swan Valley back into the system. Just wondering where you are from a capacity utilization standpoint with the transition and how much more room do you have to pick market share in Siding as you look at over the next couple of quarters?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, with the incremental capital which gives us more flexibility to produce the right products in the right mill, which we're continuing to do. As I said in my comments, we think we have enough capacity within the Siding business to last us through the
componenttext: Well, with the incremental capital which gives us more flexibility to produce the right products in the right mill, which we're continuing to do. As I said in my comments, we think we have enough capacity within the Siding business to last us through the end of 2018 with that kind of 12% to 14% kind of growth rate in volumes. So we are not as I said in comment, we're not fully utilizing Swan at this point, and part of that is that equipment. we're limited in doing production in Swan today, and we need to add flexibility to do some other products in that mill and we have plans to do that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Just wanted to shift high-level. You talked about your executions on new housing. I if you can talk a little bit what you're seeing both the retail demand there as well as just generally the remodel side?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, on the retail side, the home centers reported increases of 6% to 7% on a same-store basis. Our first-half retail business was a little bit short of that, it was 4% to 5% on a volume basis. As we look to planning, we're kind of looking at that 4% to
componenttext: Well, on the retail side, the home centers reported increases of 6% to 7% on a same-store basis. Our first-half retail business was a little bit short of that, it was 4% to 5% on a volume basis. As we look to planning, we're kind of looking at that 4% to 6% kind of growth rate in the retail. We're not going to -- we don't believe we're going to see significant expansion beyond that.

componenttext: Couple of questions. First on the potential Siding expansion. If you're -- I apologize if you got if I missed it, but if you think you need this capacity by the end of 2018, and it could take up to 24 months, then should we expect a formal decision on exactly how you are going to proceed by the end of the year?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: It's probably not by the end of the year but we -- as I said, we got approval from our board on long lead time items, which we will be ordering in the next couple of months. And we also included in that request that we continue to do engineering so that we would have a much better estimate of what that would cost. If it's a new mill, you probably can anticipate in our board meeting is early part of February, we can probably anticipate an announcement after that if it's a new mill. If it's conversion of an existing mill, the time frame is much shorter than that. It's 9 months to do that conversion.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And I guess, just on that topic, can you just remind us what you see is your kind of competitive advantage in barriers to entries for others? Just try to kind of get into this given your ability to get double-digit growth?

componenttextpreview: Being up a little bit We paid a $1 billion in claims on siding in the '90s, which is I think has been somewhat of a deterrent to others getting into it. We did reformulate the product and we do have an exclusive with our supplier of [indiscernible]. We ha
componenttext: Being up a little bit We paid a $1 billion in claims on siding in the '90s, which is I think has been somewhat of a deterrent to others getting into it. We did reformulate the product and we do have an exclusive with our supplier of [indiscernible]. We have a exclusive with our supplier of the paper use in the product. And we've got years of experience in building or converting OSB mills and running mills. And then we have a sales force that's been selling this product since 1997.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And switching gears, the price gap between plywood and OSB, particular North Central has gone quite narrow. I think lowest levels we've seen in at least 3 years. And then there is some plywood capacity coming on as we expecting much release on the t
componenttext: Okay. And switching gears, the price gap between plywood and OSB, particular North Central has gone quite narrow. I think lowest levels we've seen in at least 3 years. And then there is some plywood capacity coming on as we expecting much release on the trade front. I'm just wondering any concerns that that might start to impact customer behavior and thought process?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't seen it to date. Our plywood is lower priced than OSB, then certainly builders are going to convert back to plywood. But we have not seen any reduction and expected demand for our product due to plywood pricing at this point.
componenttext: We haven't seen it to date. Our plywood is lower priced than OSB, then certainly builders are going to convert back to plywood. But we have not seen any reduction and expected demand for our product due to plywood pricing at this point.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we didn't see that in 2013.
componenttext: And we didn't see that in 2013.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
