headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to your host for today's c
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to your host for today's conference, Ms. Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Bridgette, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call today to discuss LP's financial results for the third quarter of 2016. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer. And with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's C
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Bridgette, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call today to discuss LP's financial results for the third quarter of 2016. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer. And with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; Brad Southern, LP's new Chief Operating Officer; as well as Mike Kinney and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contacts.
I'll begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the third quarter of 2016. This will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items. After I finish my remarks, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating, update you on his current thoughts on Siding expansion plans and the recently announced organizational change as well as give some thoughts on the outlook.
As we've done in the past, we've opened up this call to the public and we are doing a webcast. That webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. 
Additionally, to help with the discussion, we've provided in a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information as well as our 10-Q. 
I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation has some of the necessary reconciliations that's been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporate them with this reference.
We are reporting $111 million of adjusted EBITDA on just under $600 million of sales for the third quarter of 2016. The last time that LP reported adjusted EBITDA of over $100 million was the second quarter of 2013. Now in the last 12 quarters, LP's earnings profile has changed as we've grown our Siding segment. For the third quarter of 2016, Siding's percent of sales increased to 33% and the percent of adjusted EBITDA increased to over 30%. We do expect the percentage of sales and earnings from the Siding segment to continue to increase as a percent of the total as the Siding segment continues to grow. 
Now with that, let me go into the details. Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the third quarter and first 9 months of 2016 consolidated financial results. We are reporting net sales of $596 million for the third quarter of 2016, a 28% increase from the net sales of $465 million reported in the third quarter of 2015. In the third quarter, we recorded net income of $66 million or $0.45 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $27 million or $0.19 per diluted share in the third quarter of 2015. 
In the third quarter, we reported income tax benefit of $7.5 million. This benefit is primarily due to the recognition of research tax credit for the years 2003 to 2015 and the reversal of certain state and local tax valuation allowances. Excluding the impact of the research tax credit and the reversal of the state and local tax valuation allowances established in the second quarter, the company's annual GAAP tax rate for the third quarter would have been approximately 20%.
The adjusted income from continuing operations for the quarter was $47 million or $0.32 per diluted share based upon a normalized tax rate of 35% as compared to a loss of $16 million or a loss of $0.12 per share reported in the third quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $111 million for the quarter compared to $11 million in the third quarter of 2015.
In the first 9 months of 2016, we recorded net income of $108 million or $0.74 per diluted share on $1.7 billion in sales compared to a net loss for the first 9 months of 2015 of $81 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.57 on $1.4 billion in sales. The adjusted income for the 9-month period was $97 million or $0.67 per diluted share based upon the normalized tax rate of 35% compared to a loss of $47 million or a loss of $0.33 per diluted share for the first 9 months of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $262 million for the 9-month period in 2016 as compared to $33 million in the first 9 months of 2015.
Moving on to Slide 5 and a review of our segment results. Beginning with OSB. OSB reported net sales for the third quarter of 2016 of $282 million, up 41% from $200 million reported in the third quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $83 million compared to $4 million reported in the third quarter of 2015. Sales volumes were up 5%. Sales pricing was higher by 36%, which improved operating results by $75 million. Reduction in raw material costs and higher utilization rates also improved the third quarter 2016 results as compared to the third quarter of 2015. 
For the first 9 months of 2016, OSB reported sales of $752 million compared to $601 million of sales in the first 9 months of 2015. For the first 9 months, OSB reported adjusted EBITDA of $172 million as compared to negative adjusted EBITDA of $13 million in the first 9 months of 2015. Sales volumes were lower by 1%, and sales prices were higher by 27%. The impact of the higher sales price on OSB operations was $161 million in the first 9 months of 2016 compared to the same period in the last year. Reduction of raw material costs, higher utilization rates as well as a positive impact of the Canadian currencies on expenses incurred by our Canadian operations also improved the 9-month 2016 results as compared to the first 9 months of 2015. 
Slide 6 reports the results of the Siding business. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel siding products as well as minor amounts of OSB. Siding reported net sales for the third quarter of 2016 of $195 million, up 23% from $158 million in the third quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $42 million compared to $22 million in the third quarter of 2015. SmartSide volumes what up 25% from the prior year. SmartSide -- sales prices in SmartSide were up 1%, primarily due to changes in product mix, with individual prices remaining relatively flat. 
The Siding segment reported sales of $583 million in the first 9 months of 2016, an increase of 18% from $495 million reported in the first 9 months of 2015. Siding segment reported adjusted EBITDA of $125 million as compared to $95 million in the same period of 2015. SmartSide sales volumes were up 15% for the first 9 months of 2016 compared to the same period in 2015, with sales prices down 1% for SmartSide. 
Please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results of our Engineered Wood Products segment. This segment includes I-Joist, Laminated Strand Lumber, Laminated Veneer Lumber, OSB produced at our Houlton, Maine facility plus other related products. This segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture or under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. The Engineered Wood Products segment recorded sales of $81 million in the third quarter of 2016, up from $74 million in the third quarter of 2015. For the third quarter of 2016, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations improved by $1 million as compared to the third quarter of 2015. Volumes of I-Joist were up 1% while volumes of LVL and LSL were up 9% compared to the same quarter of last year. Pricing increased 2% in LVL, LSL and I-Joist. 
For the first 9 months, sales were $231 million, up from $211 million in 2015. And adjusted EBITDA improved to $9 million from $3 million in the first 9 months of 2015. 
Moving on to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded sales of $32 million as compared to $27 million in the third quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA of $6 million was higher by $2 million as compared to the third quarter of 2015. Volumes in Chile were down 3% and down 9% in Brazil compared to the same quarter of last year. On a U.S. dollar basis, pricing was up 13% in Chile and up 10% in Brazil. In local currency, Chile's pricing was up 10% compared with the same quarter in 2015 and Brazil's pricing was flat. 
For the first 9 months, our South American segment recorded sales of $103 million as compared to $101 million in the first 9 months of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA for the first 9 months of 2016 increased to $22 million from $13 million in the same period in 2015.
Total selling, general and administrative costs were $47 million in the third quarter of 2016 compared to $38 million in the same quarter of 2015. For the 9-month period, our selling, general and administrative costs are $136 million for 2016 compared to $115 million for the first 9 months of 2015. For both the quarter and 9-month period, the increase on these costs was primarily due to increases in certain management incentive and higher costs associated with sales and marketing.
Turning to the balance sheet. We announced 2 transactions in the third quarter which impacted our balance sheet. During the quarter, we refinanced our $350 million senior unsecured notes with an interest rate of 7.5% due 2020 with new senior unsecured notes which carry a 4 7/8% interest rate and will mature in 2024. This transaction will decrease our annual interest expense by approximately $9 million on an annual basis. 
We also announced during the quarter that we have entered into agreement to provide for the acceleration of $410 million of notes receivable from asset sales. At the same time, we gave binding notice the pay off $369 million of related notes payable. This transaction will be completed tomorrow. As a result of the transaction, LP will accelerate the receipt of $41 million of cash. This will also accelerate the income taxes of $121 million associated with the gain on the sale of timber in 2003. We anticipate offsetting much of the accelerated income tax with available carryover benefits. 
Please turn to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of September 30, 2016, we had cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $673 million including the cash held for bond redemption or $580 million excluding that cash held for the bond redemption; working capital of $793 million; net cash of $225 million. In addition to the $580 million of cash on our balance sheet, we have $200 million of availability on our credit facility. 
We are projecting the capital expenditures for 2016 will be in the $115 million to $125 million range. For 2017, we are planning on spending approximately $140 million of capital. This estimate includes $40 million for our South American operations but does not include any capital to convert or build a new siding mill. 
We also anticipate beginning to pay cash taxes in the U.S. in 2017. The U.S. represents approximately 70% to 75% of our net income -- of our income before taxes. We don't anticipate paying cash taxes in Canada due to net operating loss carryovers. The benefit amount of our available Canadian net operating losses was $64 million at the end of 2015. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Curt.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sallie. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on today's call. Before I begin my remarks, I do want to acknowledge the passing last week of Harry Merlo, LP's first and longest-serving Chief Executive Officer. While Harry was often a controver
componenttext:
Thank you, Sallie. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on today's call. Before I begin my remarks, I do want to acknowledge the passing last week of Harry Merlo, LP's first and longest-serving Chief Executive Officer. While Harry was often a controversial leader, there is no doubt that he was instrumental in introducing OSB to the world and promoting the vision of OSB-based siding. 
I will start with our safety performance. Through the first 9 months of this year, our total incident rate or TIR was at 0.39, and this was also the rolling 12-month TIR. We are on track for our second-best safety year ever. One recent highlight, our Panguipulli mill in Chile, last week, achieved 1.5 million hours without a recordable injury, a remarkable achievement. The safety of our employees is LP's core value, and I continue to be extremely proud of all of our employees who support this view and act accordingly. 
Today, I'll be providing comments on our results and accomplishments in the quarter, provide a little more background to the transaction we announced last Friday with Norbord, discuss the promotion of Brad Southern to Chief Operating Officer and give you my views on the outlook for the rest of this year and into 2017. I know Sallie just went through our financial results in detail, but I do want to talk about a few items because it feels so good. 
Total sales in Q3 were 28% higher than Q3 of last year and produced net income of $66 million or EPS of $0.45. For the fourth consecutive quarter, all of our business segments recorded positive EBITDA, and that totaled $111 million for the company in Q3. In Siding, our big growth business, our revenue grew 23% versus the same quarter of last year and adjusted EBITDA was at $42 million. On a year-to-date basis, our sales were up 18%, net income is $108 million and adjusted EBITDA, as Sallie said, was $262 million. 
Let me discuss the mill swap with Norbord. As I did mention last quarter, we continue to explore options to building a greenfield mill in Minnesota as the foundation for our next siding expansion. Last Friday, both LP and Norbord issued press releases that described the mill swap between our 2 companies. Let me explain the rationale from LP's perspective and our preliminary plans going forward. 
LP's Chambord mill has been indefinitely curtailed since 2008, the beginning of the downturn. Norbord's Val-d'Or mill has been curtailed since 2012. While curtailed, both mills had a skeleton crew, who maintained the equipment in the shortest time necessary for a future startup. When assessing the facilities as potential siding mills, we had earlier determined that Chambord did not have ready access to the right wood species, aspen, to make a quality siding product. However, Val-d'Or is an area where there is an abundance of aspen. 
A complicating factor for both companies as we think about restarting these mills is the actions taken by the Québec government in the last 2 years to terminate the wood licenses for both mills due to a lack of cutting activity. A first priority for us is to work with the Québec government to obtain an appropriate wood allocation to run the Val-d'Or facility. To that end, I have had initial conversations with the chiefs of staff in both the premier's and the forestry minister's offices in Québec. 
As I said in the last call, the timing for additional siding capacity is near the end of 2018. For a new mill, the permitting, construction and start-up period is likely to be 24 to 30 months. With an existing mill, we believe that the conversion can take place in less than half that time. Upon closing later this week, we will immediately begin the engineering assessment to determine the cost and timing of such a project. 
In addition to the swap of Chambord for Val-d'Or, we also acquired a former Ainsworth OSB site located in Cook, Minnesota during the last quarter. This will allow us, again, to further expand siding at the appropriate time. I'm very pleased with this result, and this will allow us to continue to work with the very supportive Minnesota elected officials in the IRRRB that -- to redirect the incentives to a size that we believe is better suited from a site development infrastructure perspective than the proposed Hoyt Lakes site. 
Last Thursday, I did speak to Governor Dayton, Senator Bakk, House Speaker Daudt and U.S. Representative Nolan, and they all pledged their support for this future project. We have not yet finalized the accounting implication of this transaction as we are waiting on third-party appraisals of the assets involved. However, we do not believe this will be material. More to come as we make progress with our discussions with the Québec government regarding the wood allocation, reengage with Minnesota officials on the incentives, and begin the engineering assessment at both Val-d'Or and the Cook, Minnesota sites. 
Last Friday, our Board of Directors did elect Brad Southern to a newly created position of Chief Operating Officer. Many of you have met Brad as he's been a regular participant at investor conferences and also was at the Analyst Day we hosted last year in Two Harbors. Brad joined LP in 1999 as the Controller of our Specialty business. Over the next few years, he moved into increasingly complex operating roles. In 2004, Brad became the General Manager of the Siding business. In that role, he was the primary architect of the segment strategy that we've put in place during the housing downturn to focus on repair, remodeling, nonresidential structures and retail, in addition to new home construction. In March of 2015, Brad took over the OSB business and has been instrumental in improving our operating performance and logistics. By the way, along the way, Brad was also the executive sponsor of our successful SAP implementation in 2013. 
In this new role, Brad will maintain direct responsibility for the OSB business and will have the general managers of Siding and EWP report to him, along with our senior VP of sales and marketing and the VP of manufacturing services. Brad will remain the Chairman of the Board of our LP South America operation. 
The elevation of Brad to this new role is part of an ongoing succession planning process that our board has had in place for many years. You may recall that I moved from CFO to COO (sic) [ CEO ] about 5 years ago. I am not retiring anytime soon, and I also will not speculate on when that time might come. As the LP board has done in the past, we are making sure that we have qualified internal successors to assume leadership in all of our key roles when the time comes. I'm very pleased to have Brad in this position as his experience will be invaluable as we continue to take advantage of an improving housing market. 
Let me talk about the housing market. Q3 housing starts were basically flat for both Q2 of this year and to Q3 of last year. However, the mix between multifamily and single family moved in our favor, with single family growing at 8% while multi-family declined slightly. Also, as permits are a leading indicator, we are pleased to see an increase of over 6% to 1.23 million in the September results. With 1 quarter to go, the consensus for 2016 housing starts now stands at 1.174, a relatively slight 6% increase from last year. For next year, the current consensus is 1.272, an 8% increase over this year's forecast. 
There have been some other positive housing-related data released recently. New home sales, August is the last reported period, were up 20.5% compared to August of 2015. Existing inventory of single-family homes fell to 2.04 million, 10% below August of last year. 
On the financing side, the average 30-year fixed mortgage rates were largely unchanged compared to last quarter at 3.47% for the week ended October 14. Retail sales for building materials, garden equipment and supply dealers were about 1.5% higher than Q2. 
In Canada, third quarter starts were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of a little over 200,000, about a 1% increase from the second quarter and down about 5.5% from Q3 of last year. As I mentioned, the current forecast for 2016 shows 6% growth in housing starts, almost all of this from single family. For 2017, we should see demand for housing continue to increase, driven primarily by increased household formations and wage growth. However, because of numerous constraints, labor, adequate lots, regulatory costs and timing, I think that the growth rate in housing will once again be between 5% and 10%. We will likely see a trend towards starter homes as the first-time homebuyer appears to be coming back. 
I recently attended the Policy Advisory Board meeting of the Harvard Joint Center for Housing Studies. Among other presentations at the meeting, they did provide their forecast for household formations for the next 20 years based on demographics and, immigration, and their forecast of future home ownership rates. For household formation, this group is forecasting 13.6 million net new households in the period 2015 through 2025 and 12.4 million net new households in the next 10-year period. Coupled with household removals due to demolition, catastrophe or conversion plus second home, this is good news for the housing industry. 
On homeownership, they concluded they could go up or down from the current 62%. The low end of the range was 61%, and their high end was 64.5%. Also at the meeting, the Harvard group reaffirmed their forecast that growth in repair, remodeling expenditures should continue at about 4% for the next several years. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Sallie for questions.

componenttext: I'm just curious. In your comments about Cook and Val-d'Or and that sort of 24- to 36-month time frame to kind of start up a new mill, should we assume that you're going to move first on Val-d'Or? Is that really what you're saying?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that would be my preference. As I mentioned, the difficulty there is we don't have an adequate wood supply. So we have to be cognizant of working with the Québec government how long that might take and look at our options. So that's why we're doing
componenttext: Well, that would be my preference. As I mentioned, the difficulty there is we don't have an adequate wood supply. So we have to be cognizant of working with the Québec government how long that might take and look at our options. So that's why we're doing the assessments at both facilities. But obviously, converting an existing facility is cheaper and faster.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And can you just help us, from kind of a cost standpoint, how the 2 projects would compare?
componenttext: Okay. And can you just help us, from kind of a cost standpoint, how the 2 projects would compare?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in the Val-d'Or case, the conversion cost would be somewhere between what we spent in Hayward, which is about $60 million, and what we spent at Maniwaki -- not Maniwaki, in Swan Valley, which was about $85 million. So it's somewhere in that $60 mill
componenttext: Well, in the Val-d'Or case, the conversion cost would be somewhere between what we spent in Hayward, which is about $60 million, and what we spent at Maniwaki -- not Maniwaki, in Swan Valley, which was about $85 million. So it's somewhere in that $60 million to $85 million range would be my guess. On a new plant -- again, having an existing site that has the infrastructure will reduce that cost. There is some equipment there, although a lot of the equipment has been sold. And we would think about repurposing equipment that we own elsewhere in North America. But the number is probably going to be somewhere 275 to 300 for base OSB, and then you're going to have the same conversion cost to turn it into Siding.

And if we were to do something at the Cook site, my guess is that would be a 400 million kind of capacity mill given the equipment that we have already existing in North America.

componenttext: I can't. We have approved the project. We approved that at the July meeting. We have acquired about $15 million worth of the equipment. Most of that is either on site or on its way down, and we have started the site preparation. So that's where we are now.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if we think, Curt, about CapEx for '17, I know you put out that $140 million number, but you said that doesn't include anything on Siding. So should we -- could we assume that if you move ahead with  Val-d'Or that, that number is $30 million to
componenttext: Okay. And if we think, Curt, about CapEx for '17, I know you put out that $140 million number, but you said that doesn't include anything on Siding. So should we -- could we assume that if you move ahead with  Val-d'Or that, that number is $30 million to $40 million higher?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think you can assume that yet because if we do Val-d'Or, we don't need the capacity until kind of the fourth quarter of 2018. Most of that work would actually be spent -- or the money would be spent towards the end of 2017 into '18, but I don't ha
componenttext: I don't think you can assume that yet because if we do Val-d'Or, we don't need the capacity until kind of the fourth quarter of 2018. Most of that work would actually be spent -- or the money would be spent towards the end of 2017 into '18, but I don't have a good handle on that yet. I mean we've been in the mill a very short amount of time, so we still have a pretty significant engineering evaluation to complete.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And finally, just with this clarity on Siding, which I think is great, can you just update us on your Engineered Wood business and how you're thinking about that? Your margins are still running pretty low in that business. And I guess I'm
componenttext: Okay. All right. And finally, just with this clarity on Siding, which I think is great, can you just update us on your Engineered Wood business and how you're thinking about that? Your margins are still running pretty low in that business. And I guess I'm also just curious, with sort of clearer runway now in Siding, whether that changes your view of the engineered wood business.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say a couple of things. One, I'd just remind you on the margins. Because we looked at the competitive margins between us and Boise and Weyerhaeuser who just reported, and our margins for our manufactured products are pretty much right on top of
componenttext: Well, I'd say a couple of things. One, I'd just remind you on the margins. Because we looked at the competitive margins between us and Boise and Weyerhaeuser who just reported, and our margins for our manufactured products are pretty much right on top of theirs. The difficulty you get is Weyerhaeuser looks like they're reporting it coming out of distribution not as a pure manufacturing play. But the reminder is, the JV, we sell 100% of the product but we only get half of the margin out of that. And then whatever we sell from Murphy Plywood into the West and into export markets, we only get a sales margin on that. So when you look at -- and we don't have the outset base, so we'd have spent the capital but our margins look lower. The good news in Q3 is that what's been a drag on this business for some period of time is when we converted the Houlton mill into Laminated Strand Lumber, and we had the best volumes in Laminated Strand Lumber in the third quarter than we've ever had. And actually, that mill was EBITDA positive for the first time, I think, ever since -- well, since we've converted it. So we have good momentum on the LSL side. That will continue. And then the second thing I would say is we did have the Forest Economic advisory guys in here, and they continue to say that we're going to see a shortage of LVL as the housing starts get towards 1.4 million, which leads us to believe that, that's probably a business that we ought to continue to hold on to, to take advantage of the market when it does come back. That is a market that is heavily tied to single-family new construction. And as that becomes a greater part of the housing starts or actually happening, plus housing starts grow, we think that we will get that business back into the profitable region that we had -- we enjoyed in 2003 and 2004.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Gail Glazerman with Roe Equity Research.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to the Siding expansion. Would there -- assuming you can get the wood license from the government, would there actually be potential at that site for further expansion beyond the existing capacity?
componenttext: Going back to the Siding expansion. Would there -- assuming you can get the wood license from the government, would there actually be potential at that site for further expansion beyond the existing capacity?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- again, Gail, I think we have to complete the engineering evaluation. We have done that at 2 of our smaller mills, which used to be bigger than those mills but less than the Swan. And ways you can expand that is you could add extra platens to th
componenttext: I think -- again, Gail, I think we have to complete the engineering evaluation. We have done that at 2 of our smaller mills, which used to be bigger than those mills but less than the Swan. And ways you can expand that is you could add extra platens to the press to get a little more capacity. We did that at Two Harbors, increased capacity by 35%. And then at Tomahawk, we added platens to increase that capacity by 50%. So that would -- may be an opportunity, but I don't have the engineering expertise to answer that right now.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I presume there are no restrictions in terms of the transfer -- the swap agreement with Norbord and how you use that site. So if you chose not to go ahead with Siding, in theory, it would still be an option for OSB?
componenttext: Okay. And I presume there are no restrictions in terms of the transfer -- the swap agreement with Norbord and how you use that site. So if you chose not to go ahead with Siding, in theory, it would still be an option for OSB?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are no restrictions in it either way.
componenttext: There are no restrictions in it either way.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then just switching gears. Can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the OSB market, specifically maybe some of the price gaps? Last quarter, you talked about the gap between commodity and flooring. And then also, just in the re
componenttext: All right. And then just switching gears. Can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the OSB market, specifically maybe some of the price gaps? Last quarter, you talked about the gap between commodity and flooring. And then also, just in the recent weeks, there's been incremental pressure in Western Canada that we're not necessarily seeing in other regions.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the quarter, it was a little bit -- from a regional pricing, it's pretty much a mirror of Q2. I don't think we saw any big differences between how the market reacted in Q3 than in Q2. What you saw is a little weakness at the beginning of the quarter, t
componenttext: In the quarter, it was a little bit -- from a regional pricing, it's pretty much a mirror of Q2. I don't think we saw any big differences between how the market reacted in Q3 than in Q2. What you saw is a little weakness at the beginning of the quarter, then it strengthened. I think a couple of things I would say is that the market is -- was so tight from a demand capacity that any anomaly that happened in the market would drive pricing up, then it would kind of drift back down, then we'd have another event and it would drive pricing back up. And that's kind of what we saw. I've been actually encouraged that October hasn't come off much because, historically, you would see pricing coming off on the fourth quarter. And I think random is only down in a single region last week and flat in the other ones, and that's been kind of the case the last couple of weeks.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And just wondering, anything specific that you sense driving the weakness in Western Canada of late? And then also, just if you could touch on the flooring versus commodity. Do you feel that -- is that what you were saying mirrors kind of recent tren
componenttext: Yes. And just wondering, anything specific that you sense driving the weakness in Western Canada of late? And then also, just if you could touch on the flooring versus commodity. Do you feel that -- is that what you were saying mirrors kind of recent trends?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Western Canada, we did have a capacity come online with the [indiscernible]. That has been ramping up. So I think that's been a little bit of a drag on the pricing.
componenttext: Well, Western Canada, we did have a capacity come online with the [indiscernible]. That has been ramping up. So I think that's been a little bit of a drag on the pricing.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And was there any impacts either in terms of operations, wood supply or customer demand from the hurricane?
componenttext: Okay. And was there any impacts either in terms of operations, wood supply or customer demand from the hurricane?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. You would probably saw, and I can't even tell you for your sure whether we did, but we might have seen a little bit of incremental demand from the box stores. But it take so long for the money to flow through the system for rebuilding. We're still dea
componenttext: No. You would probably saw, and I can't even tell you for your sure whether we did, but we might have seen a little bit of incremental demand from the box stores. But it take so long for the money to flow through the system for rebuilding. We're still dealing with Sandy, we're probably getting benefits from Sandy not from Matthew.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I was thinking that there might be building sites that didn't work. I just one last one, as you look at the softwood lumber agreement and potential for trade action. Last quarter, you talked about maybe potential demand for engineered wood from [ind
componenttext: Okay. I was thinking that there might be building sites that didn't work. I just one last one, as you look at the softwood lumber agreement and potential for trade action. Last quarter, you talked about maybe potential demand for engineered wood from [indiscernible]. So if you could just give any further and also any risk to what caused in Canada?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would respond in a couple of ways. One, I was a little bit surprised by the strength of West Fraser and Campor's earnings. I'll think a lot of that is they shipped a lot of lumber in the U.S. and benefited from the low Canadian currency and shipped t
componenttext: So I would respond in a couple of ways. One, I was a little bit surprised by the strength of West Fraser and Campor's earnings. I'll think a lot of that is they shipped a lot of lumber in the U.S. and benefited from the low Canadian currency and shipped that lumber into the U.S. And if we do have trade duties in the 25% to 30% level that will go in plays next year, that will probably limit the amount that comes from Canada. So I think that was an impact that we saw on the Q3, the earnings were very good. As far as the impacts on engineered wood, I still believe that you had 30% cost to the Canadian lumber, that we should have some benefit in I-Joist and LDL. But we didn't see anything in the third quarter. We're not anticipating for the duties actions actually being collected until probably early in the second quarter of next year.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any risk to your fiber supply up in Canada?
componenttext: And any risk to your fiber supply up in Canada?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. We buy a different fiber than the lumber guys. We buy primarily hardwood. But the only impact we've had in the past is like with the beetle kill, if you're doing a mixed stand, it becomes a little more expensive to log it. But other
componenttext: No, I don't think so. We buy a different fiber than the lumber guys. We buy primarily hardwood. But the only impact we've had in the past is like with the beetle kill, if you're doing a mixed stand, it becomes a little more expensive to log it. But other than that, I think it should be very minimal.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from George Staphos with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from George Staphos with Bank of America.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick things. First of all, back to the ability to hold onto Engineered Wood Products as you're looking towards 1.4, 1.5 start-type of environment. Do you think you have enough the near capacity to keep up with that level of demand, recog
componenttext: Just a couple of quick things. First of all, back to the ability to hold onto Engineered Wood Products as you're looking towards 1.4, 1.5 start-type of environment. Do you think you have enough the near capacity to keep up with that level of demand, recognize that maybe prices on products would move up. How do you think, Curt, your margin cost would hold up in the environment? Second question that I had, just in terms of working capital, it looks like a relatively good quarter here. Could you remind us what might have been going on in the quarter in terms of working capital for LPX? And then I have quick follow on.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me address the veneer demand, I'll let Sallie talk about working capital. On the veneer demand, we only create our own veneer on one facility, that's in Golden, B.C. And we have forestry licenses in there for the next 25 years. So I don't have any con
componenttext: Let me address the veneer demand, I'll let Sallie talk about working capital. On the veneer demand, we only create our own veneer on one facility, that's in Golden, B.C. And we have forestry licenses in there for the next 25 years. So I don't have any concern about the near demand in British Columbia. We have very good wood supply and a very good 10 years there. And in the case of Murphy plywood, Murphy creates their own veneer. So he's not on the open market. So he has plywood operations, so he provides them. So as long as we have that manufacturing arrangement, again I don't get too concerned about a veneer availability on the West Coast. The one facility we would have a risk from a veneer standpoint is in Wilmington, North Carolina. But we've had long-term supply agreements with a number of plywood producers there. I think that it would be more of a cost than it will be on unavailability. I think we're probably okay, but that would be the one I would look at as the most at-risk because we don't control the veneer.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. But you think that. . .
componenttext: Right. But you think that. . .

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also, I hasten that on the East Coast, that's where we have our laminated strand facility and we do have wood supply for that.
componenttext: Also, I hasten that on the East Coast, that's where we have our laminated strand facility and we do have wood supply for that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough on that one.
componenttext: Fair enough on that one.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, George, in terms of working capital as OSB becomes a bigger piece of our working capital, the day sales outstanding on OSB are shorter than the other 2 businesses. So that is reflected pretty clearly and the improvements and the cash conversio
componenttext: So I think, George, in terms of working capital as OSB becomes a bigger piece of our working capital, the day sales outstanding on OSB are shorter than the other 2 businesses. So that is reflected pretty clearly and the improvements and the cash conversion cycle over at the DSO. And likewise, as we spend more money on capital, we tend to see more money that's in capital and accounts payable. So that's the biggest drivers. Along [indiscernible], 4 of our general managers really are continuing to take focus on inventory and making sure that we have inventory that at the right levels, given the demand going on in the market. So we've seen a slight decrease in inventories in the third quarter.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Most of my questions were already asked. But one quick thing on EWP again, Curt, if you would. To the extent that we look at your results versus other players and recognizing their moving parts and directly comparable results are probably difficult
componenttext: Okay. Most of my questions were already asked. But one quick thing on EWP again, Curt, if you would. To the extent that we look at your results versus other players and recognizing their moving parts and directly comparable results are probably difficult to get at. How do you think your shares are doing within engineered wood relative to your peers? Do you think you're maintaining, growing, losing and to the extent you can comment, why would that be your view?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our growth rate and volume sales was about the same as the industry, it wasn't that far off. The big market share gain into Q3 and actually Q2 as well was when Boise bought GPs. So you combined the GP market share into the Boise numbers. Although on th
componenttext: So our growth rate and volume sales was about the same as the industry, it wasn't that far off. The big market share gain into Q3 and actually Q2 as well was when Boise bought GPs. So you combined the GP market share into the Boise numbers. Although on their call, they talked about that one plus one wasn't 2. They were not able to retain a lot of that business and I think last quarter I talked about a lot of the churn that was going on where the consolidation we saw in the pro dealers, with some changes we made in Canada in our distribution and with the acquisition of GP by Boise, a lot of that business is up in the air. So want[ph] a little bit -- we probably won more than we've lost, but I wouldn't say it's a market shift between any of the 3 major players at this point. What I would say is that the Canadian -- the smaller Canadian producers are taking more market share at I-Joist. And that's certainly true for us, there's a price environment up there and we are just not choosing to play in.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curt and Sallie, first question. Curt, you said that the base OSB to put that in at, say, 400 million square feet would be around, I think, you said 275 to 300,000 at Cook. Now there is existing equipment, if he didn't have existing equipment, how much wo
componenttext: Curt and Sallie, first question. Curt, you said that the base OSB to put that in at, say, 400 million square feet would be around, I think, you said 275 to 300,000 at Cook. Now there is existing equipment, if he didn't have existing equipment, how much would that cost be? In other words, how much do you save by both using their equipment and repurposing some of your own?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the last few OSB mills that have been built are roughly 325 per 1000. And I haven't heard a number on but I'm guessing that, that number is about the same. But the 2 grant mills in South Carolina that now GP owns, [indiscernible] and Alabama and the jo
componenttext: So the last few OSB mills that have been built are roughly 325 per 1000. And I haven't heard a number on but I'm guessing that, that number is about the same. But the 2 grant mills in South Carolina that now GP owns, [indiscernible] and Alabama and the joint venture mill in Peace Valley were all in the 3 10 to 3 25 kind of range.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: And there were slew of plants shutdown in fact other Polax/Earth change ones, in that famed area and a lot of others that were shut down I guess in '06 and '07. And so what are you suggesting, I guess, is that a lot of these facilities, you would have to
componenttext: And there were slew of plants shutdown in fact other Polax/Earth change ones, in that famed area and a lot of others that were shut down I guess in '06 and '07. And so what are you suggesting, I guess, is that a lot of these facilities, you would have to spend maybe 80% of what you would spend to get them back to running again as much as you would spend on a new mill. In other words, that's why might it be worth even building these things or starting them because you'd have to go ahead and build a whole new mill and maybe want to start from scratch anyway. Does that make sense?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in a lot of ways, it does because you can have the newest technology. But the advantage for Cook for it's in the same region where the Lakeside site was. It's a good aspen basket, we have the incentives both from the operating standpoint and
componenttext: Well, I think in a lot of ways, it does because you can have the newest technology. But the advantage for Cook for it's in the same region where the Lakeside site was. It's a good aspen basket, we have the incentives both from the operating standpoint and some of the construction cost. And the Cook side already got rail to it, it's already got a woodyard. We have you been using that woodyard for the last couple of years as a satellite yard to our other mills in the area. So it's got logistics, it's got good labor force in the area. So there's some really advantages to using that site rather than you starting with a piece of raw land. I'll just give you an example. At the [indiscernible] site, we figured it was going to cost us $30 million to bring the rail in and that included building a track along the river, dealing with wetlands, putting the track in. And we won't have to spend that now.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Shifting gears a little bit, Sallie, that was a great rundown about the whole timber unwind. And so it looks like, obviously, you make $41 million in cash but that you're going to give some of that up and maybe all of it in terms of the deferr
componenttext: Understood. Shifting gears a little bit, Sallie, that was a great rundown about the whole timber unwind. And so it looks like, obviously, you make $41 million in cash but that you're going to give some of that up and maybe all of it in terms of the deferred taxes being paid. And you did mention that on that 1 21, a bit of it will be offset by carryovers, and I know we can kind of make you guess looking at the K from last year. But can you just give us a rough ballpark? I mean, do you think half of that 1 21? Or is it 2/3 or 1/3? What would be kind of ballpark that?

componenttext: Okay. Okay, so we should basically think that this thing is going to cost you $10 million, that you'll use the 70 and your cash taxes are 50, then you get 41 from unwinding the receivable, payable. So your net cost is $10 million.

componenttext: This is Scott for Mark. Two questions, the first, in the third quarter how much of the rise in OSB prices hit your engineered wood business? And is that a fairly normal amount? And what are your thoughts on the fourth quarter assuming OSB prices hold where they are?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

componenttext: It was relatively small amount. It's probably between $1 million and $1.5 million. And part of the offset to that is we did sell some OSB out of Houlton, [indiscernible] was probably right around $1 million negative impact.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Houlton's in that segment?
componenttext: And Houlton's in that segment?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you, okay. And then just looking at the idle OSB capacity that's out there in North America right now. How much of that capacity do you think might, ultimately, restart if housing was a little bit stronger than we are experiencing now?
componenttext: Got you, okay. And then just looking at the idle OSB capacity that's out there in North America right now. How much of that capacity do you think might, ultimately, restart if housing was a little bit stronger than we are experiencing now?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that as the rule of thumb, and I talked about this before, it's about 1.1 billion square feet of demand for every 100,000 housing starts. So if you think we're going to have 80,000 housing starts, there's going to be demand of roughly 900 mi
componenttext: Well, I think that as the rule of thumb, and I talked about this before, it's about 1.1 billion square feet of demand for every 100,000 housing starts. So if you think we're going to have 80,000 housing starts, there's going to be demand of roughly 900 million square feet, they're going to need on top of that. And I haven't seen the industry numbers, but I've seen what warehouse are running, they're running at 102% of capacity in the third quarter and I think Norbord was in the high 90s. We were on the low-90s. And now with this swap, we are going, if you Chambord took, that number would be even higher percentage. So I think there's a lot of available capacity to satisfy that increase 800,000 to 900,000 square feet of demand next year. So we will need some additional restarts or new mills. And as you know, the [indiscernible] mill is slated to start up sometime second half of next year, I don't think it will have a big impact on 2017, but it will on 2018. And then for us, we don't have anything to start unless we start Val-d'Or up as an OSB mill since Chambord is not in our portfolio any longer. And then our competitors, I did read the Norbord transcript and I think their first priority is going to be in the [indiscernible] mill to satisfy demand in the Southeast, Southwest.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Bill Hoffmann with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Bill Hoffmann with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curt, can you talk a little bit about the Cook site? Is there any possibility that you would put OSB capacity in there? And is the fiber basket successful for that?
componenttext: Curt, can you talk a little bit about the Cook site? Is there any possibility that you would put OSB capacity in there? And is the fiber basket successful for that?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you certainly can use aspen for OSB. So there's no -- think about fiber supply that will preclude you from doing that. It's really the intention is to make that as a siding facility. But one of the things you heard me say is, I don't mind being earl
componenttext: Well, you certainly can use aspen for OSB. So there's no -- think about fiber supply that will preclude you from doing that. It's really the intention is to make that as a siding facility. But one of the things you heard me say is, I don't mind being early with siding capacity because I can run always OSB until the siding fills it out. So an example when we start at Swan Valley, we're running that as a siding mill, but we converted one of the lines in Hayward back to OSB. And so that's every month, we're making less and less OSB to make more siding. And that's exactly what we would probably do it both at Val-d'Or during the conversion and add an additional mill in Cook.

So we've got some pretty exciting things that we're trying to explore internally before we either do share repurchase or dividend.

componenttext: I have reviewed their transcript and I think Peter did say something about not entering the siding market in the near term. I hate to speculate they might do. As you know, we have 20 year history in siding, we have early words in meetings around siding. We haven't had anything in the last 15 years, it's been a great product with a great warranty history. We do have 140 trained sales people in the field, selling that. We've got our marketing team that's probably 15 or 20 people. It would take a lot for somebody to compete against us as at siding, more much more than just being able to manufacture the product. As far as where we're seeing growth, home centers were relatively flat with this -- with the import supply wood coming in from Chile and Brazil, we did see some aggressive pricing on T1 11 Siding in the boxes, which I think probably heard our panel Siding a little bit. But we've been pretty flat in there. So most growth we've seen has been in the repair remodel side with the prefinishers. And we've seen growth rate in single-family new constructions.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to your host for today's c
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Louisiana-Pacific Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the call over to your host for today's conference, Ms. Sallie Bailey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Bridgette, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call today to discuss LP's financial results for the third quarter of 2016. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer. And with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's C
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Bridgette, and good morning. Thank you for joining our conference call today to discuss LP's financial results for the third quarter of 2016. I am Sallie Bailey, LP's Chief Financial Officer. And with me today are Curt Stevens, LP's Chief Executive Officer; Brad Southern, LP's new Chief Operating Officer; as well as Mike Kinney and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contacts.
I'll begin the discussion with a review of the financial results for the third quarter of 2016. This will be followed by some comments on the performance of the individual segments and selected balance sheet items. After I finish my remarks, Curt will discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating, update you on his current thoughts on Siding expansion plans and the recently announced organizational change as well as give some thoughts on the outlook.
As we've done in the past, we've opened up this call to the public and we are doing a webcast. That webcast can be accessed at www.lpcorp.com. 
Additionally, to help with the discussion, we've provided in a presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I will be referencing these slides in my comments this morning. We filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information as well as our 10-Q. 
I want to remind all the participants about the forward-looking statements comment on Slide 2 of the presentation. Please also be aware of the discussion of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached to the presentation has some of the necessary reconciliations that's been supplemented by the Form 8-K filing we made this morning. Rather than reading these 2 statements, I incorporate them with this reference.
We are reporting $111 million of adjusted EBITDA on just under $600 million of sales for the third quarter of 2016. The last time that LP reported adjusted EBITDA of over $100 million was the second quarter of 2013. Now in the last 12 quarters, LP's earnings profile has changed as we've grown our Siding segment. For the third quarter of 2016, Siding's percent of sales increased to 33% and the percent of adjusted EBITDA increased to over 30%. We do expect the percentage of sales and earnings from the Siding segment to continue to increase as a percent of the total as the Siding segment continues to grow. 
Now with that, let me go into the details. Moving to Slide 4 of the presentation for a discussion of the third quarter and first 9 months of 2016 consolidated financial results. We are reporting net sales of $596 million for the third quarter of 2016, a 28% increase from the net sales of $465 million reported in the third quarter of 2015. In the third quarter, we recorded net income of $66 million or $0.45 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $27 million or $0.19 per diluted share in the third quarter of 2015. 
In the third quarter, we reported income tax benefit of $7.5 million. This benefit is primarily due to the recognition of research tax credit for the years 2003 to 2015 and the reversal of certain state and local tax valuation allowances. Excluding the impact of the research tax credit and the reversal of the state and local tax valuation allowances established in the second quarter, the company's annual GAAP tax rate for the third quarter would have been approximately 20%.
The adjusted income from continuing operations for the quarter was $47 million or $0.32 per diluted share based upon a normalized tax rate of 35% as compared to a loss of $16 million or a loss of $0.12 per share reported in the third quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $111 million for the quarter compared to $11 million in the third quarter of 2015.
In the first 9 months of 2016, we recorded net income of $108 million or $0.74 per diluted share on $1.7 billion in sales compared to a net loss for the first 9 months of 2015 of $81 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.57 on $1.4 billion in sales. The adjusted income for the 9-month period was $97 million or $0.67 per diluted share based upon the normalized tax rate of 35% compared to a loss of $47 million or a loss of $0.33 per diluted share for the first 9 months of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $262 million for the 9-month period in 2016 as compared to $33 million in the first 9 months of 2015.
Moving on to Slide 5 and a review of our segment results. Beginning with OSB. OSB reported net sales for the third quarter of 2016 of $282 million, up 41% from $200 million reported in the third quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $83 million compared to $4 million reported in the third quarter of 2015. Sales volumes were up 5%. Sales pricing was higher by 36%, which improved operating results by $75 million. Reduction in raw material costs and higher utilization rates also improved the third quarter 2016 results as compared to the third quarter of 2015. 
For the first 9 months of 2016, OSB reported sales of $752 million compared to $601 million of sales in the first 9 months of 2015. For the first 9 months, OSB reported adjusted EBITDA of $172 million as compared to negative adjusted EBITDA of $13 million in the first 9 months of 2015. Sales volumes were lower by 1%, and sales prices were higher by 27%. The impact of the higher sales price on OSB operations was $161 million in the first 9 months of 2016 compared to the same period in the last year. Reduction of raw material costs, higher utilization rates as well as a positive impact of the Canadian currencies on expenses incurred by our Canadian operations also improved the 9-month 2016 results as compared to the first 9 months of 2015. 
Slide 6 reports the results of the Siding business. This segment includes our SmartSide and CanExel siding products as well as minor amounts of OSB. Siding reported net sales for the third quarter of 2016 of $195 million, up 23% from $158 million in the third quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was $42 million compared to $22 million in the third quarter of 2015. SmartSide volumes what up 25% from the prior year. SmartSide -- sales prices in SmartSide were up 1%, primarily due to changes in product mix, with individual prices remaining relatively flat. 
The Siding segment reported sales of $583 million in the first 9 months of 2016, an increase of 18% from $495 million reported in the first 9 months of 2015. Siding segment reported adjusted EBITDA of $125 million as compared to $95 million in the same period of 2015. SmartSide sales volumes were up 15% for the first 9 months of 2016 compared to the same period in 2015, with sales prices down 1% for SmartSide. 
Please turn to Slide 7 of the presentation, which shows the results of our Engineered Wood Products segment. This segment includes I-Joist, Laminated Strand Lumber, Laminated Veneer Lumber, OSB produced at our Houlton, Maine facility plus other related products. This segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi joint venture or under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. The Engineered Wood Products segment recorded sales of $81 million in the third quarter of 2016, up from $74 million in the third quarter of 2015. For the third quarter of 2016, adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations improved by $1 million as compared to the third quarter of 2015. Volumes of I-Joist were up 1% while volumes of LVL and LSL were up 9% compared to the same quarter of last year. Pricing increased 2% in LVL, LSL and I-Joist. 
For the first 9 months, sales were $231 million, up from $211 million in 2015. And adjusted EBITDA improved to $9 million from $3 million in the first 9 months of 2015. 
Moving on to Slide 8 of the presentation. For the quarter, our South American segment recorded sales of $32 million as compared to $27 million in the third quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA of $6 million was higher by $2 million as compared to the third quarter of 2015. Volumes in Chile were down 3% and down 9% in Brazil compared to the same quarter of last year. On a U.S. dollar basis, pricing was up 13% in Chile and up 10% in Brazil. In local currency, Chile's pricing was up 10% compared with the same quarter in 2015 and Brazil's pricing was flat. 
For the first 9 months, our South American segment recorded sales of $103 million as compared to $101 million in the first 9 months of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA for the first 9 months of 2016 increased to $22 million from $13 million in the same period in 2015.
Total selling, general and administrative costs were $47 million in the third quarter of 2016 compared to $38 million in the same quarter of 2015. For the 9-month period, our selling, general and administrative costs are $136 million for 2016 compared to $115 million for the first 9 months of 2015. For both the quarter and 9-month period, the increase on these costs was primarily due to increases in certain management incentive and higher costs associated with sales and marketing.
Turning to the balance sheet. We announced 2 transactions in the third quarter which impacted our balance sheet. During the quarter, we refinanced our $350 million senior unsecured notes with an interest rate of 7.5% due 2020 with new senior unsecured notes which carry a 4 7/8% interest rate and will mature in 2024. This transaction will decrease our annual interest expense by approximately $9 million on an annual basis. 
We also announced during the quarter that we have entered into agreement to provide for the acceleration of $410 million of notes receivable from asset sales. At the same time, we gave binding notice the pay off $369 million of related notes payable. This transaction will be completed tomorrow. As a result of the transaction, LP will accelerate the receipt of $41 million of cash. This will also accelerate the income taxes of $121 million associated with the gain on the sale of timber in 2003. We anticipate offsetting much of the accelerated income tax with available carryover benefits. 
Please turn to Slide 9 of the presentation. As of September 30, 2016, we had cash, cash equivalents, investments and restricted cash of $673 million including the cash held for bond redemption or $580 million excluding that cash held for the bond redemption; working capital of $793 million; net cash of $225 million. In addition to the $580 million of cash on our balance sheet, we have $200 million of availability on our credit facility. 
We are projecting the capital expenditures for 2016 will be in the $115 million to $125 million range. For 2017, we are planning on spending approximately $140 million of capital. This estimate includes $40 million for our South American operations but does not include any capital to convert or build a new siding mill. 
We also anticipate beginning to pay cash taxes in the U.S. in 2017. The U.S. represents approximately 70% to 75% of our net income -- of our income before taxes. We don't anticipate paying cash taxes in Canada due to net operating loss carryovers. The benefit amount of our available Canadian net operating losses was $64 million at the end of 2015. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Curt.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sallie. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on today's call. Before I begin my remarks, I do want to acknowledge the passing last week of Harry Merlo, LP's first and longest-serving Chief Executive Officer. While Harry was often a controver
componenttext:
Thank you, Sallie. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on today's call. Before I begin my remarks, I do want to acknowledge the passing last week of Harry Merlo, LP's first and longest-serving Chief Executive Officer. While Harry was often a controversial leader, there is no doubt that he was instrumental in introducing OSB to the world and promoting the vision of OSB-based siding. 
I will start with our safety performance. Through the first 9 months of this year, our total incident rate or TIR was at 0.39, and this was also the rolling 12-month TIR. We are on track for our second-best safety year ever. One recent highlight, our Panguipulli mill in Chile, last week, achieved 1.5 million hours without a recordable injury, a remarkable achievement. The safety of our employees is LP's core value, and I continue to be extremely proud of all of our employees who support this view and act accordingly. 
Today, I'll be providing comments on our results and accomplishments in the quarter, provide a little more background to the transaction we announced last Friday with Norbord, discuss the promotion of Brad Southern to Chief Operating Officer and give you my views on the outlook for the rest of this year and into 2017. I know Sallie just went through our financial results in detail, but I do want to talk about a few items because it feels so good. 
Total sales in Q3 were 28% higher than Q3 of last year and produced net income of $66 million or EPS of $0.45. For the fourth consecutive quarter, all of our business segments recorded positive EBITDA, and that totaled $111 million for the company in Q3. In Siding, our big growth business, our revenue grew 23% versus the same quarter of last year and adjusted EBITDA was at $42 million. On a year-to-date basis, our sales were up 18%, net income is $108 million and adjusted EBITDA, as Sallie said, was $262 million. 
Let me discuss the mill swap with Norbord. As I did mention last quarter, we continue to explore options to building a greenfield mill in Minnesota as the foundation for our next siding expansion. Last Friday, both LP and Norbord issued press releases that described the mill swap between our 2 companies. Let me explain the rationale from LP's perspective and our preliminary plans going forward. 
LP's Chambord mill has been indefinitely curtailed since 2008, the beginning of the downturn. Norbord's Val-d'Or mill has been curtailed since 2012. While curtailed, both mills had a skeleton crew, who maintained the equipment in the shortest time necessary for a future startup. When assessing the facilities as potential siding mills, we had earlier determined that Chambord did not have ready access to the right wood species, aspen, to make a quality siding product. However, Val-d'Or is an area where there is an abundance of aspen. 
A complicating factor for both companies as we think about restarting these mills is the actions taken by the Québec government in the last 2 years to terminate the wood licenses for both mills due to a lack of cutting activity. A first priority for us is to work with the Québec government to obtain an appropriate wood allocation to run the Val-d'Or facility. To that end, I have had initial conversations with the chiefs of staff in both the premier's and the forestry minister's offices in Québec. 
As I said in the last call, the timing for additional siding capacity is near the end of 2018. For a new mill, the permitting, construction and start-up period is likely to be 24 to 30 months. With an existing mill, we believe that the conversion can take place in less than half that time. Upon closing later this week, we will immediately begin the engineering assessment to determine the cost and timing of such a project. 
In addition to the swap of Chambord for Val-d'Or, we also acquired a former Ainsworth OSB site located in Cook, Minnesota during the last quarter. This will allow us, again, to further expand siding at the appropriate time. I'm very pleased with this result, and this will allow us to continue to work with the very supportive Minnesota elected officials in the IRRRB that -- to redirect the incentives to a size that we believe is better suited from a site development infrastructure perspective than the proposed Hoyt Lakes site. 
Last Thursday, I did speak to Governor Dayton, Senator Bakk, House Speaker Daudt and U.S. Representative Nolan, and they all pledged their support for this future project. We have not yet finalized the accounting implication of this transaction as we are waiting on third-party appraisals of the assets involved. However, we do not believe this will be material. More to come as we make progress with our discussions with the Québec government regarding the wood allocation, reengage with Minnesota officials on the incentives, and begin the engineering assessment at both Val-d'Or and the Cook, Minnesota sites. 
Last Friday, our Board of Directors did elect Brad Southern to a newly created position of Chief Operating Officer. Many of you have met Brad as he's been a regular participant at investor conferences and also was at the Analyst Day we hosted last year in Two Harbors. Brad joined LP in 1999 as the Controller of our Specialty business. Over the next few years, he moved into increasingly complex operating roles. In 2004, Brad became the General Manager of the Siding business. In that role, he was the primary architect of the segment strategy that we've put in place during the housing downturn to focus on repair, remodeling, nonresidential structures and retail, in addition to new home construction. In March of 2015, Brad took over the OSB business and has been instrumental in improving our operating performance and logistics. By the way, along the way, Brad was also the executive sponsor of our successful SAP implementation in 2013. 
In this new role, Brad will maintain direct responsibility for the OSB business and will have the general managers of Siding and EWP report to him, along with our senior VP of sales and marketing and the VP of manufacturing services. Brad will remain the Chairman of the Board of our LP South America operation. 
The elevation of Brad to this new role is part of an ongoing succession planning process that our board has had in place for many years. You may recall that I moved from CFO to COO about 5 years ago. I am not retiring anytime soon, and I also will not speculate on when that time might come. As the LP board has done in the past, we are making sure that we have qualified internal successors to assume leadership in all of our key roles when the time comes. I'm very pleased to have Brad in this position as his experience will be invaluable as we continue to take advantage of an improving housing market. 
Let me talk about the housing market. Q3 housing starts were basically flat for both Q2 of this year and to Q3 of last year. However, the mix between multifamily and single family moved in our favor, with single family growing at 8% while multi-family declined slightly. Also, as permits are a leading indicator, we are pleased to see an increase of over 6% to 1.23 million in the September results. With 1 quarter to go, the consensus for 2016 housing starts now stands at 1.174, a relatively slight 6% increase from last year. For next year, the current consensus is 1.272, an 8% increase over this year's forecast. 
There have been some other positive housing-related data released recently. New home sales, August is the last reported period, were up 20.5% compared to August of 2015. Existing inventory of single-family homes fell to 2.04 million, 10% below August of last year. 
On the financing side, the average 30-year fixed mortgage rates were largely unchanged compared to last quarter at 3.47% for the week ended October 14. Retail sales for building materials, garden equipment and supply dealers were about 1.5% higher than Q2. 
In Canada, third quarter starts were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of a little over 200,000, about a 1% increase from the second quarter and down about 5.5% from Q3 of last year. As I mentioned, the current forecast for 2016 shows 6% growth in housing starts, almost all of this from single family. For 2017, we should see demand for housing continue to increase, driven primarily by increased household formations and wage growth. However, because of numerous constraints, labor, adequate lots, regulatory costs and timing, I think that the growth rate in housing will once again be between 5% and 10%. We will likely see a trend towards starter homes as the first-time homebuyer appears to be coming back. 
I recently attended the Policy Advisory Board meeting of the Harvard Joint Center for Housing Studies. Among other presentations at the meeting, they did provide their forecast for household formations for the next 20 years based on demographics and, immigration, and their forecast of future home ownership rates. For household formation, this group is forecasting 13.6 million net new households in the period 2015 through 2025 and 12.4 million net new households in the next 10-year period. Coupled with household removals due to demolition, catastrophe or conversion plus second home, this is good news for the housing industry. 
On homeownership, they concluded they could go up or down from the current 62%. The low end of the range was 61%, and their high end was 64.5%. Also at the meeting, the Harvard group reaffirmed their forecast that growth in repair, remodeling expenditures should continue at about 4% for the next several years. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Sallie for questions.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
