componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. All right. And can you give us a sense of kind of what capacity would be at either of those 2 -- at each of those 2 sites?
componenttext: Yes, okay. All right. And can you give us a sense of kind of what capacity would be at either of those 2 -- at each of those 2 sites?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Val-d'Or mill is going to -- I think the rated capacity for OSB, about 320 million, 330 million. You have to discount that for Siding. So it's probably going to be in the 250 million to 260 million range roughly. And if we were to do something at the
componenttext: The Val-d'Or mill is going to -- I think the rated capacity for OSB, about 320 million, 330 million. You have to discount that for Siding. So it's probably going to be in the 250 million to 260 million range roughly. And if we were to do something at the Cook site, my guess is that would be a 400 million kind of capacity mill given the equipment that we have already existing in North America.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. Just switching gears a little bit. Can you also give us an update on kind of where you're at down -- with the third mill down in Chile?
componenttext: Okay. All right. Just switching gears a little bit. Can you also give us an update on kind of where you're at down -- with the third mill down in Chile?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can. We have approved the project. We approved that at the July meeting. We have acquired about $15 million worth of the equipment. Most of that is either on site or on its way down, and we have started the site preparation. So that's where we are now.
componenttext: I can. We have approved the project. We approved that at the July meeting. We have acquired about $15 million worth of the equipment. Most of that is either on site or on its way down, and we have started the site preparation. So that's where we are now.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if we think, Curt, about CapEx for '17, I know you put out that $140 million number, but you said that doesn't include anything on Siding. So should we -- could we assume that if you move ahead with Val-d'Or that, that number is $30 million to $
componenttext: Okay. And if we think, Curt, about CapEx for '17, I know you put out that $140 million number, but you said that doesn't include anything on Siding. So should we -- could we assume that if you move ahead with Val-d'Or that, that number is $30 million to $40 million higher?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think you can assume that yet because if we do Val-d'Or, we don't need the capacity until the end of the fourth quarter of 2018. Most of that work would actually be spent -- or the money would be spent towards the end of 2017 into '18, but I don't
componenttext: I don't think you can assume that yet because if we do Val-d'Or, we don't need the capacity until the end of the fourth quarter of 2018. Most of that work would actually be spent -- or the money would be spent towards the end of 2017 into '18, but I don't have a good handle on that yet. I mean we've been in the mill a very short amount of time, so we still have a pretty significant engineering evaluation to complete.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And finally, just with this clarity on Siding, which I think is great, can you just update us on your Engineered Wood business and how you're thinking about that? Your margins are still running pretty low in that business. And I guess I'm
componenttext: Okay. All right. And finally, just with this clarity on Siding, which I think is great, can you just update us on your Engineered Wood business and how you're thinking about that? Your margins are still running pretty low in that business. And I guess I'm also just curious, with sort of clearer runway now in Siding, whether that changes your view of the engineered wood business.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say a couple of things. One, I'd just remind you on the margins. Because we looked at the competitive margins between us and Boise and Weyerhaeuser who just reported, and our margins for our manufactured products are pretty much right on top of
componenttext: Well, I'd say a couple of things. One, I'd just remind you on the margins. Because we looked at the competitive margins between us and Boise and Weyerhaeuser who just reported, and our margins for our manufactured products are pretty much right on top of theirs. The difficulty you get is Weyerhaeuser looks like they're reporting it coming out of distribution not as a pure manufacturing play. But the reminder is, the JV, we sell 100% of the product but we only get half of the margin out of that. And then whatever we sell from Murphy Plywood into the West and into export markets, we only get a sales margin on that. So when you look at it, we don't have the outset base, so we'd have spent the capital but our margins look lower. The good news in Q3 is that what's been a drag on this business for some period of time is when we converted the Houlton mill into Laminated Strand Lumber, and we had the best volumes in Laminated Strand Lumber in the third quarter that we've ever had. And actually, that mill was EBITDA positive for the first time, I think, ever since -- well, since we've converted it. So we have good momentum on the LSL side. That will continue. And then the second thing I would say is we did have the Forest Economic advisory guys in here, and they continue to say that we're going to see a shortage of LVL as the housing starts get towards 1.4 million, which leads us to believe that, that's probably a business that we ought to continue to hold on to, to take advantage of the market when it does come back. That is a market that is heavily tied to single-family new construction. And as that becomes a greater part -- or the housing starts are actually happening, plus housing starts grow, we think that we will get that business back into the profitable region that we had -- we enjoyed in 2003 and 2004.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Gail Glazerman with Roe Equity Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Gail Glazerman with Roe Equity Research.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to the Siding expansion. Would there -- assuming you can get the wood license from the government, would there actually be potential at that site for further expansion beyond the existing capacity?
componenttext: Going back to the Siding expansion. Would there -- assuming you can get the wood license from the government, would there actually be potential at that site for further expansion beyond the existing capacity?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- again, Gail, I think we have to complete the engineering evaluation. We have done that at 2 of our smaller mills, which this would be bigger than those mills but less than the Swan. And ways you can expand that is you could add extra platens to
componenttext: I think -- again, Gail, I think we have to complete the engineering evaluation. We have done that at 2 of our smaller mills, which this would be bigger than those mills but less than the Swan. And ways you can expand that is you could add extra platens to the press to get a little more capacity. We did that at Two Harbors, increased capacity by 35%. And then at Tomahawk, we added platens to increase that capacity by 50%. So that would -- may be an opportunity, but I don't have the engineering expertise to answer that right now.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I presume there are no restrictions in terms of the transfer -- the swap agreement with Norbord and how you use that site. So if you chose not to go ahead with Siding, in theory, it would still be an option for OSB?
componenttext: Okay. And I presume there are no restrictions in terms of the transfer -- the swap agreement with Norbord and how you use that site. So if you chose not to go ahead with Siding, in theory, it would still be an option for OSB?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are no restrictions in it either way.
componenttext: There are no restrictions in it either way.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And just switching gears. Can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the OSB market, specifically maybe some of the price gaps? Last quarter, you talked about the gap between commodity and flooring. And also, just in recent weeks, th
componenttext: All right. And just switching gears. Can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the OSB market, specifically maybe some of the price gaps? Last quarter, you talked about the gap between commodity and flooring. And also, just in recent weeks, there's been incremental pressure in Western Canada that we're not necessarily seeing in other regions.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the quarter, it was a little bit -- from a regional pricing, it's pretty much a mirror of Q2. I don't think we saw any big differences between how the market reacted in Q3 than in Q2. What you saw is a little weakness at the beginning of the quarter, t
componenttext: In the quarter, it was a little bit -- from a regional pricing, it's pretty much a mirror of Q2. I don't think we saw any big differences between how the market reacted in Q3 than in Q2. What you saw is a little weakness at the beginning of the quarter, then it strengthened. I think a couple of things I would say is that the market is -- was so tight from a demand capacity that any anomaly that happened in the market would drive pricing up, then it would kind of drift back down, then we'd have another event and it would drive pricing back up. And that's kind of what we saw. I've been actually encouraged that October hasn't come off much because, historically, you would see pricing coming off on the fourth quarter. And I think random is only down in a single region last week and flat in the other ones, and that's been kind of the case the last couple of weeks.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm just wondering, anything specific that you sense driving the weakness in Western Canada of late? And then also, just if you could touch on the flooring versus commodity. Do you feel that -- is that what you were saying mirrors kind of recent tren
componenttext: Yes. I'm just wondering, anything specific that you sense driving the weakness in Western Canada of late? And then also, just if you could touch on the flooring versus commodity. Do you feel that -- is that what you were saying mirrors kind of recent trends?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Western Canada, we did have the capacity come online with the Tolko mill that has been ramping up. So I think that's been a little bit of a drag on the pricing.
componenttext: Well, Western Canada, we did have the capacity come online with the Tolko mill that has been ramping up. So I think that's been a little bit of a drag on the pricing.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And was there any impacts, either in terms of operations, wood supply or customer demand, from the hurricane?
componenttext: Okay. And was there any impacts, either in terms of operations, wood supply or customer demand, from the hurricane?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We probably saw -- and I can't even tell you for your sure whether we did. We might have seen a little bit of incremental demand from the box stores. But it takes so long for the money to flow through the system for rebuilding. We're still dealing wit
componenttext: No. We probably saw -- and I can't even tell you for your sure whether we did. We might have seen a little bit of incremental demand from the box stores. But it takes so long for the money to flow through the system for rebuilding. We're still dealing with Sandy. We're probably getting benefits from Sandy now, not from Matthew.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I was thinking that there might be like building sites that didn't work. And then just one last one. As you look at the softwood lumber agreement and potential for trade action, last quarter, you talked about maybe potential demand for engineered wo
componenttext: Okay. I was thinking that there might be like building sites that didn't work. And then just one last one. As you look at the softwood lumber agreement and potential for trade action, last quarter, you talked about maybe potential demand for engineered wood from that. And also, if you could just give any further update. And also, any risk to wood costs in Canada?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would respond to that in a couple of ways. One, I was a little bit surprised by the strength of West Fraser and Canfor's earnings. And I think a lot of that is they shipped one hell of a lot of lumber into the U.S. and benefited from the low Canadian
componenttext: So I would respond to that in a couple of ways. One, I was a little bit surprised by the strength of West Fraser and Canfor's earnings. And I think a lot of that is they shipped one hell of a lot of lumber into the U.S. and benefited from the low Canadian currency and shipped that lumber into the U.S. And if we do have trade duties in the 25% to 30% level that will go in place next year, that will probably limit the amount that comes from Canada. So I think that was an impact that we saw on Q3 because their earnings were very good. As far as the impacts on engineered wood, I still believe, if you add 30% to the cost of Canadian lumber, that we should have some benefit in I-Joist and LVL. But we didn't see anything in the third quarter. We're not anticipating for those duties actually being collected until probably early in the second quarter of next year.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any risk to your fiber supply up in Canada?
componenttext: And any risk to your fiber supply up in Canada?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't -- no, I don't think so because we buy a different fiber than the lumber guys. We buy primarily hardwood. The only impact we've had in the past is like with the beetle kill, if you're doing a mixed stand, I think it becomes a little more expensive
componenttext: I don't -- no, I don't think so because we buy a different fiber than the lumber guys. We buy primarily hardwood. The only impact we've had in the past is like with the beetle kill, if you're doing a mixed stand, I think it becomes a little more expensive to log it. But other than that, I think it should be very minimal.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from George Staphos with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from George Staphos with Bank of America.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick things. First of all, back to the ability to hold onto Engineered Wood Products as you're looking towards 1.4, 1.5 start type of environment. Do you think you have enough veneer capacity to keep up with that level of demand? Recogni
componenttext: Just a couple of quick things. First of all, back to the ability to hold onto Engineered Wood Products as you're looking towards 1.4, 1.5 start type of environment. Do you think you have enough veneer capacity to keep up with that level of demand? Recognize that maybe prices on products would move up. How do you think, Curt, your margin cost would hold up in that environment? Second question that I had, just in terms of working capital, it looks like you had a relatively good quarter here. Could you remind us what might have been going on in the quarter in terms of working capital for LPX? And then I had one quick follow-on.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me address the veneer demand. I'll let Sallie talk about working capital. On the veneer demand, we only create our own veneer in one facility. That's in Golden, BC. And we have forestry licenses there for the next 25 years. So I don't have any c
componenttext: Okay. Let me address the veneer demand. I'll let Sallie talk about working capital. On the veneer demand, we only create our own veneer in one facility. That's in Golden, BC. And we have forestry licenses there for the next 25 years. So I don't have any concern about veneer demand in British Columbia. We have a very good wood supply and a very good 10 years there. And in the case of Murphy Plywood, Murphy creates their own veneer, so he's not on the open market. So he has plywood operations, so he provides himself. So as long as we have that manufacturing arrangement, again, I don't get too concerned about veneer availability on the West Coast. The one facility we would have a risk from a veneer standpoint is in Wilmington, North Carolina. But we've had long-term supply agreements with a number of plywood producers there. I think that it would be more of a cost than it will be an availability. So I think we're probably okay, but that would be the one I would look at as the most at risk because we don't control the veneer.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. But you think that you. . .
componenttext: Right. But you think that you. . .

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will also hasten to add -- I hasten to add that on the East Coast, that's where we have our laminated strand facility, and we do have good wood supply for that.
componenttext: I will also hasten to add -- I hasten to add that on the East Coast, that's where we have our laminated strand facility, and we do have good wood supply for that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough on that one.
componenttext: Fair enough on that one.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, George, in terms of working capital, as OSB becomes a bigger piece of our working capital, the day sales outstanding on OSB are shorter than the other 2 businesses. So that is reflected pretty clearly in the improvements in the cash conversion
componenttext: So I think, George, in terms of working capital, as OSB becomes a bigger piece of our working capital, the day sales outstanding on OSB are shorter than the other 2 businesses. So that is reflected pretty clearly in the improvements in the cash conversion cycle or the DSO. And likewise, as we spend more money on capital, we tend to see more money that's in capital and accounts payable. So that's the biggest drivers, along with all 4 of our general managers really continuing to take a focus on inventory and making sure that we have inventory that -- at the right levels, given the demand going on in the market. So we've seen a slight decrease in inventories in the third quarter.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Most of my other questions were already asked. But one quick thing on EWP again, Curt, if you would. To the extent that we look at your results versus other players and recognizing there are moving parts and directly comparable results are probably
componenttext: Okay. Most of my other questions were already asked. But one quick thing on EWP again, Curt, if you would. To the extent that we look at your results versus other players and recognizing there are moving parts and directly comparable results are probably difficult to get at, how do you think your shares are doing within engineered wood relative to your peers? Do you think you're maintaining, growing, losing? And to the extent you can comment, why would that be your view?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our growth rate in volume sales was about the same as the industry, so it wasn't that far off. The big market share gain in the Q3 and actually Q2 as well was when Boise bought GP, so you combine the GP market share into the Boise numbers. Although, on
componenttext: So our growth rate in volume sales was about the same as the industry, so it wasn't that far off. The big market share gain in the Q3 and actually Q2 as well was when Boise bought GP, so you combine the GP market share into the Boise numbers. Although, on their call, they talked about that 1 plus 1 wasn't 2, they were not able to retain a lot of that business. And I think last quarter, I talked about a lot of the churn that was going on with the consolidation we saw in the pro dealers, with some changes we made in Canada at our distribution. And with the acquisition of GP by Boise, a lot of that business is up in the air. So we won a little -- we probably won more than we've lost, but I wouldn't say it's a market shift between any of the 3 major players at this point. The one shift I would say is that the Canadian -- the smaller Canadian producers are taking more market share at I-Joist, and that's certainly true for us. There's a pricing environment up there that we're just not choosing to play in.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Chip Dillon with Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Chip Dillon with Vertical Research.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, Curt, you have said that the base OSB, to put that in at, say, 400 million square feet, would be around, I think you said, $275,000 to $300,000 at Cook. Now there is existing equipment. If you didn't have existing equipment, how much would
componenttext: First question, Curt, you have said that the base OSB, to put that in at, say, 400 million square feet, would be around, I think you said, $275,000 to $300,000 at Cook. Now there is existing equipment. If you didn't have existing equipment, how much would that cost be? In other words, how much do you save by both their -- using their equipment and repurposing some of your own?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the last few OSB mills that have been built are roughly $325,000 per 1,000. And I haven't heard a number on Martco, but I'm guessing that, that number is about the same. But the 2 Grant mills in South Carolina that now GP owns, our mill in Alabama and
componenttext: So the last few OSB mills that have been built are roughly $325,000 per 1,000. And I haven't heard a number on Martco, but I'm guessing that, that number is about the same. But the 2 Grant mills in South Carolina that now GP owns, our mill in Alabama and the joint venture mill in Peace Valley were all in that $310,000 to $325,000 kind of range.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: And there were a slew of plants shut down, in fact, other Potlatch/Ainsworth ones, in that famed area and a lot of others that were shut down, I guess, in '06 and '07. And so what you're suggesting, I guess, is that a lot of these facilities are -- you wo
componenttext: And there were a slew of plants shut down, in fact, other Potlatch/Ainsworth ones, in that famed area and a lot of others that were shut down, I guess, in '06 and '07. And so what you're suggesting, I guess, is that a lot of these facilities are -- you would have to spend maybe 80% of what you would spend to get them back to running again as much as you would spend on a new mill. In other words, it might not -- that's just an argument why it might not be worth even building these things or restarting them because you'd have to go ahead and build a whole new mill and maybe you'd want to start from scratch anyway. Does that make sense?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, in a lot of ways, it does because you can have the newest technology. But the advantage of Cook, for us, it's in the same region where the Hoyt Lake site was. It's a good aspen wood basket. We have the incentives both from an operating stan
componenttext: Well, I think, in a lot of ways, it does because you can have the newest technology. But the advantage of Cook, for us, it's in the same region where the Hoyt Lake site was. It's a good aspen wood basket. We have the incentives both from an operating standpoint and to offset some of the construction cost. And the Cook site is already got rail to it. It's already got a woodyard on it, that we happen to -- actually, we've been using that woodyard for the last couple of years as a satellite yard to our other mills in the area. So it's got good logistics, it's got a good labor force in the area. So there's some real advantages to using that site rather than just starting with a piece of raw land. I'd just give you -- I'll give you an example. At the Hoyt Lakes site, we figured it was going to cost us $30 million to bring rail in, and that included building a trestle over the river, dealing with wetlands, putting the track in. And we won't have to spend that now.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Now shifting gears a little bit. Sallie, that was a great rundown about the whole timber unwind. And so it looks like, obviously, the -- you'll make $41 million in cash, but then you're going to give some of that up and maybe all of it in term
componenttext: Understood. Now shifting gears a little bit. Sallie, that was a great rundown about the whole timber unwind. And so it looks like, obviously, the -- you'll make $41 million in cash, but then you're going to give some of that up and maybe all of it in terms of the deferred taxes being paid. And you did mention that of that $121 million, a bit of it would be offset by carryovers. And I know we can kind of make a guess looking at the K from last year, but can you just give us a rough ballpark? I mean, do you think half of that $121 million? Or is it 2/3 or 1/3? What would you kind of ballpark that at?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's -- and I think we actually put this into the original announcement. It was a little over $70 million deferred tax asset that will be used.
componenttext: It's -- and I think we actually put this into the original announcement. It was a little over $70 million deferred tax asset that will be used.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. So we should basically think that this whole thing is going to cost you $10 million, that you'll use the $70 million -- so your cash taxes are $50 million and then you get $41 million from unwinding the receivable, payable, so your net cost is
componenttext: Okay, okay. So we should basically think that this whole thing is going to cost you $10 million, that you'll use the $70 million -- so your cash taxes are $50 million and then you get $41 million from unwinding the receivable, payable, so your net cost is $10 million.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: From a cash basis, yes. But then you have to think about what our earnings are in '16 and that we'll start paying taxes on those because this will use up our -- for the U.S., it will use up our deferred tax assets and then some.
componenttext: From a cash basis, yes. But then you have to think about what our earnings are in '16 and that we'll start paying taxes on those because this will use up our -- for the U.S., it will use up our deferred tax assets and then some.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I see. So indirectly, there'll be a little more cost, to the extent you're profitable in the U.S. in the -- this year. I got you. And then the last question is -- just to make sure I've heard this right. You said, I think, Curt, in Chile, you'd bough
componenttext: Yes, I see. So indirectly, there'll be a little more cost, to the extent you're profitable in the U.S. in the -- this year. I got you. And then the last question is -- just to make sure I've heard this right. You said, I think, Curt, in Chile, you'd bought -- was that 1-5 million, $15 million in equipment that you'd already bought?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Connelly with CLSA.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Scott Liebman in for Mark. Two quick questions for you. The first one is, in the third quarter, how much of the rise in OSB prices hit your engineered wood business? And is that a fairly normal amount? And what are your thoughts on the fourth quar
componenttext: This is Scott Liebman in for Mark. Two quick questions for you. The first one is, in the third quarter, how much of the rise in OSB prices hit your engineered wood business? And is that a fairly normal amount? And what are your thoughts on the fourth quarter assuming OSB prices hold where they are?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was relatively small amount. It's probably between $1 million and $1.5 million. And what -- part of the offset to that is we did sell some OSB out of Houlton. So if you net it, it was probably right around $1 million negative impact.
componenttext: It was relatively small amount. It's probably between $1 million and $1.5 million. And what -- part of the offset to that is we did sell some OSB out of Houlton. So if you net it, it was probably right around $1 million negative impact.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Houlton's in that segment?
componenttext: Okay. And Houlton's in that segment?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you, okay. And then just looking at the idle OSB capacity that's out there in North America right now. How much of that capacity do you think might ultimately restart if housing was a little bit stronger than we're experiencing now?
componenttext: Got you, okay. And then just looking at the idle OSB capacity that's out there in North America right now. How much of that capacity do you think might ultimately restart if housing was a little bit stronger than we're experiencing now?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that as the rule of thumb, and I've talked about this before, it's about 1.1 billion square feet of demand for every 100,000 housing starts. So if you think we're going to have 80,000 housing starts, there's going to be demand of roughly 900
componenttext: Well, I think that as the rule of thumb, and I've talked about this before, it's about 1.1 billion square feet of demand for every 100,000 housing starts. So if you think we're going to have 80,000 housing starts, there's going to be demand of roughly 900 million square feet that we're going to need on top of that. And I haven't seen the industry numbers, but I've seen what Weyerhaeuser ran at, which they said ran at 102% of capacity in the third quarter. And I think Norbord was in the high 90s. We were in the low 90s. And now with this swap, we're going -- if you took Chambord out of that number, we'd be even a higher percentage. So I don't think there's a lot of available capacity to satisfy that increased 800 million to 900 million square feet of demand next year. So we will need some additional restarts or new mills. And as you know, the Martco mill is slated to start up some time the second half of next year. I don't think it will have a big impact on 2017, but it will on 2018. And then for us, we don't have anything to start unless we start Val-d'Or up as an OSB mill since Chambord is not in our portfolio any longer. And then our competitors, I did read the Norbord transcript, and I think their first priority is going to be the Huguley mill to satisfy demand in the Southeast, Southwest.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Bill Hoffmann with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Bill Hoffmann with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curt, can you talk a little bit about the Cook site? Is there any possibility that you would go -- put OSB capacity in there as well? And is the fiber basket accessible for that?
componenttext: Curt, can you talk a little bit about the Cook site? Is there any possibility that you would go -- put OSB capacity in there as well? And is the fiber basket accessible for that?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you certainly can use aspen for OSB. So there's no -- nothing to a fiber supply that will preclude you from doing that. It's really -- the intention is to make that as siding facility. But one of the things you heard me say is I don't mind being ear
componenttext: Well, you certainly can use aspen for OSB. So there's no -- nothing to a fiber supply that will preclude you from doing that. It's really -- the intention is to make that as siding facility. But one of the things you heard me say is I don't mind being early with siding capacity because I can run OSB until the siding fills it out. So as an example, when we start up Swan Valley, we're running that as a siding mill, but we converted one of the lines at Hayward back to OSB. And so that's -- every month, there's -- we're making less and less OSB as we make more siding. And that's exactly what we would probably do at both Val-d'Or during the conversion and at a additional mill in Cook.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just from a cost standpoint, do you expect that the Cook site can be as cost competitive as your other sites?
componenttext: And just from a cost standpoint, do you expect that the Cook site can be as cost competitive as your other sites?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. I mean, one of our best mills is in Sagola, Michigan, which is not very far away. I don't have any reason to believe it won't be competitive.
componenttext: I think so. I mean, one of our best mills is in Sagola, Michigan, which is not very far away. I don't have any reason to believe it won't be competitive.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Steve Chercover with Davidson.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, beating a dead horse. I just wanted to clarify the ownership of the Cook OSB mill. It was no longer part of the Norbord/Ainsworth family, right?
componenttext: So I guess, beating a dead horse. I just wanted to clarify the ownership of the Cook OSB mill. It was no longer part of the Norbord/Ainsworth family, right?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what happened is before Norbord bought Ainsworth, Ainsworth sold that site to a scrap dealer. They were taking the equipment out and piecemealing it to anybody that wanted to buy the equipment or selling the rest as scrap. We were leasing it from th
componenttext: Well, what happened is before Norbord bought Ainsworth, Ainsworth sold that site to a scrap dealer. They were taking the equipment out and piecemealing it to anybody that wanted to buy the equipment or selling the rest as scrap. We were leasing it from that scrap dealer for the woodyard for the last couple of years. So it has supported our other mills in the region. So no -- so we actually purchased the site last month -- or in September from the scrap dealer.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So as I fly my drone over there, and it looked like there's also a biomass facility or something, but okay. And one other thing, switching gears. Can you discuss the seasonality of siding? Because I think, intuitively, I would have thought that, l
componenttext: Got it. So as I fly my drone over there, and it looked like there's also a biomass facility or something, but okay. And one other thing, switching gears. Can you discuss the seasonality of siding? Because I think, intuitively, I would have thought that, like OSB, peak demand would be in Q3, but that doesn't appear to be the case -- at least the last couple of years.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're right. It's a great question. And I actually -- I have the answer for that. In 10 out of the last 11 years, Q2 has been higher volume than Q3. And the reason for that is that we load up the pre-finishers in Q1 and Q2 for the repair/remodel mar
componenttext: Yes, you're right. It's a great question. And I actually -- I have the answer for that. In 10 out of the last 11 years, Q2 has been higher volume than Q3. And the reason for that is that we load up the pre-finishers in Q1 and Q2 for the repair/remodel market, and then they sell out inventory in Q3 and into Q4.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. Yes, I thought it might be something to do with a prebuy or something. Okay, that makes sense.
componenttext: Got it, okay. Yes, I thought it might be something to do with a prebuy or something. Okay, that makes sense.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually not a prebuy. They don't get a discount. But they don't have the capacity to run what they need during the building season, so they have to run the inventory.
componenttext: It's actually not a prebuy. They don't get a discount. But they don't have the capacity to run what they need during the building season, so they have to run the inventory.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Intuitively, I would have thought people are hustling to kind of seal up any structures that they have in Q3 so they can do the interior work when the weather changes, so I thought it might have had something to do with repair and remodel. But that's
componenttext: Yes. Intuitively, I would have thought people are hustling to kind of seal up any structures that they have in Q3 so they can do the interior work when the weather changes, so I thought it might have had something to do with repair and remodel. But that's great.

componenttext: All right.

componenttext: $250 million to $300 million. So maybe kind of update us on the thinking there. And given that you have such a strong cash position, excellent liquidity and I think you have referenced contemplating at some point the question of returning cash to shareholders, maybe any update on thoughts in that vein?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I said in the last call is that we would come in to our board in early February with an update on kind of our capital allocation and how we would look at that, which would include returning cash to shareholders. We would plan on having that discussio
componenttext: What I said in the last call is that we would come in to our board in early February with an update on kind of our capital allocation and how we would look at that, which would include returning cash to shareholders. We would plan on having that discussion with them in early February. And then if there were an action on a dividend or a share repurchase, probably wouldn't happen until the May meeting. We do have $100 million share repurchase. But as I -- again, what I said in the last meeting is I don't have unanimous support for that at the board. There's varying views. The other thing, I think, that's important is that we've got a lot of opportunities for reinvesting our cash in South America, reinvesting our cash in Siding. We've been doing a lot of work over the last several years on growth and innovation and new products and new markets. So we've got some pretty exciting things that we're trying to explore internally before we either do share repurchase or dividend.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just question on the siding volume. It looks like volumes are up 15% year-to-date, and you're sort of referencing 12% to 14% growth in that business. What is -- if you could dive in on the details on where are you taking market share in that business. And
componenttext: Just question on the siding volume. It looks like volumes are up 15% year-to-date, and you're sort of referencing 12% to 14% growth in that business. What is -- if you could dive in on the details on where are you taking market share in that business. And then just to get to the mill swap with Val-d'Or. Val-d'Or was a mill that Norbord contemplated doing some sidings. Does that preclude Norbord as competing against you in siding?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have reviewed their transcript, and I think Peter did say something about not entering the siding market in the near term. But I hate to speculate on what they might do. As you know, we have a 20-year history in siding. We have early words and beatings
componenttext: I have reviewed their transcript, and I think Peter did say something about not entering the siding market in the near term. But I hate to speculate on what they might do. As you know, we have a 20-year history in siding. We have early words and beatings [ph] around siding. We haven't had anything in the near -- in the last 15 years. It's been a great product with a great warranty history. We do have 140 trained salespeople in the field selling that. We got our marketing team that's probably 15 or 20 people. It would take a lot for somebody to compete against us as at siding, much more than just being able to manufacture the product. As far as where we're seeing growth, home centers were relatively flat. With this -- with the import supply wood coming in from Chile and Brazil, we did see some aggressive pricing on T1-11 siding in the boxes, which, I think, probably hurt our panel siding a little bit. But we've been pretty flat in there. So most of the growth we've seen has been in the repair/remodel side with the pre-finishers. And we've seen growth rate in single-family new construction. And I guess our nonresidential business, the shed business has been very good.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, Curt, you mentioned that you're not retiring anytime soon. But when I dive into your press releases, it looks like you got named COO back in November of 2011 and 6 months later, CEO. Not that I don't have full confidence in Brad, but is that the time line that we're looking at for a transition?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was the time line when I was named, you're right.
componenttext: That was the time line when I was named, you're right.
